Ugh, okay, so like, everyone keeps asking me about the whole surprise thing with Mark and Vanessa. It's not some *huge* philosophical statement, alright? It's just...they're really, really prepared. Like, they've got the nursery decorated, the clothes picked out, the whole nine yards. Everything is *blue*. Seriously, it's a Smurf convention waiting to happen.

And honestly? I kinda wanted to mess with them a little. They're good people, don't get me wrong. Super nice. But they're also...intense planners. I figured a little curveball, a little "Oh, hey, it's a girl!" might be good for them. Force them to, like, *react* instead of just ticking things off a list. 

Plus, it felt...right. Like, this baby deserves a little bit of mystery, you know? It's *their* baby, but it started with *me*. And I didn't know what it was 'til pretty late. So letting them experience that same little bit of the unknown felt...fair. 

It's not about wanting drama, okay? It's about letting them have a moment that isn't perfectly orchestrated. A moment that's just...real. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit funny. Because let's be honest, a room full of blue for a girl? That's pretty hilarious.



Ugh, don't even *get* me started on that lady. Seriously. Like, I get it, she probably sees a lot of… situations. But the *tone*, you know? It was all, "Oh, you're so young, are you *sure* about this?" and then a whole lecture about how adoption isn't just "giving a baby away" like it's a Beanie Baby or something. 

It was just… presumptuous. Like she thought she knew my life story based on, what, my age and the fact that I was lying on a table having a picture taken of a tiny human growing inside me? Newsflash: not all teenage moms are tragic cases waiting to happen. Some of us actually *think* things through.

And the whole adoption thing? I'd already done a ton of research. I knew it wasn't simple. I wasn't just picturing handing over a bundle and walking away. It felt… disrespectful, you know? Like she was implying I hadn't considered the emotional weight of it all. 

Honestly, it just made me want to roll my eyes so hard they got stuck. I mean, I was already dealing with a lot, and I didn't need a stranger judging my choices. It kinda solidified the fact that I needed to find parents who *got* me, who understood I wasn't doing this lightly. It needed to be a good fit, for everyone. And definitely not with someone who thinks they're the expert on my life.



Ugh, okay, so like, where do I even *begin* with the challenges? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, cool, a baby! Let's just find some nice people and hand it over!" 

First off, telling my parents was...intense. My dad, he's a pretty quiet guy, but he got all choked up. My stepmom, Bren, she was surprisingly cool about it, though. She's a good egg, that one. But still, it was awkward. Like, *super* awkward. Explaining to everyone at school was even worse. People just...stared. And whispered. It's like suddenly I was a science experiment or something.

Then there was the whole *finding* the right people thing. It wasn't like browsing a catalog. You're talking about a whole *person*, you know? A tiny human. Mark and Vanessa, they were...different. Really different. And honestly, at first, I was kinda judging them. They were, like, *perfect*. Too perfect. I thought, "Are these people even *real*?" It made me question if I was doing the right thing, if they'd actually understand what I was going through.

And then, there was just...me. Dealing with all the feelings. Being pregnant is weird. Your body is doing this thing, and you're like, "Whoa, hold up, this isn't part of the plan." And then you start thinking about this little person, and you want the best for them, even if that best doesn't include you. It's a lot to process when you're sixteen and mostly concerned with finding vintage clothes and listening to The Moldy Peaches.

Honestly, the biggest challenge wasn't the physical stuff, or even the judgment. It was figuring out who *I* was, and what *I* wanted, all while growing another human. It's a lot of self-discovery when you're also discovering a bun in the oven, let me tell you.



Ugh, okay, deep thoughts time. Don't get me wrong, I still think romantic love is mostly just…overrated. Like, all those movies? Total garbage. But *this*… this isn't about finding a boyfriend or whatever. It's about wanting something good for someone, even if that someone isn't *with* you. Which is weird, right? I mean, I'm giving a baby away, and that's supposed to be the opposite of love, I guess. But it feels…right. Like, the best kind of love is letting go, even when it totally sucks.

Responsibility? Oh, man. Before, responsibility was like, doing my homework and not failing history. Now it's…bigger. It's realizing that actions have consequences, and that those consequences aren't always about *you*. It's about this little person who didn't ask to be here, and making sure they have a good life. It's less about what *I* want and more about what's best for *him* or *her*. It's kinda terrifying, honestly.

And growing up? Forget about it. I thought I was pretty mature for sixteen. I liked old movies, I played guitar, I wasn't obsessed with, like, sparkly vampires. But this… this is a whole different level of grown-up. It's realizing that life isn't some neat little story with a happy ending tied up with a bow. It's messy and complicated and sometimes really, really hard. 

It's also made me realize that adults aren't always as together as they seem. Like, Mark and Vanessa? They're trying so hard to be perfect, but they're just as confused as I am. Maybe even more so. It's kinda comforting, in a weird way. 

So yeah, it's changed things. A lot. I'm still figuring it all out, obviously. But I think… I think I'm okay with that. It's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be a little bit lost. As long as you're trying to do the right thing, I guess.



Ugh, okay, so like, everyone in town is obsessed with that living room set. It's seriously weird. It just... appeared. One day it was a normal, kinda sad-looking lawn, the next BAM! Full-on, perfectly arranged living room. Couch, armchair, coffee table, even a little lamp. Like someone just *decided* that's where a living room should be.

Honestly? It's kinda fascinating. It's like a little pocket of domesticity just... plopped down in the middle of nowhere. Bleaker than my dad's attempts at decorating, and *that's* saying something. 

But mostly, I think it's a statement. Like, someone's trying to say something about, I don't know, the illusion of the perfect family or something. Or maybe they just had a really good deal on furniture. It's hard to tell with people. They're complicated. Especially adults. 

Plus, Paulie Bleeker thinks it's a good spot for, like, philosophical discussions. Which is... a thing. So, yeah, I'm interested. It's a good place to people-watch, and sometimes you can get a decent burger from the diner and eat it on the porch swing. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin the mystique.



Ugh, okay, seriously? Still thinking about the Wizard. That guy was… a lot. And creepy. Like, a *lot* creepy.

When he said that, all whispery and intense, "Do you know how long I've wanted this?"... it wasn't about *me*, okay? It wasn't like he was thrilled to meet *Juno MacGuff*, the witty, independent girl with a penchant for Super Nintendo. No. It was about the baby. 

He and Vanessa, they wanted a kid for *so* long. Like, years. Vanessa couldn't... well, she couldn't have one herself. So he was talking about finally getting the chance to be a dad. It was kinda sad, actually, when you think about it. A little pathetic, even. But also... I guess understandable? People want things. 

It just felt weird coming from *him*, you know? He was all… intense collector vibes with his records and his basement. It made the whole thing feel less about wanting a family and more about wanting to *complete* something. Like a rare vinyl. 

Honestly, it still gives me the shivers a little. But I knew, right then, that they were serious. And that they would be good parents. Even if the dad was a little…off.



Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about the *juice container*? Like that's the important part of the whole thing? Honestly.

Look, it wasn't just *any* juice container. It was a Super Big Gulp, okay? And after... well, after finding out about the whole baby situation with Paulie Bleeker, I needed something. Something sugary and distracting. And then I realized, walking home, that it was just... sitting there. A monument to my questionable life choices. Dramatic, I know. But it felt right to just *fling* it. 

And then, naturally, I needed a pregnancy test. Like, duh. Dancing Elk was the closest place. Mr. Elk is kinda weird, always trying to sell you homeopathic remedies for everything, but they have the tests. Plus, it's not like I was gonna go to, like, Walgreens. Too mainstream. 

It was a whole process, okay? A very emotionally charged process involving a large plastic container and a desperate need for confirmation. Don't judge. It's not like anyone *plans* on this kind of thing.



Ugh. Don't *even* get me started on that. Seriously. Like, what kind of question *is* that? I was just trying to find some prenatal vitamins – you know, being responsible and stuff, even though it's, like, totally weird to be responsible at sixteen – and this woman, this *Tough Girl* as you put it, just corners me in the aisle. 

She's all, sizing me up, and then just blurts it out. "Are those real brown?" Like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo. I mean, hello? Personal space? And honestly, what does the *color* of my nipples have to do with anything? It's just...rude. 

I think she was trying to, like, assess my "maturity" or something, probably deciding if I was a good candidate for...well, for being pregnant. It was just so judgmental. I just kinda stared at her and said, "I don't know, they feel pretty real to me." Which, looking back, was probably a pretty good comeback, if I do say so myself. 

People just assume a lot when they see a girl my age with a bump. It's annoying. It's like, yeah, I'm pregnant, okay? But I'm still *me*. And my nipples are my business.



Ugh, Leah. Don't even get me *started*. Not in a bad way, though. Honestly, I probably would've completely imploded without her. Like, seriously. Picture a supernova of awkwardness and teenage angst – that would've been me.

See, Leah's... well, she's *Leah*. Super into everything, super enthusiastic, always has a craft project going. Which, normally, I'd roll my eyes at. But when I found out about the baby, she was the first person I told, besides Paul, obviously. And she didn't freak. She didn't judge. She just... started knitting.

Like, immediately. A tiny, ridiculously adorable hat. It was kinda overwhelming, actually. But it was also... nice. It meant she was already thinking about the baby, even before I'd really processed it myself. 

She was the one who dragged me to the doctor, you know? I was just kinda hoping it would all go away if I ignored it. Leah doesn't *do* ignoring things. She's all about facing stuff head-on, even if it's terrifying. And she was the one who found the ad, the one with Mark and Vanessa. I wouldn't have even *looked* at something like that. Too… earnest.

Honestly, she was my emotional support system, my research assistant, and my designated tiny-hat-knitter all rolled into one. She kept me from spiraling into a total mess. Plus, she made me laugh, which was crucial. Because, let's be real, the whole situation was pretty ridiculous. And sometimes, you just need a friend to laugh *with* you, not *at* you.

So yeah, Leah was… important. More important than I probably let on at the time. She's a good egg, that one. A little intense, maybe, but a good egg.



Ugh, okay, so *that*. Honestly? It wasn't some grand, thoughtful gesture, alright? It was mostly... desperation, mixed with a healthy dose of wanting to see if they'd, like, completely freak out. I mean, Mark and Vanessa are... *particular*. Very Pottery Barn. Very "perfect life" aesthetic. 

I figured showing them the ultrasound – the little blurry blob, you know? – would be a good test. Like, would they still want a kid knowing it was *real* real? Not just a concept they'd picked out from a brochure. Would they still be all "rustic charm" and "organic cotton" when faced with, well, a tiny human starting to form?

Plus, I kinda needed to see *their* reaction. It was weirdly important to me to know they weren't just doing this because it was the "right" thing to do, or because it would look good. I wanted to see if they actually *wanted* this kid. 

It was a gamble, I admit. A slightly manipulative gamble. But sometimes you gotta poke the bear a little, you know? Just to see if it's a real bear, or just a really fluffy dog in a bear costume. And honestly, seeing their faces... it was worth it. It told me a lot.



Ugh. Honestly? It was...not surprising. Like, not at *all*. Mark is...well, Mark. Sweet, definitely. But also kinda clueless, you know? He's the type to leave a note on the fridge saying "Gone to the library! Be back eventually!" and then wander off to a record store for six hours. 

So when he was all, "Vanessa isn't here," I just kinda raised an eyebrow and thought, "Yeah, no kidding." It wasn't like I expected a full-blown welcome committee or anything. I mean, the whole situation was already...complicated. Finding out *he* was the father was complicated. Finding out *she* wasn't even around to, like, acknowledge the complicated-ness? Just felt about par for the course.

It mostly just made me feel...awkward. Like, I was intruding on his life, and he was clearly trying to navigate a situation he wasn't equipped for. It's not like I was thrilled to be there, either. It was a whole mess of uncomfortable, and honestly, I just wanted to get it over with. You know? Sometimes people just aren't ready for real life, and Vanessa definitely struck me as one of those people.



Ugh, okay, so *that*. Honestly? It wasn't even a fully formed thought, it just kinda...escaped. It's just, like, Mark's all earnest and sensitive and writing music that's, you know, *real*. And then he's selling out to, like, car commercials? It felt...disjointed. Like a really bad mix tape. 

It's not that I think making money is *wrong*, okay? I get it. Rent's a thing. But it felt like he was compromising something important to him, and I just...reacted. I tend to deflect with sarcasm, it's a coping mechanism, alright? Especially when things are feeling weird and complicated, which, let's be real, everything was feeling weird and complicated at that point. 

Plus, it was a pretty cheesy commercial. Seriously. Like, aggressively cheesy. It deserved a little ribbing. Don't judge.



Ugh, Mark. Don't even *get* me started. It was... a lot. Like, the guy went totally pale, then started rambling about how he needed to "re-evaluate his life choices." Re-evaluate? Seriously? We were looking at a little bean on a screen, not deciding whether to buy a timeshare. 

Honestly? It felt kinda… lonely. I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, but I didn't expect him to look like I'd just told him the world was flat. It made me realize pretty quick that this wasn't something *we* were going to figure out together, you know? It was going to be... me figuring it out. 

It wasn't like I was expecting a parade or anything, but a little "Wow, that's... something" would have been nice. Instead, it was just this awkward silence and him staring into the middle distance like he was trying to remember where he parked his car. 

It kinda solidified things, actually. Like, okay, this is happening, and I need to be okay with that, even if *he* isn't. It's just... sometimes people aren't ready for real life, you know? And sometimes, you gotta be the grown-up, even when you're, like, sixteen and still trying to figure out what a 401k is.



Ugh. Havenbrooke. Honestly, the whole *vibe* of that place was…intense. Like, aggressively pro-life. Lots of pictures of babies, you know? And pamphlets. So. Many. Pamphlets. It felt less like a medical clinic and more like a guilt trip waiting to happen.

Look, it wasn't like I *wanted* to be pregnant, okay? It was…unexpected. And yeah, abortion was definitely on the table. I mean, it felt like the logical thing, right? I was sixteen, barely able to handle algebra, let alone a human being. 

But being *there*, at Havenbrooke, with all that…pressure…it just felt wrong. Not morally wrong, necessarily, but wrong for *me*. It felt like they were trying to tell me what to feel, what to do, instead of letting me figure it out myself. And honestly, I hate being told what to do. It's, like, my defining characteristic.

Plus, the counselor kept talking about "the sanctity of life" and I was just thinking, "Lady, have you *seen* the world? Sanctity of life is a little hard to find sometimes." 

It wasn't a decision I took lightly, okay? It was…complicated. But ultimately, I realized I couldn't go through with it. Not because of them, or their pictures, but because…well, it felt like giving up on something before I even really knew what it was. And I'm not really a quitter. Even if quitting would have been a whole lot easier.



Ugh. Okay, look. This is…awkward. Like, *super* awkward. It's not exactly something I volunteer information about, you know? It's not like we sat down and had a whole "Let's discuss the ramifications of unprotected sex" conversation. That would be…intense. And not really *us*.

Paulie Bleeker and I…we'd been friends since, like, forever. Elementary school forever. He was always just *there*. Quiet, kinda dorky, really good at guitar. He wasn't, like, the popular type, and honestly, neither was I. We just…clicked. We bonded over a shared love of bad horror movies and avoiding gym class. 

It happened after a movie marathon at his house. We were both kinda…feeling things, I guess. It wasn't some grand romantic gesture or anything. It was just…impulsive. A moment. A really, *really* poorly timed moment, as it turns out. 

Honestly, I think we were both just trying to figure stuff out, and we figured it out the wrong way. It wasn't about love, not at first. It was… curiosity, I guess. And maybe a little bit of boredom. Don't judge. Teenagers are bored people.

It's funny, because now, looking back, it feels so…naive. Like, we were kids playing at being adults. And then, well, then I found out I wasn't playing anymore. It was real. And suddenly, everything got a whole lot more complicated.



Ugh. Okay, so, like, *how* did I feel? That's a loaded question, right? It wasn't exactly a party in my uterus, let me tell you. It wasn't like I was planning on, you know, popping out a kid with the drummer from a band whose name sounds like a skin condition. Bleeker... honestly, he's sweet, but not exactly Mensa material. 

At first? Mostly just... overwhelmed. And a little bit panicked. Like, seriously panicked. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about getting into a decent college, not, like, gestational diabetes and tiny socks. It felt… weird. Like my life had suddenly been hijacked by a tiny human.

But then, after the initial freak-out, it kinda settled into… well, it was just *there*. It was happening. And I figured, okay, I can't change it, so I gotta figure out what to *do* about it. And that meant finding the right parents. Not just anyone. Someone who would actually *want* him, you know? Someone who could give him a good life. 

It wasn't about *liking* being pregnant, because, honestly, heartburn is the enemy. It was about doing the right thing. Even if the right thing was, like, the hardest thing. And also, trying to find a really good playlist to distract myself from the whole situation. Music helps, you know? A lot.



Ugh. Okay, so telling Paulie... Bleeker, I mean. It wasn't exactly a cinematic moment, you know? No slow-motion, no dramatic music. Just...awkward. Really, *really* awkward.

I found him after school, by the bike racks, naturally. He was trying to look cool leaning against them, all slouchy and brooding, probably thinking about some obscure indie band. And I just...blurted it out. Like ripping off a band-aid, except the band-aid was my entire future. 

"So, uh, remember that time we...you know?" I said, which, looking back, was a *stellar* way to start a conversation about impending parenthood. He just blinked at me, looking like a deer caught in headlights. Then I dropped the bomb. "Well, I'm pregnant."

He went totally pale. Like, legitimately lost all color. He mumbled something about needing to sit down, which, fair enough. I think he thought I was messing with him at first. Like, this was some elaborate prank. Which, honestly, considering my usual level of sarcasm, wasn't entirely unreasonable.

The whole thing was just...quiet. He didn't yell, he didn't freak out, he just...looked *lost*. And honestly, that was almost worse. It wasn't the reaction I expected. I figured he'd be all dramatic, maybe even angry. But he was just...sad. And confused. 

It took a while for him to process it, and honestly, it took a while for *me* to process it too, even *after* I'd already said the words. It wasn't a happy moment, not by a long shot. But it was...real. And that's what mattered, I guess.



Okay, so, like, that's a *big* question. It wasn't...easy. People think it's just, you know, hand the baby over and boom, everything's fine. It's not. It's way more complicated than that. 

Honestly? At first, it was mostly just...panic. Like, full-blown, "my life is over and I'm gonna be stuck changing diapers forever" panic. But then I started thinking, and talking to my dad, and Bleeker (he's...a musician, kinda), and mostly just *thinking*, and I realized keeping it wasn't really an option. Not for me, and definitely not for the baby. I was still in high school! I was barely figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raising a whole person.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, see? It was about wanting the baby to have a good life. A *better* life, maybe. And Mark and Vanessa, the couple I chose...they were amazing. They were, like, genuinely excited and ready. They weren't just looking for a baby, they were looking for *this* baby. 

It still stung, though. A lot. Even knowing it was the right thing. It's weird, you know? Carrying a kid, feeling it kick...it's a really intense connection. And then you consciously choose to...not raise it. It's not something you just *get over*. 

But I figured, the best thing I could do was make sure it was a good situation. And I did. And that, I think, made it...okay. Mostly. It's still something I think about, obviously. But I try to focus on the fact that I gave that little kid a chance at a really good life. And that's...something.



Ugh, okay, so people *always* ask me this. Like, my musical taste defines my entire personality or something. It's kinda reductive, honestly. But fine. I'll indulge.

It's...varied. I'm not one of those people who's like, "Oh, I *only* listen to indie folk." That's just...limiting. I mean, The Moldy Peaches are essential. Don't even *try* to argue with me on that. They just *get* awkwardness, you know? 

But then I also dig stuff like Cat Power, and Belle & Sebastian. Real mellow stuff for when I'm, like, contemplating the universe or whatever. And sometimes, when I need to just...blast everything, I'll put on some early Sonic Youth. It's good for feeling angsty, which, let's be real, happens a lot.

Oh, and don't forget The Velvet Underground. My dad's got a whole bunch of their records. He's kinda a hipster before hipsters were even a thing. 

Basically, if it's a little bit weird and a little bit honest, I'm probably into it. It's gotta have *something* to it, you know? No bubblegum pop for this girl. That stuff just feels...fake.



Ugh. "The Wizard of Gore"? Seriously? Okay, look, I get that Paulie likes his… *intense* cinema. Like, really intense. And I appreciate a good, cheesy scare as much as the next person, especially if it's ironic. But that movie? That's just… a lot. 

It's not even *good* bad, you know? It's just… bad. Like, the special effects look like they were done by a particularly enthusiastic kindergartener with a lot of ketchup. And the whole premise? A wizard who kills people on TV? It's trying too hard to be shocking. It feels desperate. 

Honestly, it's the kind of movie you watch with a group of people and spend the whole time making fun of it. Which, okay, that *can* be fun. But it doesn't hold up on its own. It's like a really awkward date – you might laugh *at* it, but you definitely won't be thinking about it tomorrow.

Plus, it kinda gave me the creeps. And I'm already dealing with enough life changes right now without adding a wizard who dismembers people with a chainsaw to the mix. Just sayin'.



Ugh. Madison. Seriously? It's...fine, I guess. Like, perfectly *fine*. Which is the problem, you know? It's so...beige. It's the name you give a doll when you can't think of anything better. It feels like it should be paired with a matching headband and a tiny purse. 

Not that there's anything *wrong* with beige, per se. Some people *like* beige. But a name? It needs a little...oomph. A little something to make it stick in your brain. Like, a good song needs a killer guitar riff, you know? Madison is more like elevator music.

Look, I'm not saying it's the *worst* name ever. But if you're looking for something with personality, something that says "I'm a unique individual," you might wanna keep looking. Just my two cents. And believe me, I've been thinking a *lot* about names lately. It's kinda important when you're, uh, you know...in the situation I'm in.



Okay, so, like, people always make it sound *so* dramatic, right? "Giving up" a baby. It feels…loaded. Like I'm just casually returning something to the store that doesn't fit. Which, honestly, sometimes it feels like my life *is* just a series of things that don't quite fit.

But seriously, it's not about *giving up*. It's about… wanting something *better*. For the kid, obviously. I mean, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I still haven't figured out what I want for *breakfast*, let alone a whole human life. I can barely keep a houseplant alive, and you want me to raise a tiny person? No thanks. 

It's complicated, okay? It's not like I don't feel *something*. It's just… I know I'm not ready. And honestly, I think it's kinda selfless, you know? Like, recognizing your limitations and doing what's best, even if it sucks for *you*. 

Mark and Vanessa, they seem… good. Really good. Like, actual grown-ups who have their stuff together. They want a kid, and I… well, I have a lot of mixtapes to make and a life to figure out. It's not ideal, but it feels… right. As right as anything feels when you're staring down the barrel of a pregnancy test, anyway.

It's not a happy thing, exactly. It's just… a *real* thing. And sometimes, real life is messy and complicated and doesn't come with a neat little bow on top. You just gotta deal with it, I guess.



Ugh. Okay, so, it's not like anyone *prepares* you for this, you know? Like, they tell you about puberty and awkward dances and trying to figure out if that guy in history actually *likes* you, or if he's just being nice because your mom baked cookies for the class. But nobody mentions the whole… accidental baby thing.

Honestly? It's mostly just compartmentalizing. Like, one minute I'm stressing about a pop quiz in bio, the next I'm trying to figure out if I should get the organic apples or the regular ones because, apparently, what I eat matters now. It's exhausting. 

And the pressure? Oh, *the pressure*. Everyone has an opinion. My mom, bless her heart, is trying to be supportive but also keeps subtly hinting at all the life changes. Blech. Then there's the school thing – whispers, stares, the whole shebang. It's like suddenly I'm a science experiment everyone's observing.

But you kinda just… deal. I mean, what else are you gonna do? Curl up in a ball and cry? I did that for, like, a day. It wasn't productive. So, I just try to be… normal. As normal as a pregnant sixteen-year-old *can* be, I guess. I still listen to The Moldy Peaches, I still hang out with Paulie and Leah, I still try to avoid Mr. Hetrick in the hallway. 

It helps to have a plan, too. Knowing I'm giving the baby to Mark and Vanessa, people who are actually *ready* for a kid? That makes it… less scary. It doesn't make it easy, but it makes it feel like I'm doing something responsible, even if it's the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

Basically, it's a lot of deep breaths, a lot of sarcastic comments to deflect, and a whole lot of hoping I don't accidentally trip and fall on my face in front of the entire school. It's a mess, but it's *my* mess. And I'm figuring it out. Slowly.



Ugh, that's... a big question. Like, existential crisis big. Honestly? It's a constant struggle. I *like* being self-sufficient, you know? I like figuring things out on my own, not having to rely on anyone. It feels... cleaner, I guess. Less messy. 

But then, you get thrown a curveball like... well, like *this* whole situation, and suddenly "clean" goes right out the window. You realize you can't exactly build a human being all by yourself. Or navigate the whole adoption thing, or even just, like, deal with the fact that your life has done a complete 180.

So, you swallow your pride. Which is *hard*, let me tell you. It's like admitting you're not a superhero, even though you totally feel like you should be. You let people help. My dad, he's... well, he's my dad. He's goofy, but he's always there. And Bren, even though she's a total drama queen sometimes, she's a good friend. And Paulie... okay, Paulie's a bit of a mess, but he tries. 

It's about picking your battles, I think. Knowing when to say "I got this" and when to say "Okay, I clearly do *not* got this, someone please help." It doesn't make you weak, it just makes you... human. And sometimes, letting people in is the strongest thing you can do. Even if it feels totally weird and uncomfortable. Especially if it feels totally weird and uncomfortable.



Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so, at first? It was...awkward. Like, *super* awkward. You know, one minute you're bonding over The Cure and feeling all angsty-teenager vibes, and the next minute you've, uh, made a baby. It's not exactly a smooth transition. He was...sweet, I guess. In a quiet, kinda dorky way. He tried, you know? Brought me orange juice and stuff when I was feeling nauseous, which was nice, even if it was the kind with pulp. *Pulp*. Seriously.

But he wasn't exactly equipped to deal with, like, *life*. He was still figuring out his own stuff, playing guitar, trying to get good grades. And I get that. But suddenly needing to talk about things like, "Okay, so we're gonna have a baby, what are we gonna *do*?" was a lot for him. He kinda retreated into himself, which, honestly, was frustrating. 

It wasn't that he didn't care, it was just...he processed things differently. He wasn't gonna be all dramatic and emotional about it, you know? He just...was. And eventually, I realized that was okay. He showed up for the important stuff, like the doctor's appointments and stuff with Mark and Vanessa. He wasn't the one making all the big decisions, but he was *there*. 

We didn't end up as, like, a couple or anything. That wasn't really the point. But we ended up being...friends. Sort of. Friends who made a baby and then gave it to a really awesome couple. It's a weird sentence when you say it out loud. But yeah, it changed. It started awkward, went kinda quiet, and ended up...respectful, I guess. We both grew up a little, even if he still prefers orange juice with pulp. Don't even get me started on that.



Ugh, okay, seriously? This is like, the *first* question people ask. It's not some deep, philosophical thing, alright? My dad... he's kinda into mythology. Like, *really* into it. He and my stepmom, Bren, were naming me and he was going on and on about how Juno was, like, the queen of the gods and a protector of marriage and stuff. 

Honestly, I mostly tuned him out. I was a baby. But apparently, he thought it was ironic, considering he and my biological mom weren't exactly a picture of marital bliss. He said it was a "statement." 

Whatever. It's a name. It's not like I *chose* it. Though, honestly, sometimes I think it fits. I mean, I *am* pretty boss, even if I don't have a whole lot of interest in protecting anyone's marriage. Mostly I just protect my own space and try to avoid awkward conversations. Which, let's be real, is a full-time job.



Ugh, okay, so Vanessa. Right. Honestly? It was...weird. Like, I was expecting a whole *thing*, you know? Tears, maybe a dramatic fainting spell. She's, like, super put-together, always has a plan. So when she just...breathed a sigh of relief when she saw the picture? It threw me. 

She said something about needing to *know* it was actually happening, that it wasn't just some weird dream. Which, okay, fair enough, I guess. Being pregnant is pretty surreal. But it also felt...distant, you know? Like she was already processing it as something to *manage* instead of, like, a tiny human growing inside of me.

It made me think about how different we are, her and I. She's got her whole life mapped out, the perfect house, the perfect husband, the perfect everything. And me? I'm just trying to figure out what I want for lunch most days. It was a good reminder that this whole adoption thing wasn't just about *me* giving a baby away. It was about giving a baby to a family who was ready for it, in their own way. Even if their "ready" looks a little...composed.

It's just...people are complicated, you know? And pregnancy? That's a whole other level of complicated. Don't even get me started on Mark and his whole existential crisis. Seriously.



Ugh, don't *even* get me started on Vanessa's mom, Brenda. Seriously, that woman is a whole *mood*. Like, a really intense, floral-print, passive-aggressive mood. 

Okay, so picture this: I'm chillin' with Vanessa, we're listening to The Moldy Peaches, and suddenly Brenda just *appears*. It wasn't a graceful entrance, either. More like a tactical strike. And the look on her face? Like I'd personally insulted her entire life choices.

She went straight for the "you're a bad influence" speech, which, honestly, is pretty rich coming from someone who decorates her house entirely with porcelain dolls. It's creepy, Brenda, seriously. Anyway, I just kinda... stared her down. I figured if I looked bored enough, she'd run out of steam. 

I think my exact words were something along the lines of, "Look, I get it. You're protective. But Vanessa and I are friends. And frankly, your house smells like potpourri and judgment." 

It didn't *completely* diffuse the situation, but it definitely threw her off. She sputtered a bit, then launched into a whole thing about my "lifestyle" and how I needed to "think about my future." Which, ironic, considering *my* future was currently kicking inside me.

I mostly just kept repeating, "Okay," and nodding slowly. It's a good tactic. Makes people think you're listening when you're really just mentally composing a haiku about the absurdity of it all. Eventually, she just huffed and went to yell at her husband, probably about how I was ruining Vanessa's chances of getting into a good college. 

Honestly, dealing with Brenda was good practice for dealing with... well, everything that was happening. You gotta learn to just roll with the crazy, you know? And sometimes, a well-timed, slightly sarcastic comment is the best defense.



Ugh, okay, so like, it's not exactly a super fun story, you know? It's not like I *wanted* to be pregnant, first of all. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was mostly concerned with finding the perfect vintage dress and figuring out if Paulie Bleeker was actually noticing me, not, like, raising a human. 

And honestly? I just... wasn't ready. It's not that I thought I couldn't *handle* it, exactly. It's more that I knew the baby deserved parents who were, like, *fully* ready. Parents who had their stuff together. Parents who weren't still in high school and whose biggest life decision up to that point was whether to get extra cheese on their tater tots. 

Mark and Vanessa, they were... different. They *wanted* a baby, really wanted one, and they had a beautiful house and a stable life. It just felt... right. Like, the least messed up option in a pretty messed up situation. 

It wasn't easy, don't get me wrong. It's still not easy, thinking about it. But it felt like the most selfless thing I could do. And sometimes, you gotta do the selfless thing, even if it kinda sucks for you. Plus, I figured I had enough drama in my life already. One less tiny human needing a diaper change felt like a win.



Ugh, don't even *get* me started on lab partners. Honestly? It's a whole thing. See, I'm not, like, actively *trying* to be a deadbeat. It's just... my brain kinda wanders. Like, you're supposed to be dissecting a frog or something, and I'm over here contemplating the existential dread of being a frog, you know? Or wondering if the formaldehyde fumes are giving me superpowers. 

And then I get distracted by, like, the *patterns* in the tile floor, or the way Mr. Burns' comb-over defies gravity. It's not that I don't *care* about science, it's just... everything else is so much more *interesting*. 

Plus, Paulie, my usual partner, is... well, he's Paulie. He gets really intense about the scientific method and judges my tangents. It's exhausting. So yeah, I end up letting him do most of the work while I provide moral support and witty commentary. Which, let's be real, is a valuable contribution. It's just not the kind they grade you on.

Basically, I'm a philosophical observer in a world obsessed with frogs. It's a tough life.



Ugh. Seriously? Another dramatic episode in the petri dish of high school? Look, I've seen enough passive-aggressive note-passing and eye-rolling to last me a lifetime, and honestly, lab partners fighting is *so* cliché. It's like, did nobody watch "The Breakfast Club"? 

It usually boils down to one of two things, right? Either he's not pulling his weight and she's doing all the work, which, okay, I get being annoyed about that. Like, contribute, dude! Or, he thinks she's being a control freak. Which, okay, *some* girls can be. Not naming names, obviously.

But honestly, the whole thing is just... exhausting. Like, can't people just *do* the lab and then go back to obsessing over whatever band is currently on their LiveJournal? It's a lab, not a life-or-death situation. Unless they're messing with something really dangerous, in which case, maybe I should just walk away. I've got enough drama in my own life right now, thanks very much. 

It's probably something stupid, like who gets to use the Bunsen burner first. Honestly, the priorities of some people... it's baffling.



Whoa, hold your horses. "Hasty abortion"? That's... a really loaded way to put it. It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Ooh, let's just *get rid* of it!" It's a little more complicated than that, okay?

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I spend most of my time trying to figure out if I should wear Converse or beat-up boots with my jeans, not raising a human. And honestly? My life is... not exactly set up for a baby. My dad's a handyman, my stepmom's obsessed with wreaths, and I'm mostly just trying to survive high school without completely losing my cool. 

It's not that I don't think babies are cool. They're... squishy. And they smell weird. But they also need, like, *everything*. And I can barely keep my own life organized, let alone another person's. 

So, yeah, I was thinking about an abortion. But then I started thinking... maybe there's another way. A better way. It's not a decision I'm taking lightly, okay? It's just... a lot to process. And honestly, it's kinda terrifying.



Don't go judging me, though. It's my body, my life, and my problem. And frankly, I'm trying to figure it out the best way *I* can.



Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *Boone's*? Like, that's the big question of the day? Whatever. But fine, I'll indulge you. It's not even close, honestly. 

See, all the other flavors are just... trying too hard. They're like those kids in high school who wear way too much eyeliner and think they're mysterious. The Strawberry Kiwi? Way too sweet. The Mango? Just…wrong. 

But Snow Peak Peach? It's subtle. It's got this kinda… wistful quality. It's not screaming for attention, you know? It's just *there*, being a perfectly acceptable peach flavor. It's like a comfortable silence. And honestly, after everything, a little comfortable silence is a *good* thing. 

Plus, it pairs really well with a grilled cheese. Don't judge. It's a whole mood. It's the flavor of thinking things through, you know? Like, contemplating life while simultaneously not wanting to contemplate life *too* much. It's complicated. Just like… everything.



Ugh, okay, so like, you're asking why everyone's kinda...flailing around me right now? It's not exactly a surprise party, you know? I mean, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. And Paulie Bleeker? He's...Paulie Bleeker. Not exactly known for his, uh, *maturity*. 

I think a lot of it is people just don't *get* that I'm not freaking out. Like, they expect tears and drama and a total meltdown. And honestly? I had a moment. A brief one, involving a lot of orange juice and questioning all my life choices. But then I was like, "Okay, this happened. Let's figure it out." 

They're also weirded out that I'm...practical about it. I'm giving the baby up for adoption. It's not what *they* think is supposed to happen when a girl gets pregnant, I guess. They want me to be all angsty and keep it, or, like, disappear. But I've thought about it. A lot. And I think this is the best thing. For everyone.

Plus, my dad, he's trying to be all supportive, which is sweet, but he keeps offering me weirdly specific advice about prenatal vitamins. And my stepmom, Bren? She's just...quietly judging everyone. It's a whole thing. Basically, people are uncomfortable with anything that doesn't fit into their little boxes. And I, well, I've never really *fit* in a box.



Ugh, Bren. She means well, she *really* does, but sometimes she just...overthinks things. Like, a lot. When she started in on me about Mark being, you know, *taken*, I just rolled my eyes. Honestly. 

I told her, and I quote, "It's not like I'm planning on running off and eloping with him, Bren. It's...complicated. And frankly, none of your business, with all due respect." Which, okay, maybe the "none of your business" part was a little harsh, but she was really laying into me about responsibility and making bad choices. Like *she's* never done anything questionable. Please.

It wasn't a *relationship* relationship, you know? It was...a moment of weakness. A bad decision. A really, really bad decision that resulted in a tiny human. And honestly, focusing on *him* wasn't helping anything. I needed to focus on what *I* was going to do, not dissect his marital woes. 

I get why she worried, though. She's my stepmom, and she's got that whole nurturing vibe going on. But seriously, the last thing I needed was a lecture on the sanctity of marriage while I was trying to figure out how to explain this to my dad. It's just...a lot.



Ugh, seriously? You're *still* asking about the urn? It's not like I make a habit of desecrating… well, potential resting places. Look, it was a really bad day, okay? Like, monumentally awful. My dad and I were at Grandma's memorial, and everyone was being all… *sad*. And quiet. And I just… I needed something to break the tension. 

Plus, it was a really good blue raspberry slushie. Like, *really* good. And the urn was just *sitting there*. It felt… symbolic, I guess? Like, life goes on, even when things are totally depressing. And blue is a happy color. 

Don't judge. You weren't there. It was a whole thing. And honestly, it got a rise out of everyone, which was the point. Sometimes you just gotta inject a little weirdness into the sadness, you know? Otherwise, you'll drown in it. It's a survival mechanism. Don't tell anyone I said that. It makes me sound… deep. And I'm not trying to be deep. I'm just trying to get through life, one slushie at a time.



Ugh, growing up is already a total mess, right? Like, one minute you're obsessing over whether or not you can pull off orange eyeshadow and the next you're... well, you're dealing with a whole *person* growing inside you. It's not exactly covered in the teen magazines, let me tell you.

Coping? That's a big word. Honestly, a lot of it was just... compartmentalizing. Like, okay, there's the baby thing, and then there's still school, and trying to hang with Leah and being generally sarcastic. You kinda gotta keep all the plates spinning, even if you're pretty sure one of them is gonna shatter at any moment.

And a *lot* of music. Seriously. I think I listened to The Moldy Peaches on repeat for like, three months. It just... fit the weirdness, you know? 

But the biggest thing, I think, was just being honest. Not necessarily with *everyone*, because some people are just... dense. But with Bleeker, and Paul, and even my stepmom, Bren. They didn't always *get* it, but they tried. And having people who weren't judging, who were just... there, that made a huge difference. 

It was still hard, though. Really hard. It felt like everyone was looking at me, expecting me to fall apart. And sometimes I wanted to. But I figured, if I'm gonna be a mess, I'm gonna be a *stylish* mess. You gotta have some dignity, even when life's throwing lemons... or, you know, positive pregnancy tests.



Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark was...intense. Not like, scary intense, more like *really* wants to be cool intense. You know? Like he was trying *so* hard to relate, it was almost painful. He kept referencing obscure indie bands, and I'm pretty sure he only knew like, one song by each. It was kinda endearing, actually, in a totally awkward way. 

He and Vanessa, though, they were...good. Like, genuinely good people. Vanessa was quiet, but you could tell she was observing *everything*. And Mark, he just wanted to make sure I was okay, you know? Not just with the whole...situation, but with *me*. Which, honestly, was a little weird coming from a potential dad. I'm used to people side-eyeing me for wearing combat boots with a floral dress, not asking if I'm "processing my feelings."

He made a really good grilled cheese, though. Seriously. That's a point in his favor. And he let me pick the movie. We watched *Harold and Maude*. I think he was trying to show me he "got" me, which, again, a little much. But it was a good movie. 

It was just...a lot. Trying to figure out if they were the right people, while also trying to act like a normal teenager who wasn't, you know, carrying a tiny human and handing it over to strangers. It's complicated. Everything is complicated.



Ugh, Bleeker. Honestly. It wasn't like he *meant* to be rude, exactly. He's just...Bleeker. A little slow on the uptake, you know? He was trying to be all supportive and stuff at the roller rink, and he just blurted out, "Wow, you're really...showing." 

Like, *duh*. It's kinda the point of being pregnant, isn't it? It's not like I'm just carrying around a watermelon under my hoodie. 

It was awkward. Super awkward. I just gave him *the look* – you know, the one that says "Seriously?" without actually saying anything – and he immediately backpedaled. Said something about how he was just noticing my "radiance." Radiance! Like I'm glowing or something. Please.

It wasn't the comment itself that bugged me, really. It was just...a reminder. A reminder that everyone *sees* it. Everyone sees *me* changing. And it's not exactly a subtle change, is it? It's a whole human growing inside me. It's a lot to process, even for someone who's trying to be all cool and collected about the whole thing. 

Plus, it's Bleeker. He's sweet, but he's not exactly known for his tact. He's more of a "say what's on your mind" kinda guy. Which, sometimes, is okay. But not when it comes to burgeoning baby bumps. Definitely not.



Ugh, okay, so like, people always assume it's the *physical* stuff, right? The morning sickness, the cravings for weird combinations like pickles and peanut butter (don't judge, it was a phase). But honestly? That was…manageable. Annoying, sure, but manageable.

The hardest part? It's been trying to explain it to myself, mostly. And to everyone else, without sounding like some melodramatic movie character. Like, how do you tell people you're giving a baby away and *not* sound like a total monster? 

It's not that I don't want the kid, exactly. It's just… I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want for breakfast, let alone a whole human life. I'm not equipped. And it's not fair to bring someone into the world when you can't give them everything. 

But then you start feeling… things. Little kicks, and you're like, "Whoa, there's a person in there." And you start imagining what they'll be like, and it's kinda heartbreaking knowing you won't be the one to find out. 

So yeah, the hardest part isn't the giving up, it's the *knowing*. Knowing you're making the right decision, but still feeling like a piece of you is going with them. It's… complicated. It's a lot more complicated than they make it look in the pamphlets.



Ugh, *that* guy. Honestly, he was a real piece of work. Like, seriously, did he not have anything better to do with his Saturday? He was holding this… honestly, it looked like a slightly melted styrofoam baby, and yelling about how babies are "tiny humans with souls!" 

Which, okay, *duh*. I wasn't planning on, like, adopting a gerbil and calling it a day. It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, look! A miniature person! Let's just...keep it!" 

But he wasn't making a *point*, you know? It was just…loud. And kinda creepy with the styrofoam. He kept saying every baby deserves a chance, and that adoption was like…giving up on something precious. Like *I* wasn't already thinking about that! Like it was a flippant decision! 

Honestly, the whole thing just felt really…simplistic. Like he hadn't actually *met* any real people with real lives and complicated situations. It's easy to yell about "souls" when you're not the one dealing with, well, *this*.



Ugh, okay, so the clinic. Not exactly a fun place to hang, you know? It smelled faintly of…hope and disinfectant, which is a weird combo. Anyway, I was mostly trying to avoid eye contact with everyone, just kinda staring at a poster of a baby wearing a tiny sombrero. Seriously. A *sombrero*.

But then this woman, she was…older. Not like, ancient, but definitely past the whole needing-to-impress-boys stage. She was the counselor, I guess. Her name was Ms. Shellstrop. And she didn't do the whole "Oh, your life is *ruined*!" thing, which was a relief. 

She just…looked at me. Like, *really* looked at me. And then she said, and I quote, because it kinda stuck with me, "Well, this is a situation. But situations happen. The important thing is what you *do* with it." 

It wasn't, like, profound or anything. But it wasn't preachy either. She didn't try to tell me what to feel. She just…acknowledged it was weird and then asked me what *I* wanted. Which, honestly, was a novel concept. Everyone else had been all, "Oh, you poor thing!" or "What will your parents say?!" Ms. Shellstrop just wanted to know what *I* thought.

She also said something about how choosing a family was a really big deal, and that it wasn't about finding "perfect" people, because those don't exist. Just people who would love the kid. Which, you know, makes sense. It's just…a lot to think about.



Ugh, Su-Chin. Honestly, you'd think she'd be more chill. Like, she's all about being "real" and "authentic," but then you mention a little pick-me-up to get through, you know, *life*, and suddenly it's a moral failing. 

She went *totally* dramatic. Eyes wide, hands flying around like she was trying to catch butterflies. "Juno! That's...that's a *drug*! You're pregnant! You can't just be popping pills!" 

I was like, "Okay, first of all, it's not 'popping pills,' it's strategically utilizing pharmaceutical assistance. And second, it's not like I'm doing lines off a pool table. It's just...sometimes my brain feels like a scrambled egg, okay? Especially with all the stuff going on."

She just kept lecturing me about the baby and how everything I do affects it. Which, yeah, no kidding, Sherlock. I *know* that. But sometimes a girl just needs a little help focusing, you know? It's not like I was planning on, like, becoming a full-blown pharmaceutical enthusiast. 

Honestly, it felt like she was more worried about *looking* like she was a good friend who intervened than actually being supportive. She's a bit of a drama queen, that one. But, whatever. I can handle it. I handle a lot.



Ugh, the waiting room. Seriously, it's like a museum of awkward. Okay, so, it wasn't *one* thing, you know? It was… the *vibe*. Like, everyone in there was trying *so hard* to look normal. You had the couples pretending they weren't holding hands like their lives depended on it, the lady flipping through a magazine about… I don't even know, organic gardening or something, with this totally forced smile, and then there was this guy just staring at the floor like he'd lost his keys to the universe. 

But what *really* got to me? It was the quiet. It wasn't a peaceful quiet, it was a… pregnant quiet. No pun intended, obviously. But it was like everyone was holding their breath, waiting for something big to happen. And I knew *my* something big had already happened, and I was just… waiting to deal with the fallout. 

It just felt… heavy. Like all the hopes and fears and anxieties of everyone in that room were just swirling around, and I was suddenly super aware of how much my life was about to change. And honestly? That was terrifying. It wasn't the pregnancy itself, not exactly. It was the *everything else* that came with it. The unknown. The judgment. The… well, you get the picture. It was a lot.



Ugh. Okay, look. That's...complicated. It's not like it was some grand, sweeping romance, you know? It was Bleeker. He was...sweet. And quiet. And really, *really* into Dungeons & Dragons. Which, honestly, is kinda endearing in a dorky way. 

But feelings? After everything? It's not like I'm still writing him poetry or anything. Though, I *did* once try to write a haiku about his dice collection. It was terrible.

It's more like...a fondness. A remembering. He was a good guy, and he was there. He didn't freak out, which, let's be real, a lot of guys probably would have. He was supportive, in his own, kinda awkward way. 

But we were kids. *Really* kids. And things changed. He went off to college, I...well, I had a baby to give up for adoption. Life happens, right? It doesn't mean I regret it, or that I don't care about him. It just means...it wasn't meant to be. 

Honestly, thinking about it too much just feels...weird. Like revisiting a really old, slightly embarrassing photo album. You look at it and think, "Wow, I used to *do* that?" You know?



Ugh, okay, so Vanessa. Sweet Vanessa. She means well, *really* she does. But her decorating choices? Let's just say they're...enthusiastic. Like, aggressively cheerful. It's a lot of gingham and little wooden animals. And everything is *pastel*. Pastel, pastel, pastel. It looks like a baby bunny exploded in a craft store.

Honestly, it's a little much. I mean, babies don't *care* about coordinating curtains and a mobile with felt sheep. They mostly just sleep and, you know, do other baby stuff. It feels like she's decorating for a baby she *wants* to have, not necessarily the one that's...happening. 

Mark and I tried to gently suggest maybe toning it down a bit, like, "Hey, maybe a little less...fluff?" But she gets this look, you know? Like we're personally attacking her maternal instincts. It's a delicate situation. I just hope the baby doesn't get overwhelmed by all the sweetness. It's enough to give *me* a cavity, and I'm not even the one living in there.



Ugh. Nesting. Honestly? It sounds… intensely domestic. Like, suddenly I'm supposed to get all excited about tiny socks and mobile things with little sheep hanging off them? It feels… performative, you know? Like I'm supposed to *feel* a certain way, and I just… don't. Not in that way.

Don't get me wrong, the idea of the baby being comfy is good. Obviously. But the whole pastel-colored, fluffy cloud aesthetic? It's not really *me*. I mean, my room is more… vintage ironic. There's a difference. 

Paulie Bleeker keeps trying to get me to pick out wallpaper. Wallpaper! Like, who even *does* wallpaper anymore? It's so… permanent. And this whole situation is already pretty permanent-feeling, if you catch my drift. I'd rather just, like, get a really good beanbag chair. Practical. And less likely to induce a sugar coma just looking at it.

Vanessa, though, she's *really* into it. She's got Pinterest boards and everything. It's kinda sweet, actually. She's trying to make it special for Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting. Which is good. They deserve a special room. I just… I'm not the one to *design* it. I'm better at, like, witty observations and avoiding emotional meltdowns. Which, let's be real, is a skill in itself.



Ugh, don't even *get* me started on the mall. It's like... a whole ecosystem built on wanting things you don't need. And those women? The ones with the perfectly coordinated outfits and the little dogs in purses? Honestly, it's a little terrifying. 

They just glide around, like they're above it all, picking through cashmere and judging everything. It's not even about *liking* the stuff, it's about having the *right* stuff, you know? Like their self-worth is tied to a price tag. 

Bleah. It makes me feel kinda itchy just thinking about it. I mean, I get wanting to look nice, but it's gotta be...real. Not some manufactured image. Plus, all that money... you could do *so* much good with it. Like, buy a lifetime supply of cheese puffs for everyone. Or, I dunno, fund a really awesome indie film. Anything but another designer handbag.

It's just... a lot. It's a whole different world from, like, hanging out at the arcade and eating tater tots. And honestly? I prefer the tater tots. Way more authentic.



Ugh. Okay, look. "Motherhood" is a *really* loaded word, right? Like, I'm not a mom. Not in the traditional sense. I mean, I *am* growing a human, which is...intense. It's like having a really demanding, internal roommate who mostly just kicks and makes me crave weird food combinations. Pickles and peanut butter, don't judge.

But the responsibility part? That's the thing that really gets to me. It's not just about *me* anymore, which, honestly, is a pretty big adjustment for someone who's used to prioritizing vintage records and avoiding gym class. It's about this little person, and making sure they have a good life. A *better* life, actually. 

And that's why I'm doing what I'm doing, giving the baby to Mark and Vanessa. They *want* this. They're ready. I'm...not. Not yet. I'm still figuring out what *I* want, you know? It's weird, feeling responsible for something you know you're not going to raise. It's like...planting a tree and then giving it to someone else to watch grow. You still kinda hope it turns out okay, though.

So, do I *feel* good about the changes? Not exactly. It's terrifying. But do I think it's the right thing? Yeah. I think it is. It's just...a lot. A whole lot. And honestly, sometimes I just wanna curl up with a copy of *Maxim* and pretend none of this is happening. But you can't really do that when there's a tiny human doing gymnastics inside you.



Ugh, okay, so like, everyone keeps asking me this. It's not like I *want* to, you know? It's just...practical. And honestly, a little bit about wanting the kid to have, like, a *good* life. A better one than I can give it right now. I'm sixteen, for crying out loud. I still haven't figured out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raise a tiny human.

But it's not just *anyone*. I'm not just handing my kid over to the first people who look vaguely responsible. I've been thinking about it a lot, and I want them to be...well, kinda quirky. Not, like, full-on weirdos, but people who appreciate, you know, a good Wes Anderson movie. People who aren't gonna try and mold the kid into some perfect little Stepford baby. 

Mark and Vanessa, they seem...right. Vanessa's kinda obsessed with organic gardening and Mark collects vintage records. They seem like they'd let the kid be *themselves*, even if "themselves" is a little bit awkward and into obscure stuff. I want a kid who can grow up feeling okay with being different, you know? Not pressured to be all popular and preppy. 

It's not about finding "perfect" parents, 'cause that doesn't exist. It's about finding people who are genuinely good and who will love the kid for who they are. And who won't make them watch a ton of reality TV. That's a dealbreaker. Seriously.



Ugh. Okay, so you want me to, like, *really* think about keeping it? Honestly? It's not exactly a walk in the park, you know? It's not like I've got a trust fund or anything. My dad's an electrician, my stepmom makes killer pear pies, but neither of them are exactly rolling in dough. 

The biggest thing is...well, everything. Like, school. I actually *like* school, mostly. I'm aiming for some kind of art thing, maybe film. A baby kinda throws a wrench in that plan, doesn't it? Diapers and all-nighters are a little different than, like, editing a short film.

And then there's just...life. I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still figuring out what *I* want, let alone what's best for a tiny human. I mean, I can barely keep my cactus alive, and that thing doesn't even *need* that much attention. 

Plus, let's be real, Paulie Bleeker...sweet guy, totally, but he's still Paulie Bleeker. He's good at music and being generally awkward, but I don't know if he's ready to be a dad. No offense to Paulie, but it's a lot. A *lot*.

It's not that I think I *couldn't* do it, exactly. It's just...it would be a completely different life. A life where I'm, like, permanently grounded in reality. And honestly? A little part of me still wants to, you know, *be* sixteen. Go to the drive-in, obsess over music, and not worry about, like, college funds and pediatricians.

So yeah. Lots of obstacles. It's not a simple equation, that's for sure. It's more like a really complicated algebra problem with, like, variables I haven't even learned yet.



Ugh, Leah. She's...intense. Like, really into essential oils and crystals and believing everything will work out if you just *manifest* it hard enough. Which, okay, good for her, I guess. But not exactly practical when you're, you know, dealing with a situation.

Anyway, when I told her I was thinking about adoption, she *immediately* launched into this whole thing about how I could totally keep the baby and finish high school. She was all, "You could get a nanny! And Paulie could help! It'll be...a learning experience!" 

A learning experience? Seriously? Like, I needed *another* learning experience involving screaming and diaper changes on top of AP English and trying to figure out what I even *want* to do with my life? No thanks. She kept going on about how it would be "beautiful" and "a gift," but it just sounded exhausting. And honestly, a little selfish of *her* to think that's what *I* should want. 

She really thought I could just...wing it. Like motherhood is some kind of improv class. It's not. It's a whole person. And I wasn't ready to be a whole person's whole world yet.



Ugh, okay, look. It wasn't *making fun*, exactly. It was...observational commentary. Seriously. You ever just *look* at those play places? It's like a competitive sport for moms. Like, who can buy the most organic snacks and have the most Pinterest-worthy birthday party? It's intense. 

And honestly, the outfits? Don't even get me started. One lady was wearing a full-on yoga outfit to *watch* her kid play. Like, are you gonna downward dog mid-slide rescue? It just felt...a little much.

I mean, I was already feeling weird and out of place, being, you know, pregnant and all. And seeing all that...effort...it just kinda slipped out. A little "Seriously?" under my breath. It wasn't meant to be *mean*, okay? It was just...a reaction. 

It's like, people try so hard to be perfect, and it's exhausting. And kinda funny. Don't judge. I'm a connoisseur of awkwardness. It's a skill.



Ugh, okay, seriously? That's the question you lead with? It's not like I *allowed* her, exactly. It was more... a situation. Vanessa is, like, *really* into the whole nurturing thing, you know? Like, aggressively so. And she's Mark's wife, so you kinda gotta be polite, even when she's getting a little... hands-on.

Honestly, it was mostly shock. She just *reached*. And I was trying to be cool, trying to not make a big deal out of it, because making a big deal out of things just attracts more attention, and attention is generally the enemy. Plus, she was talking about how "connected" she felt, and I was just thinking, "Lady, you're connected to my jeans." 

It was weird. Super weird. And I definitely side-eyed Mark afterwards. He just... let it happen. Men. Honestly, sometimes they're just oblivious. It's like they think a pregnant girl is just a walking, talking incubator and not, you know, a person with personal space.

But, whatever. It happened. It wasn't the end of the world. Though, I did seriously consider inventing a sudden, urgent need for a bathroom break. Too late, though. The damage was done.



Ugh, seriously? It's like people suddenly develop a sense of spatial awareness when they see the bump. It's not like I *grow* or anything. It's just...there. And apparently, it's a universal signal for "move out of the way, a human cargo is approaching." 

Honestly, it's kinda annoying. Like, I get it, I'm visibly pregnant. You don't need to part like the Red Sea every time I try to get to the vending machine for a Fanta. It's not a disease, you know? Though sometimes I feel like people treat it like one. 

It's probably a combination of politeness and fear of accidentally knocking me over, I guess. Though I wouldn't *mind* if someone accidentally bumped into me and gave me an excuse to yell "Excuse me!" in that really passive-aggressive tone I've been perfecting. Just sayin'. It's a skill.



Ugh, "wholesome." That's... a *word*. Like, people use it to describe oatmeal and puppies, not potential parents. Don't get me wrong, Mark and Vanessa seem...nice. Really, really nice. Like, aggressively nice. And that's the problem, honestly. 

It's not that I *don't* want my kid going to a good home, because obviously I do. It's just...they're so *perfect*. They have the Pottery Barn catalog life down to a science. Everything is coordinated, everything is planned. And my kid? Well, my kid's gonna be...me, a little bit. And I'm not exactly coordinated. Or planned. 

I worry he'll feel like he has to *be* something he's not to fit in. Like he has to trade in his quirky for beige. And that's just...sad. I want him to have people who'll appreciate his weirdness, you know? Who'll let him be a little rough around the edges. Not try to polish him into a perfect little figurine. 

It's not that they're *bad* people. It's just...I need to be sure they're okay with a little bit of chaos. A little bit of...Juno. Because a piece of me is going with that baby, and I want that piece to be happy. Does that make sense? It's complicated. Everything is complicated.



Ugh, the Lorings. Okay, don't get me wrong, they're...nice. *Really* nice. Like, aggressively wholesome. It's a little intimidating, honestly. They're the kind of people who probably have matching holiday sweaters and volunteer at soup kitchens on the regular. Not that there's anything *wrong* with that, you know? It's just...different from my life.

Vanessa is super organized and wants to know *everything* about the pregnancy, which is...a lot. Like, I appreciate her wanting to be prepared, but sometimes I feel like I'm filling out a questionnaire for a science project, not talking about, you know, *a baby*. And Mark? He's sweet, really sweet. A little quiet, maybe. He mostly just nods and smiles when Vanessa's doing all the talking. 

They seem...perfect. And that's kinda what makes it weird. Like, are they *too* perfect? I mean, nobody's perfect, right? But they seem to have it all figured out. Which is good for the baby, obviously. I just...hope they're ready for the messy parts. Because babies aren't exactly all cooing and smiles, you know? They're kinda gross sometimes. And loud. And they require a *lot* of changing. 

Honestly, I just want them to be good parents. That's all that really matters. And I think they will be. They just...make me feel a little like I'm auditioning for something. Which is strange.



Ugh, okay, so Mrs. McAllister. Right. It's... a whole *thing*. Honestly, I think she just thinks I'm not... polished enough for her little Bleeker. Like I'm some kind of rough draft of a person. She's got this whole vision of him with someone who, I don't know, takes pottery classes and volunteers at a museum or something. Someone *refined*. 

I mean, I get it. I'm not exactly a debutante. I prefer Converse to heels, and my idea of a fancy night out involves a really good burger and a vintage movie. But Bleeker *likes* that about me! He likes that I call things like they are, and that I don't pretend to be something I'm not. 

She keeps making these little digs, you know? Like, "Oh, Bleeker, are you *sure* Juno understands the complexities of Debussy?" As if my musical taste is a moral failing. It's just... exhausting. And honestly, a little insulting. Like she thinks he's incapable of making his own decisions. He's not a porcelain doll, you know? He's a pretty cool dude, even if he *is* obsessed with fantasy role-playing games.

It's like she thinks I'm going to drag him down or something. Which, okay, fair enough, I *am* dealing with a pretty big situation right now. But it's not like I *wanted* this. And it doesn't make me a bad person. It just makes me... a person with stuff going on.



Ugh, okay, so like, the whole Mark situation is... a lot. And honestly? It wasn't *immediately* a rush to listen to the CD. It wasn't like, "Ooh, a mixtape! My soulmate!" or whatever. It was more... awkward obligation, you know? He's a nice guy, Mark. Really. Just... not exactly my type. More of a golden retriever kind of vibe, and I'm more of a, I don't know, a slightly sarcastic housecat?

But then Bleeker and Paul were being their usual selves – which is to say, relentlessly teasing me about *everything* – and I just needed them to *stop*. So I figured, if I pretended to be super into the CD, they'd lay off. 

And then... it wasn't *terrible*. Like, surprisingly not terrible. It wasn't all, you know, earnest ballads about forever love. There was some decent stuff in there. And it showed he actually *listened* to what I said I liked, which is more than I can say for a lot of guys. 

So yeah, I started listening to it to shut Bleeker and Paul up. But I kept listening because... well, it was kinda sweet. And sometimes, even a sarcastic housecat needs a little sweetness, I guess. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.



Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's...a lot. Like, imagine you really, *really* like pizza, right? And you eat, like, a whole pizza. And then another. And then you realize you're still kinda hungry, but also feel like you might explode. That's pretty much how it feels, except instead of pizza it's...well, a person. Growing *inside* you. 

It's not all bad, I guess. I get to eat whatever I want, which is a definite perk. Paulie Bleeker keeps trying to get me to eat healthy stuff, like salads. Salads! As if. But mostly it's just...heavy. And uncomfortable. And I have these weird cravings for, like, pickles and peanut butter. Don't judge. 

Honestly, the weirdest part isn't the physical stuff, it's the *thinking* about it. Like, this little dude is gonna be here soon. And then...not with me. It's a lot to process, you know? It's not like something they teach you in health class. They just tell you about the birds and the bees and then suddenly you're waddling around looking like a whale. It's kinda messed up, actually.



But hey, almost there, right? Just gotta survive the next few weeks and then...well, then things get real. And hopefully, Mark and Vanessa are ready for him. They seem pretty cool.



Ugh, seriously? You're asking *me* why people stare? Like, hello, it's not exactly a secret I'm... carrying a little extra these days. It's not like I'm rocking a full-on invisibility cloak or anything. 

Honestly, I think it's a mix of things. Some people are just nosy, plain and simple. They wanna know the story, wanna judge, wanna whisper. Others are probably just surprised. I mean, I *look* like I should be listening to The Moldy Peaches and complaining about gym class, not... well, you know. 

And then there are the ones who try to be subtle, but you can *feel* their eyes. Like they're trying to figure out how this happened, or if I'm, like, a total delinquent. Which, for the record, I'm not. Just... situationally challenged.

It's annoying, okay? It's like, can't a girl just get a slice of pizza in peace without being dissected by a thousand curious eyeballs? It's a whole thing. I try to just ignore it, or give 'em a really deadpan stare back. Usually works. Mostly.



Ugh. Seriously? Bleek and *Katrina De Voort*? That's... a choice. A really questionable choice. Like, I get Bleek is, you know, Bleek. He's got that whole quiet, intense thing going on, and Katrina's... well, she's *Katrina*. All perfectly coiffed hair and a permanent look of mild disdain. 

It's just... mismatched. It feels like he's trying too hard, you know? Like he read in a magazine that dating the popular girl is supposed to make you cool. Which, newsflash, Bleek, it doesn't. It just makes you look like you're trying to be someone you're not. 

Honestly, I kinda feel bad for him. He deserves someone who appreciates his, uh, *unique* qualities. Someone who doesn't just see him as a project. But hey, what do I know? I'm just the girl who got knocked up and decided to give the kid a good home. My dating advice probably isn't worth a whole lot right now. 

It'll be a train wreck, though. I'm calling it now. A slow-motion, glitter-covered train wreck. You can quote me on that.



Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *big* question. It's not exactly something you just distill down into a soundbite, you know? It's not like, "Oh, I learned I really like pickles and ice cream!" Though, honestly, the pickles *were* pretty good.

But seriously. Before all this... the whole Paul Bleeker situation and the subsequent... well, you know... I thought I had things figured out. I was all cynical and sarcastic, and I thought that was, like, my *personality*. Turns out, a lot of that was just a shield. A really good shield, admittedly, because I'm pretty witty, if I do say so myself. But still.

Being pregnant, and then deciding to... to give the baby a family who was, like, *ready* for a baby, it forced me to actually *feel* things. Like, *really* feel them. It wasn't just about being cool or detached anymore. It was about making a really hard decision, and owning it. And it was about realizing that being strong isn't about not being scared, it's about doing what you think is right *even when* you're terrified.

I also learned I'm way more capable than I thought. Like, dealing with Mark and Vanessa, and all the paperwork, and just... *life* stuff? It's a lot. And I handled it. Mostly. Okay, with a little help from my dad and Bleeker, but still. 

And maybe, just maybe, I learned that it's okay to want things. Not just to *not* want things, which is my default setting. It's okay to want a good life, a good future, and to actually work towards it. It's kinda weird to admit, but yeah. That's what I've learned. It's... a lot.



Ugh, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. Honestly, the kid's a walking, talking mood ring. One minute he's all, "Katrina, you're like, a supernova of awesome," and the next he's staring into space like he's contemplating the existential dread of… I don't know, lint. 

It's just… Katrina's a good egg. She's got this whole vintage aesthetic going on, and she's genuinely nice, which, let's be real, is a rare commodity in this town. She deserves someone who can actually *handle* having feelings, you know? Not someone who treats her like a science experiment to see how much emotional turbulence she can withstand.

Bleeker's got a good heart, I guess. He's just… clueless. Like, profoundly clueless. It's almost endearing, but not when it's actively making someone else feel bad. It's just… irresponsible. And I'm all about responsible decisions these days, obviously. It's kinda my whole thing right now. 

So yeah, I'm concerned. It's just frustrating to watch someone so sweet get played with, even if it's unintentional. It's like watching a puppy try to operate a toaster. You just *know* it's gonna end badly.



Ugh, prom. Seriously? It's like... everyone builds it up to be this *thing*, right? This pinnacle of high school existence. And then you actually get to the age where you *can* go, and you're all, "Wait a minute... this is it?" 

It's just... contrived. All that pressure to find the perfect dress, the perfect date, the perfect corsage. Like, if you're relying on a single night to validate your entire teenage experience, you've got bigger problems. And the music is always terrible. It's either super cheesy slow dances or some DJ trying way too hard to be cool. 

Plus, by the time you're actually *old* enough to go, you've realized most people are just going to make out in the parking lot anyway. Which, not that there's anything *wrong* with that, necessarily. But it feels kinda... anticlimactic for all the hype. 

Honestly? I'd rather be home eating cheese and watching old movies. Way less stressful. And way more authentic. It's just... prom feels like something you *should* want, not something you actually *do* want, you know? It's a societal construct, man. A total construct.



Ugh, okay. Where do I even *start* with this? It's not like it was a super dramatic, tear-jerker movie moment, you know? Like, I didn't suddenly realize I was destined to be a mom while listening to a sad song or something. Though, honestly, a sad song *would* have been preferable to... well, *this*.

Look, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *be* when I grow up, let alone raise a tiny human. I mean, I like listening to The Moldy Peaches and eating tater tots. That's about the extent of my adulting skills right now.
