Paul, you know, the… father… he wasn't exactly stepping up to the plate. And my mom, she's amazing, but she already had me pretty young. I didn't want to put that on her again. It just... didn't feel right.

So, adoption felt like the least messed-up option. Like, giving the baby a chance at a really good life with people who *wanted* a kid and were, you know, *ready* for one. It wasn't about not wanting the baby, exactly. It was about wanting the baby to have everything I couldn't give it. 

It's complicated. It's not like flipping a switch. It's more like... a really long, awkward conversation with yourself, punctuated by a lot of staring at the ceiling and trying not to think about tiny socks. Does that make any sense? Probably not. It rarely does.



Ugh, Dad. He means well, I guess. It's just...the whole "getting ripped off" thing. Like, what does he even *mean* by that? Is he picturing Mark and Vanessa as some kind of baby-snatching villains? They seem pretty normal, you know? They like Scrabble and have a really nice house. It's not like they're gonna trade the baby for a used car or something. 

Honestly, it's more about him being weirdly protective, I think. He's always been a bit of a worrier. And I get it, this is a big deal. It's *my* big deal, but it affects him too. He just...processes things in a really dramatic way. He keeps talking about legal stuff and contracts and making sure everything's "above board." Like I was planning on just handing the baby over in a parking lot for twenty bucks. 

It's annoying, but also...kind of sweet? He's trying to be a dad, even if his methods are a little...intense. I just keep telling him I've done my research, I've talked to Vanessa and Mark, and I feel good about it. Hopefully, that'll chill him out. Though knowing my dad? Probably not. He'll probably have a whole binder of legal documents prepared by tomorrow.



Ugh, *that* comment. Honestly? It's so typical of Mac. He thinks everything is about moderation. Like, yeah, Dad, maybe I should only eat *half* a box of Nerds. Or listen to *one* Flaming Lips song. It's just... not how I operate, okay? 

He said it after... well, after the whole pregnancy thing came out. Like *I* deliberately went looking for trouble. As if getting knocked up was some kind of impulsive decision about, I don't know, the perfect amount of cheese to put on a grilled cheese. 

It's not about not knowing when to say when, it's about... experiencing things. And sometimes things happen *to* you, you know? You don't always get a say in when things start or stop. It's just... life. And he's always trying to put everything into neat little boxes. It's exhausting.

Plus, it's kinda rich coming from a guy who collects vintage horror movie posters. *That's* not knowing when to say when. Seriously, the basement is terrifying.



Ugh, the Lorings' place. Honestly? It's... a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's all perfectly manicured lawns and houses that look like they were designed by someone who's never actually *lived* in a house, you know? Everything's beige and symmetrical and screams "we have our lives completely together and also a lot of money." 

It's not that I'm, like, *against* people having nice things. It's just... it feels so…sterile. Like a movie set. And the gate? Seriously? It's not keeping out burglars, it's keeping out *reality*. It's like they're trying to build a little bubble where nothing messy or unpredictable can happen. 

Which, let's be real, is a pretty pathetic way to live. Life *is* messy. Life is unpredictable. And pretending otherwise just feels… fake. Plus, it makes you wonder what they're so afraid of. Probably kids with skateboards, honestly. Or people who don't iron their clothes. 

Mark and Vanessa are good people, don't get me wrong. But their world is... different. It's a good place for the baby, though. Safe. Stable. Which is, you know, the whole point. But I definitely wouldn't want to *live* there. Too much pressure to be… perfect. And I'm pretty much the opposite of perfect.



Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, first impressions? Polished. *Really* polished. Like, she looked like she stepped out of a Pottery Barn catalog, you know? Everything coordinated. Her house smelled faintly of lavender and ambition. It wasn't a *bad* smell, just...intense. 

Paul, her husband, seemed nice enough, kinda quiet. But Vanessa? She was...focused. Like she had a five-year plan for everything, including a baby she hadn't even *met* yet. Which, honestly, was a little intimidating. 

I mean, I'm not saying she wasn't nice to *me*, she was. Super polite, offered me sparkling water, asked about my favorite bands. But it felt...calculated. Like she was interviewing a potential baby-maker, not talking to a person. 

It wasn't that I expected her to be wearing sweatpants and eating Cheetos, but she just seemed...perfect. And perfect is kinda scary, you know? It makes you wonder what happens when things *aren't* perfect. Which, let's be real, they never are.



Ugh, Bleeker. Honestly? It was...weird. Like, not in a *bad* weird, necessarily, just...unexpected. He's kinda quiet, you know? Usually just kinda *there*, strumming his guitar and looking intensely at things. So when he just...reached for my backpack, the one with all the textbooks and, you know, *stuff*, it was a total head-scratcher. 

It wasn't even like it was a super thoughtful gesture, exactly. It was more like he saw a problem – a girl struggling with a ridiculously heavy backpack – and his brain just went, "Solution: carry backpack." Which, okay, points for efficiency. 

But it also felt...significant, I guess. Like he was trying to *do* something, you know? Show he cared. And it was sweet, in a dorky, Bleeker-y kind of way. It made me realize he actually *notices* things. Which is more than I can say for some people. 

I just said, "Thanks," because what else are you gonna say? "Oh, wow, Bleeker, you're finally acknowledging my existence with physical labor?" That would've been awkward. Plus, my back *was* killing me. So, yeah. It was a whole thing. A small thing, but a thing nonetheless.



Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about *that*? Seriously? It's kinda personal, but fine. It wasn't like a magical transformation or anything, don't get me wrong. I was still me, still rocking the… generously proportioned physique, you know? 

But Yuki, she just... *did* stuff. Like, she didn't apologize for existing, or for being into things. She just *was*. And she was really into being a mom, and drawing comics, and just generally being a person. And it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, either. It felt...real.

See, before that, I felt like everyone was looking *at* me, not *seeing* me. Like I was just a walking stereotype, a "fat dork" as you so eloquently put it. But Yuki, she made me think maybe being different wasn't a bad thing. Maybe it just meant I had more stuff going on inside. 

It wasn't about wanting to be *exactly* like her, it was about realizing I could just...be. Be Juno. And that being Juno was okay, even if it meant liking weird music and eating a lot of cheese curls. It was a little spark, you know? A little permission slip to just...exist without feeling like I needed to shrink myself to fit in. 

It didn't fix everything, obviously. But it helped. A lot. And honestly? It was a comic book. Don't overthink it.



Ugh, Mark. Honestly. That kid lives in a world made of plastic and explosions. He's...enthusiastic, let's say. Anyway, he compared me to this superheroine in *The Try-Force* – some super obscure comic he's obsessed with – because she gets, like, super-powered *while* pregnant. 

Which, okay, is a *little* bit flattering, I guess. But mostly it's just…weird. Like, yeah, both of us are carrying around a little human, but I'm pretty sure my superpower is being able to deadpan my way through awkward situations. And maybe a knack for finding the perfect vintage record. Definitely not shooting lasers out of my eyes. 

He said something about both of us being "strong" and "capable." Which, I mean, I *am* capable. Capable of a lot. Eating a whole pizza by myself, for example. But strong? That feels...different. It's not about being able to lift a car, it's about doing what you gotta do, even when it totally sucks. And that superheroine, she's fighting villains. I'm fighting morning sickness and the existential dread of choosing the right parents for my kid. Different leagues, really.

He just wanted to make me feel better, I think. Mark's a good kid, just…a little dense. And really into comics.



Ugh, okay, so people are *always* asking me about the adoption thing. Like it's some kind of…social studies project. But fine, I'll bite.

Look, open adoption? It sounds…complicated. And honestly, a little stressful. Like, forever having to explain things? Dealing with…feelings? I already have enough of *those* swirling around, thank you very much. It's not that I don't think it's a good thing for *some* people, it just wasn't for *me*. 

I needed…clean breaks. You know? Like ripping off a band-aid. Fast. I figured the less contact, the easier it would be for everyone. For me to move on, for the baby to have a family without me constantly hovering, and for Mark and Vanessa to, like, actually *be* a family without me being a weird footnote. 

It's not that I don't care, obviously. I do. A lot. But caring from a distance felt…safer. Less messy. I needed to know I was doing something good, something responsible, and then…let it go. A closed adoption felt like the most responsible way to do that. It felt like giving them a real chance at a normal life, you know? Without Juno MacGuff popping up every birthday or something.

Plus, honestly? I'm not exactly known for my graceful social skills. I'm pretty good at sarcastic commentary, not…long-term emotional connections with people I've given babies to. It just felt like a recipe for disaster.



Does that make sense? It's not about not wanting to know, it's about wanting what's best, and for me, that meant letting go completely. It's…a lot. Don't even get me started on the paperwork. Seriously, the paperwork was a *nightmare*.



Ugh, okay, deep question right off the bat. Like, seriously? It's not like I *planned* on having a whole existential crisis at sixteen, you know? But, yeah, the whole… situation. The baby. It kinda forced me to, like, *look* at myself. Not in a mirror, checking for zit situations, but… *inside*.

Before, I was just… floating. A sarcastic observer. I liked my records, I liked hanging with Leah and Paulie, I was good at avoiding gym class. I was comfortable being the witty one, the one who could always crack a joke. It was a shield, I guess. Kept people from getting too close, and honestly, kept *me* from having to feel too much.

But then, boom. Positive pregnancy test. Suddenly, I wasn't just observing life anymore, I was *in* it. And it wasn't a cute indie movie anymore, it was… real. 

Finding Vanessa and Mark, that was huge. They weren't, like, pitying or preachy. They just… wanted a kid. And they were *good* people. That made me realize I could make a good decision, even a hard one, and it didn't mean I was a bad person. It meant I was thinking about what was best for everyone. 

And honestly? Dealing with Bleeker. That dork. He was… surprisingly okay. He didn't run, he didn't judge. He just… listened. And wrote songs. Really bad songs, but still. He showed me that being vulnerable isn't the same as being weak. 

So, yeah, it was messy. It was awkward. It was a whole lot of feeling things I didn't want to feel. But it made me realize I'm not just some sarcastic kid who likes Phoebe Buffay. I'm… capable. I can handle stuff. I can make tough choices. And I can figure out who I am, even if it takes a while. It's still a work in progress, obviously. I'm still sixteen. But I'm a little less floaty now, and a little more… me.



Ugh, prom. Don't even *get* me started. It was...an experience. Mark, bless his heart, he was really trying. He'd been practicing his slow dancing in his basement for, like, weeks. It was kinda sweet, actually.

Anyway, the song. It wasn't some super romantic ballad, which was good, 'cause that would've been *way* too much. It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes. Connor, Bleeker's dad, suggested it. Said it was "ironic." Honestly, I think he just likes Bright Eyes. 

It was...nice. A little sappy, yeah, but nice. We mostly just kinda swayed and tried not to step on each other's feet. Mark's a tall drink of water, you know? Hard to navigate. Plus, I was, uh, carrying a little extra cargo at the time, so graceful wasn't exactly my middle name. 

It wasn't about the dancing, though, was it? It was about...well, it was about Mark trying to be a good guy, and me trying to pretend everything was normal. Which, let's be real, it definitely wasn't. But for a few minutes, with that song playing, it *felt* kinda normal. Does that make sense? Probably not. I'm not exactly known for my linear explanations.



Ugh, okay, seriously? People keep asking me about that. It's not like I *wanted* to play relationship counselor to a couple who were, like, actively failing at being a couple. But it wasn't really about *him* leaving *her*, you know? It was about the baby. 

See, Mark, he was...well, he was a good guy. A little clueless, maybe, obsessed with records and stuff, but genuinely good. And Vanessa, she was...intense. Like, really intense. But she *wanted* this baby. She was already picking out names and decorating a nursery and, honestly, she was gonna be a fantastic mom. A little overbearing, probably, but a fantastic mom nonetheless.

If Mark had just...bailed, the baby would've been raised by a single dad who, let's be real, probably wouldn't have known which end of a diaper bag to start with. And Vanessa would've been heartbroken, and probably a little resentful, and that's not a good environment for a kid. 

It wasn't about saving their marriage, okay? It was about giving the baby the best possible start. Two parents, a stable home, a mom who was already head-over-heels. It felt...right. Even if it was messy and complicated and involved a lot of awkward conversations. 

Plus, honestly? I figured if they could work through their stuff *for the baby*, maybe they'd work through it for themselves too. It wasn't my place to dictate their lives, just to make sure the little dude had a good one. It's a lot to process, I know. It's not exactly a rom-com, is it?



Ugh. Mark. Honestly? It was...predictable, I guess. Not *good*, predictable, just...yeah. Like, I wasn't expecting him to suddenly sprout a responsible adult appendage or anything. He's Mark. He likes fantasy role-playing and eating cheese puffs. Not exactly father-of-the-year material, you know?

It stung, though. Don't get me wrong, I wasn't picturing us building a picket fence and having 2.5 kids. But a little bit of, like, *something* would have been nice. A "Hey, this is scary, but we'll figure it out *together*," maybe? Instead, it was just a lot of stammering and looking at his shoes. 

It kinda solidified things, though. Like, okay, this is *my* thing. I'm doing this. And if he's gonna bail before the opening credits even roll, well, that's his problem. It just meant I needed to be extra sure about everything, you know? Finding the right people for the baby, making the right choices...all on me. Which is kinda terrifying, but also...empowering, in a weird way. 

It's just...people are weird. And sometimes, they don't rise to the occasion. You gotta accept that and move on. And maybe eat a really big slice of pie. That helps.



Ugh, okay, so like, Mark. Right. People always ask about Mark. It's not like I *actively* sought out a friendship with a guy who collects plastic dinosaurs and plays guitar like a wounded animal, you know? It just… happened. 

Honestly, at first it was mostly because he wasn't trying to, like, *get* with me. Which, after dealing with Paulie Bleeker and his whole earnest, puppy-dog-eyes thing, was a *huge* relief. Most guys my age just see a girl and immediately think… well, you know. Mark just saw someone who also thought the world was kinda ridiculous.

He's just… different. He's got this whole quiet intensity, and he doesn't care what anyone thinks. He's comfortable being a little bit of a freak, and I guess I kinda dig that. It's refreshing. Plus, his life *is* weird, but it's a good weird. Like, he's genuinely passionate about things, even if those things are vintage video games and obscure horror movies. 

And he *listens*. Not like, pretends to listen while checking you out, but actually listens. When I was… going through stuff, he didn't offer advice or try to fix things. He just… sat with me. Which, honestly, was way more helpful than anything anyone else said. 

So yeah, I liked being a part of his weird life because it was a safe space to be myself, even when "myself" was a total mess. And because, let's be real, it was way more interesting than hanging out with the popular kids. They're all so… beige.



Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark is... a work in progress, let's just say that. Honestly, figuring out what's *actually* going on in that head of his is like trying to decipher ancient hieroglyphics while riding a skateboard. 

At first? Pure panic. Like, full-blown, eyes-wide-and-sweaty panic. He kept saying stuff like, "This is...intense," which, yeah, no kidding, Sherlock. Intense is an understatement. He was mostly worried about, like, having to give up skateboarding and getting a *real* job. Which, okay, fair enough, I guess. But also...priorities, dude.

But then, after a while, it kinda shifted. He started trying to be...responsible? He started reading those "What to Expect When You're Expecting" books, which was hilarious because he kept getting confused about Braxton Hicks contractions. Seriously. He'd be like, "So, is that like...a practice labor?" 

I think deep down, he's scared. He's a good guy, Mark, just...immature. He wants to do the right thing, he really does. He just doesn't really *know* what the right thing is, you know? He's trying to be supportive, and he's definitely stepped up, but I think he's mostly just trying to look like he has it all together. It's a whole thing.



Ugh, seriously? We're *still* talking about the perfume? It's not like I planned a heist or anything. It was... a moment of weakness, okay? A really specific, hormonally-charged moment of weakness. 

See, I was at Loring's, right? And everything there just smelled *fancy*. Like, grown-up fancy. My life at that point was mostly smelling like Froot Loops and desperation. And this perfume... it was called "Seventeen." Seventeen! Like, it was practically *begging* me to feel sophisticated. 

Plus, Leah was going on and on about how important smelling good is for attracting Paulie Bleeker, and I just... I wanted to feel like maybe, just maybe, I could pull off being someone who *deserved* to be noticed. It was stupid. I knew it was stupid even *while* I was slipping it into my pocket. 

It wasn't about the perfume, really. It was about wanting something... more. Something that smelled like a life I didn't have yet. And honestly? It smelled pretty good. Don't judge. Everyone has their things.



Ugh, seriously? You're asking *me* about Mark and Vanessa's whole mess? It's... a lot. Like, a whole lot of beige and quiet desperation, if you ask me. And nobody *did* ask me, but here we are.

Okay, so, from what I gathered – and believe me, you pick up things when you're spending time at their house, trying to avoid eye contact with the antique furniture – it's not one big dramatic thing. It's more like a million tiny things that just... eroded everything. 

Mark, he's... a music guy, right? Really into vinyl and stuff. And Vanessa? She's all about appearances. Like, perfectly coordinated everything. I think he felt like she was trying to *curate* him, you know? Like he was a record in her collection, not a person. He wanted someone who'd actually *listen* to his music, not just admire the album cover.

And she, well, she wanted stability. A house, a perfect life, the whole nine yards. And Mark... he's just not built for "perfect." He's more of a "slightly off-kilter but genuine" kind of guy. 

It's sad, honestly. They just... grew apart. Like two songs on different albums. They used to fit, but then the track listing changed. It's kinda like when you realize your favorite band isn't as good as you thought they were. Disappointing, but you gotta move on, right? 

Don't tell them I said any of this, though. Seriously. Vanessa would probably try to redecorate *me*.



Ugh, seriously? You're still thinking about that? Okay, look. Vanessa is...intense. Like, a full-on emotional hurricane wrapped in a vintage dress. And she just *looks* at you with those big, concerned eyes and suddenly you feel like you need to explain the entire existential dread of being a teenager, *plus* the whole...situation. 

It wasn't that I didn't *want* to talk to her, exactly. It's just...sometimes you need to escape before you accidentally overshare and then everyone's walking on eggshells around you for the next six months. Plus, she was talking about feelings. And feelings are...sticky. Like, once you start poking at them, they just cling to everything. 

So, yeah, I bolted. It's a perfectly reasonable reaction, if you ask me. Sometimes a girl just needs a quiet moment with a can of Froot Loops and a really good record, you know? It's called self-preservation. Don't judge.



Ugh. Vanessa. She's...sweet, I guess. Like a golden retriever who genuinely thinks everyone is a good person. Which, you know, good for her. But Mark? Seriously? That guy's still figuring out how to operate a washing machine without shrinking all his band t-shirts, let alone a *baby*. 

Honestly, it's a little naive. Like, wanting something to be true doesn't *make* it true. She keeps saying he just needs time to "process," but processing usually involves, like, actually *doing* something other than playing guitar and brooding. He barely even looked at the ultrasound, remember? It was all, "Whoa, that's...intense." Intense? It's a tiny human growing inside someone!

Look, I get wanting a dad involved. It'd be nice. But you can't force someone to be ready for something they clearly aren't. It's just setting herself up for disappointment, and honestly, it's kinda unfair to the kid, too. A kid deserves a dad who *wants* to be there, not one who's being guilt-tripped into it. 

It's just...sometimes people don't grow up when you expect them to. And sometimes, you gotta accept that and move on. It's harsh, but it's real. And I've learned a thing or two about real lately.



Ugh, okay, this is a surprisingly deep question for a random chat, but alright. My favorite? Honestly, it's kinda all over the place, which probably reflects my brain. But if I *had* to pick... I'd say indie rock. 

Like, The Velvet Underground, Modest Mouse, stuff like that. It's not all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's got a little grit, a little weirdness, a little… *realness* to it. It doesn't try too hard to be something it's not. And honestly, after everything that's happened, I kinda appreciate music that doesn't pretend life is perfect. 

Plus, it's good for thinking. And I've been doing a *lot* of thinking lately. It's not like I'm gonna put on some bubblegum pop when I'm, you know, contemplating the future of a tiny human. That just feels… inappropriate.

So yeah, indie rock. It's just… *me*, I guess. Does that make sense? Don't look at me like that. It's just music.



Ugh, pilates. Honestly? It sounds…beige. Like, aggressively beige. All those controlled movements and breathing? I get enough of that just *existing*, you know? It feels like something people do when they've already figured everything out, which, let's be real, nobody ever does. 

Exercising in general…look, I'm not *against* it. I mean, I walk to school, which is exercise, right? And sometimes I have to, like, aggressively haul myself up the stairs when I'm late. That builds character. And probably some leg muscle. But deliberately going to a gym and *paying* someone to yell at me to do lunges? No thanks. 

I think I'd rather spend that time perfecting my sarcastic wit. It's a much more useful skill, honestly. Plus, it doesn't require spandex. Spandex is a crime against humanity. Don't even get me started.

It's not that I'm lazy, okay? It's just…priorities. And right now, my priorities involve finding the perfect vintage record and avoiding eye contact with anyone who asks about the baby. Pilates just doesn't fit into that equation.



Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, the guitar thing... it's complicated, right? Like *everything* with Mark is complicated. It started 'cause he was trying to be all... supportive. You know, after... the whole situation. And he's a pretty good guitar player, actually. Not like, Jimi Hendrix good, but good enough.

He started showing me chords, and it was... nice. Distracting, mostly. It was something to *do* besides obsess about, well, everything. And honestly? I'm kinda good at it. I pick things up fast. It's way more satisfying than, like, cheerleading or whatever all the other girls are into.

But it also... I don't know. It made things *feel* more than they were. Like, we were bonding over something cool, and it felt... intimate. Which is weird, because he's, like, a total dork, and I'm trying really hard not to fall for dorks. 

It definitely made me see him differently. Before, he was just... Paul's friend. The quiet one who liked fantasy stuff. But when we were playing, it was like he wasn't trying so hard to be cool, you know? He was just... Mark. And that was... surprisingly okay.

But it also made me realize he wanted more than just friendship. And that's where it got messy. Because I was trying to figure out my own stuff, and he was trying to figure out *me*, and it was just a whole lot of awkwardness wrapped in a six-string. It's like, can you even *have* a normal connection with someone when your life is already so... not normal?



Ugh, music. Okay, don't get me wrong, it's not like I'm *constantly* blasting tunes to drown out the existential dread or anything. That would be… dramatic. Though, honestly, sometimes it kinda is.

But seriously, it's a thing. Like, when everything feels super weird and confusing – which, let's be real, is pretty much *all the time* right now – music just… fits. It's a good distraction, for starters. Helps me not think about, you know, the whole growing-a-human situation for five minutes. 

But it's more than that. It's like, different songs feel like different parts of what's going on. When I was first finding out everything, it was a lot of The Velvet Underground. Kind of gloomy, but in a cool, ironic way. Like, "Yeah, my life is a mess, but at least I have good taste in music." 

Then there was a phase with a lot of upbeat stuff, trying to pretend everything was totally normal. Superchunk, mostly. Just loud and fast and… distracting. 

And now? Now it's kinda all over the place. Sometimes I need something sad, sometimes something angry, sometimes just something… neutral. It's like a soundtrack to the whole mess, you know? Helps me process stuff without actually *talking* about it, which, let's face it, is my preferred method of dealing with things. Talking is overrated.



It's kinda like… if life was a movie, music would be the score. And right now, the score is a little all over the place. A little bit indie, a little bit melancholy, and definitely a little bit awkward.



Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *that*? It's not like I planned a whole escape route with rope ladders and disguises, alright? It just...happened. 

Look, Vanessa and Mark, they're...intense. Like, really intense. And they were just *laying* it on thick with the whole "perfect family" vibe, you know? The Pottery Barn catalog come to life. And honestly? It was suffocating. They were already picking out names and decorating a nursery before I even had a chance to, like, *process* anything. 

It wasn't about them being bad people, okay? They just...wanted so much, so fast. And it felt like they were trying to mold me into something I wasn't. Like I was a lump of clay they could just shape into the perfect expectant mother for their perfect life. 

I needed air. I needed to just...*breathe*. So yeah, I bolted. I figured a little space was necessary. Plus, the whole thing was making me feel kinda panicky. It's hard to explain. It's like when you're watching a movie and you just *know* something bad is about to happen, and you want to yell at the screen to tell the characters to just *stop*? It was like that, but with baby furniture.

Honestly, running was probably a dumb move. But sometimes, dumb is all you got.



Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. It was… not a stellar moment, okay? Like, seriously, the soundtrack to my life was suddenly all violins and regret. It wasn't even, like, a *normal* sob, you know? It was a full-on, snotty, hiccuping, "my life is officially a Nancy Drew mystery gone wrong" kind of sob. 

It wasn't just about, like, being pregnant, though that was a pretty big part of it. It was about… everything. Paulie Bleeker looking all concerned and confused, my dad trying to be supportive but mostly just looking awkward, and realizing that my life was about to change in a way that was way bigger than choosing the right vintage dress. 

I think I was mostly just scared. Scared of messing everything up. Scared of disappointing everyone. And, honestly? Scared of what it all *meant*. Like, who *am* I now? I was just… Juno. A girl who liked records and avoiding gym class. And suddenly I was… a vessel? A future mom? It was a lot to process, okay? A *lot*.

And the worst part? I couldn't even blame anyone. It was just… me. Which is, like, a really humbling and also really annoying realization. So yeah, sobbing in the car. Not my finest hour. But hey, at least the upholstery was relatively stain-resistant. Silver linings, right?



Ugh, seriously? You *still* ask people about the Jiffy Lube receipt? It's, like, my whole thing, apparently. Okay, fine. I wrote "Super Duper Baby."

Look, it wasn't some deep, philosophical statement, alright? It just...came to me. Paulie Bleeker and I were at the pharmacy, getting a pregnancy test (awkward, obviously), and he was all, "What are you gonna write on the receipt?" 'Cause I always write something on receipts, it's a habit. And I was just...panicked. And the first thing that popped into my head was "Super Duper Baby." 

It sounded ironic, you know? Like, this whole situation is *anything* but super duper. It's kinda terrifying. But also...it felt a little hopeful? Like, maybe this baby *could* be something super duper for someone. For Vanessa and Mark. 

Honestly, it was mostly just a way to avoid actually *talking* about what was happening. Talking is hard. Writing silly things on receipts is easy. Don't read too much into it, okay? It's just a receipt.



Ugh, Vanessa. Honestly? It was... a lot. Like, a whole *scene*. You know, the kind you see in melodramatic movies, except way more awkward because it was happening in *real life*. 

When I slipped her that note about, well, *the situation*, I was bracing for... something. I figured she'd be mad, maybe yell a little. But the way she just...deflated? Like a punctured bouncy castle? It was kinda heartbreaking, actually. And then the tears started. It was a total waterworks situation.

I felt terrible, obviously. I mean, I didn't *want* to upset her, but someone had to say something. Paulie Bleeker wasn't exactly being forthcoming with information, and I figured she deserved to know before she found out from, like, a gossip blog or something. 

Mostly, though, I was just really uncomfortable. I'm not good with big displays of emotion. It makes me wanna hide under a pile of vintage records. It was like, "Okay, Vanessa, I get it, you're sad. Can we maybe process this without the dramatic sobbing?" 

It made me realize, though, that this wasn't just about me. It was about her, and Paulie, and their whole...thing. And that made it even more complicated. It's weird, you know? Being the one who kinda throws a wrench into everything.



Ugh, Vanessa. She means well, I guess, but sometimes she just...*needs* to know things. Like she's collecting data for a science project or something. When she asked me if I was *really* going ahead with the adoption, it felt… weirdly intrusive, you know? Like she thought I was gonna have a last-minute change of heart and suddenly decide to keep a baby I wasn't prepared for. 

It wasn't like I was waffling or anything. I'd already *thought* about it. A lot. Like, obsessively. It wasn't a spur-of-the-moment "Oh, a baby! How cute!" kinda situation. It was a really big decision, and I'd made it. 

So, I just kinda gave her *the look*. You know the one. The one that says, "Seriously? Are we still having this conversation?" And I told her, pretty bluntly, that yeah, I was. It was the right thing to do. For everyone. 

It's just...people assume it's sad, you know? Like I'm giving something *up*. But it felt more like...giving something *to*. Giving a baby a life with people who were ready for it. And honestly? That felt pretty powerful. It still does.



Ugh. Seriously? Vijay. That guy. He's like... aggressively helpful, you know? Like he *needs* to be the one solving everyone's problems, even when nobody asked him to. And bringing that up? At the roller rink, no less? Talk about a mood killer. 

It was... irritating. Beyond irritating. Like, I get it, Bleeker's kinda spacey and Vijay's his best friend and feels the need to manage his life, but to just *out* it like that? And then suggest it could be *Bleeker's*? Please. I know who the father is. It's Paulie Bleeker, alright? He's not exactly subtle. 

Honestly, it wasn't the accusation itself that bugged me so much as the sheer *audacity*. Like, who *is* this guy to question my life? And to question *Bleeker's*? It just felt... invasive. And kinda rude. 

I just gave him that look. You know the one. The "are you serious right now?" look. It usually works. Though, he did try to backpedal with something about being concerned. Yeah, concerned about stirring up drama, probably. 

It just reminded me that everyone has an opinion, and most of them are completely unwanted. It's like, can't people just mind their own beeswax? Especially when it involves, you know, *gestational stuff*. It's complicated enough without random dudes throwing theories around.



Ugh. Seriously? Vijay and his… *aspirations*. It was… a lot. Like, a whole *level* of trying too hard. He was all puffed up about being a dad, which, okay, good for him, right? He's stepping up. But the mustache? The whole "real man" thing? It felt… performative. Like he thought growing facial hair was gonna magically unlock some paternal instinct or something. 

Honestly, it just made me roll my eyes so hard I thought they might get stuck. I mean, being a dad isn't about looking the part, it's about *being* the part. It's about, you know, actually caring and being there. Not about looking like a slightly confused, overly-enthusiastic lumberjack.

I told him as much, of course. Something about how a mustache doesn't change the fact he still asks me to explain things from *Superbad*. He got a little huffy, but he eventually dropped it. Though I swear I saw him eyeing some beard oil at the drugstore later. Boys are weird. Just… really weird.



Ugh, *that* note. Honestly, it's kinda embarrassing even *thinking* about it now. Okay, so, Vanessa – my stepmom, she's...intense about healthy eating, let's just say that. And I was having a *moment*, you know? A serious craving. Like, a full-blown, can't-think-of-anything-else craving for a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. A *really* good one. 

So I left a note for her. It wasn't, like, a request. It was more of a...plea. A desperate, handwritten declaration of my need for PB&J. I think I even used the word "existential." It was something along the lines of, "Dear Vanessa, my very existence hinges on the immediate procurement of a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Seriously. Don't judge."

She did judge. *Hard*. And then she made me eat a pear. A pear! Like *that* was going to solve anything. Honestly, the whole thing was a tragedy. It's a good thing she found it before my dad did, he would've just laughed and made me one, which would've been worse in the long run, probably. It would've set a bad precedent.



Ugh, okay, so like, people staying together... it's a whole *thing*, right? It's not just about, "Oh, they love each other, therefore happily ever after." It's way more complicated than that. 

I was mostly worried about people staying together for the *wrong* reasons. Like, because they're scared to be alone, or because they think they *should*, or because everyone else expects them to. That's just... sad. And kinda pathetic, honestly. 

I saw it with my folks, you know? They stayed together for *us* kids, and it wasn't exactly a picnic. It was just... quiet. And strained. And I didn't want that for anyone. I figured if you gotta force it, it's probably not worth forcing. 

It's like, a good relationship should be something you *want*, not something you feel obligated to do. And it shouldn't be about completing someone else, it should be about two people who are already pretty okay on their own, choosing to share their lives. Does that make sense? It's kinda hard to explain without sounding all philosophical and stuff. I'm not usually that deep, I swear.



Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, existential crisis big. It's not like I'm *searching* for someone to love me, you know? I'm pretty good at being me, even if "me" is currently carrying a tiny human and trying to navigate the whole adoption thing.

But... if I had to name people who already *do* love me, for the weird, sarcastic, slightly-too-into-horror-movies version of myself? That'd be my dad, Mac. He's... a softie, really, even though he pretends to be all stoic and into landscaping. He just wants me to be happy, even when he doesn't *get* me. And he makes a mean grilled cheese, which is a pretty solid form of love, honestly.

Then there's Bren, my stepmom. She's... sparkly. Like, aggressively sparkly. But she's also really good at listening, and she doesn't judge me for, like, anything. She just accepts that I'm a bit of a mess and tries to help me sort it out. 

And Leah. Oh, Leah. She's my best friend. We've been through everything together, from bad haircuts to questionable boy choices. She's the one who tells me when I'm being a total idiot, which is, admittedly, pretty often. She loves me even when I'm being completely insufferable.

So yeah. I'm not exactly lacking in the love department. It's just... different kinds of love, you know? It's not all hearts and flowers and romantic comedies. It's more like... comfortable sweaters and shared silences and knowing looks. And that's good enough for me. For now, anyway.



Ugh, the ultrasound. Honestly, it's kinda weird seeing a little... blob in there. Like a tiny, silent movie star. But yeah, okay, the *plan*. Right.

So, after the ultrasound confirms it's, you know, actually happening and not just a really intense gas bubble, I'm giving the baby up for adoption. It's not like I'm not capable of having a kid, it's just... my life right now is not exactly set up for tiny humans. I'm still figuring *me* out, if you catch my drift. 

I've been talking to Mark and Vanessa Loring, this couple who are, like, super normal and really want a kid. They seem... good. Like, genuinely good people. They've got a house with a yard and everything. Way more stable than my situation, let's just say. 

It's not gonna be easy, obviously. It's kinda like... giving away a really cute, slightly-developing pet. Except it's a person. A whole person. But I think it's the right thing to do. For everyone. 

I'm trying not to get too attached, which is hard when you're staring at a little blob on a screen. But I'm focusing on finding them the perfect parents. That's my job now, I guess. It's... complicated. But mostly, it's just trying to be responsible, you know? Even if responsible feels really, really grown-up.



Ugh. People judging? Like that's *new*. Honestly, it's kinda expected, right? Like, everyone's got an opinion on everything, especially when it comes to stuff they don't understand. And let's be real, a sixteen-year-old getting pregnant isn't exactly a common Tuesday. 

It's mostly the looks, you know? The little head tilts and the pursed lips. Like I'm some kind of…failed experiment. Or irresponsible. Which, okay, maybe the getting pregnant part *was* a little irresponsible. But giving the baby up? That's the *responsible* part. It's about wanting something better for the kid than I can give right now. I'm still figuring out what *I* want for breakfast most days, let alone raising a human.

People think it's sad, I guess. Like I'm just…getting rid of something. But it's not like that. It's about finding the perfect people, Mark and Vanessa, who are actually *ready* and excited. They want this. I... I have other stuff I need to figure out. College, maybe. Or learning to play the bass properly. 

So yeah, the judging stings a little. But mostly, it just makes me roll my eyes and think, "Mind your own business, okay?" It's my life, my decision, and honestly, it's a lot more complicated than anyone who's just looking from the outside could ever know. It's not a tragedy, it's just...life. A weird, messy, kinda beautiful life.



Ugh, okay, so like, it's not that I *don't* trust Mark and Vanessa, okay? They seem...nice. Really nice, actually. Almost *too* nice, you know? Like they're trying too hard to be the perfect Stepford parents. Which, honestly, is kinda weird.

My biggest thing is, I just want them to be...real. Like, babies are messy. They scream. They throw up. They're not little accessories you can coordinate with your Pottery Barn living room. I worry they're picturing this perfect little cherub and aren't prepared for the actual, you know, *human* part of it. 

And Vanessa...she's really focused on the whole "organic, free-range" thing. Which is fine, I guess, if that's their vibe. But I don't want my kid to grow up thinking they're superior because they only ate kale chips and listened to classical music. A little junk food never hurt anyone. Seriously.

It's just...I want them to be good people, obviously. But good people who are also, like, *people*. Flawed and messy and able to handle a kid being a kid, not a project. Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. It's my baby, even if I'm not raising him, and I want him to be happy. And sometimes "happy" means a little bit of chaos.



Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about people having opinions? Like, seriously, everyone suddenly becomes a parenting expert the *second* you tell them you're... you know. And the ultrasound tech? Don't even *get* me started. She was all, "Are you *sure* about this?" with this look like I hadn't thought it through, like I just decided to get a latte on a whim. 

It's like, lady, I appreciate the tiny human picture, but my reproductive choices are not up for debate with someone who spends their day looking at blobs. Honestly.

I mostly just deflect. Sarcasm is my superpower, you know? If someone starts in on me about how "precious" this is and how I'm "throwing away a life," I usually hit 'em with something like, "Oh, I'm sorry, were *you* planning on raising it?" or "Yeah, well, I'm pretty sure a kid deserves parents who actually *want* a kid, not someone who's still figuring out what they want for *breakfast*."

It's not about being mean, exactly. It's about protecting myself. It's *my* decision. And it's a really hard one, okay? I don't need strangers piling on with their guilt trips. 

Paulie Bleeker – he's good at shutting people down too, in his own quiet way. He just gives them *the look*. You know, the one that says, "Don't mess with my girl." It's surprisingly effective.

But honestly? It's exhausting. Sometimes I just wanna yell, "Mind your own business!" But then I remember that most people are just...scared. Scared of things they don't understand. So I try to remember that, and just keep moving forward. It's my life, and I gotta own it, even when everyone else is trying to tell me how to live it.



Ugh. Okay, so, the ultrasound. Right. It wasn't... what I expected, you know? Like, in movies, people are *always* crying and all gooey-eyed. And don't get me wrong, it was... a lot. But it wasn't necessarily *happy* tears, if that makes sense. 

It was mostly just...weird. Like, there was this tiny little person, all blurry and grey, just *existing* inside me. And it was kinda freaky, honestly. It wasn't a baby *baby* yet, more like a little alien bean sprout. 

There was definitely a moment of, like, "Whoa. This is real." And a little bit of panic, if I'm being honest. Because suddenly it wasn't just a theoretical situation anymore. It was... a thing. A little thing that needed me, even if I wasn't gonna, like, *keep* needing to need it, you know? 

It was a lot to process. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, that's for sure. It was more like...grey clouds with a tiny, flickering lightbulb inside. And a whole lot of thinking about what the heck I was gonna do. It made the whole thing feel...permanent, even though I knew it wasn't supposed to be. Does that even make sense? It's hard to explain.



Ugh, seriously? You're *still* asking about the Tic Tacs? It's been, like, forever. Okay, fine. Look, Bleeker is...Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely a little bit of a dork. And he was being *so* relentlessly cheerful after...well, you know. After the whole situation. Like, aggressively optimistic. 

It was just...a lot. 

So, yeah, I filled his mailbox with Tic Tacs. A *lot* of Tic Tacs. It was a visual representation of how I felt. Like, a tiny, minty avalanche of awkwardness. Plus, he likes them. It was a passive-aggressive gesture of affection, okay? Don't judge. It's complicated. 

Honestly, it felt less weird than actually *talking* about my feelings. Sometimes you just gotta express yourself through excessive candy distribution. It's a valid coping mechanism, I think. Don't look at me like that. It made *sense* at the time.



Ugh. Okay, so, Bleeker. That's... a whole thing. It wasn't like a movie moment, you know? No grand declarations, no running through fields of wheat. More like... awkward silences punctuated by him staring at his shoes and me trying *really* hard not to roll my eyes.

Confessing, like, actually *saying* the words "I think I might have a thing for you" was the easy part. It was the *after* that was brutal. He got all flustered, which, okay, kinda cute at first. But then it just became... complicated. He was already kinda a sensitive soul, and suddenly having me, you know, *like* him, on top of everything else with the baby? It was too much for him to process, I think. 

He started trying to be... more. More attentive, more helpful. Which was nice, I guess, but it felt forced. Like he was trying to be the boyfriend he thought I wanted, instead of just being Paulie. And Paulie is... well, Paulie is Paulie. He's quiet, he likes music, he's good at taking pictures of stuff. I liked *that* Paulie. 

It wasn't that he didn't care, it's just... he wasn't equipped to handle all the emotional baggage. He's a sweet kid, honestly. Just... not a superhero. And I needed someone who could at least *pretend* to be a superhero for a little while, you know? 

We ended up just being friends again, which was probably for the best. It was weird for a bit, definitely. But we got back to just sharing headphones and talking about music. It was... comfortable. And honestly, after everything, comfortable was a *very* good thing.



Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the chalk? Seriously? It's not like I planned a whole elaborate performance art piece or anything. It was... a message. A *very* direct message.

Bleeker, you gotta understand, he's... well, he's Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, obsessed with records. And after *the thing* happened, and I found out I was pregnant, he just... froze. Like a deer in headlights, except the headlights were, like, the weight of responsibility. 

So, yeah, I wrote "GET A LIFE" on his stoop in chalk. It wasn't about being mean, exactly. It was about... shaking him up. He needed to *deal*. He needed to understand this wasn't just some abstract thing, it was *real*. And he needed to, like, grow a spine and maybe contribute to the conversation instead of just staring at me with those big, sad eyes.

It was also, admittedly, a little bit of me being a sarcastic jerk. I mean, what can I say? It's a coping mechanism. Plus, chalk washes away, right? It felt... less permanent than, like, spray painting it. Though honestly, a part of me *wanted* to spray paint it. But my dad would have killed me. And probably Bleeker's parents too. 

It was a messy situation, okay? And sometimes, messy situations call for messy, chalk-written declarations. Don't judge.



Ugh, Bleeker. Don't even get me *started*. It's not like he was, you know, *actively* helpful at first. More like... a really tall, quiet shadow. Like a really awkward, lanky tree. He mostly just... existed. And played guitar. A *lot* of guitar. 

But honestly? That was kinda the point. He didn't try to fix things, or tell me what to do, or get all dramatic. Paulie Bleeker just... *was*. He showed up. He brought me orange juice and those weird peanut butter crackers I like when I was feeling nauseous. He listened to me rant about everything – the adoption agency, Mark and Vanessa, even just how much I hated gym class. He didn't judge. Which, let me tell you, is a rare commodity in this town.

At first, I thought it was just pity. Like, "Oh, poor Juno, she messed up, let's be nice to her." But it wasn't. It was... genuine. He didn't want to be a hero, or a dad, or anything like that. He just wanted to be *there*. 

And that, surprisingly, was exactly what I needed. It wasn't about him solving my problems, it was about him letting me figure things out *with* someone who wasn't freaking out. It made me feel... less alone, I guess. Less like a total disaster. 

He's a good kid, Bleeker. A little dorky, sure. But good. And honestly, seeing him just... be himself, even when things were totally crazy, kinda gave me permission to do the same. It's weird, right? A quiet, guitar-playing dude being a source of strength. But that's Bleeker for ya. He's full of surprises.



Ugh, okay, so like, everyone keeps asking me that. It's not a *deep* thing, okay? It's not some profound statement about societal expectations or anything. Honestly? It just felt... unnecessary. 

Like, knowing if it was a boy or a girl wasn't gonna change anything about the fact that I was giving the baby up for adoption. It wasn't *my* forever baby, you know? And I figured, let the parents who are actually gonna raise it get the surprise. They deserve that. 

Plus, honestly, I was already dealing with a lot. Trying to navigate school, Paulie Bleeker, my dad being... my dad, and the whole pregnancy thing? Adding "pink or blue?" to the list just felt like extra credit I didn't need. It felt kinda selfish to want to know, when it wasn't really my place.

It's just... simpler this way. Less to process. Less to feel weird about. You get me? It's not like I *didn't* wonder, obviously. But I decided it was better to just let it be a little mystery. A little something special for Mark and Vanessa.



Ugh. Don't *even* get me started on that. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, he's got a way with words, doesn't he? "Scary neuter-baby." Like, seriously? It's not a monster movie, okay? It's... a baby. A tiny human. And yeah, the whole Mark situation was... a lot. A really intense, indie-film-gone-wrong kind of lot. 

Honestly, the thought of a kid looking like *him* was probably the most terrifying part of the whole pregnancy thing, besides, you know, *being* pregnant. He was all brooding and poetry and... well, let's just say he wasn't exactly built for diaper changes. 

But it's not about "scary" or "neuter." It's about wanting this kid to have a good life. A *stable* life. With parents who actually, you know, want to be parents. And who aren't obsessed with vinyl and existential dread. So, yeah, the thought of a mini-Mark running around was... unsettling. But it just reinforced the fact that this wasn't about me, or him. It was about what was best for the baby.

It's complicated, okay? Everything is always complicated. Especially when you're dealing with awkward indie rockers and unexpected pregnancies.



Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so, it wasn't... *conventional*, you know? Like, he wasn't exactly the star quarterback or anything. More like the guy who *documented* the star quarterback. With a camera. A really nice camera, actually. He was a quiet kid, really into music – The Smiths, mostly. Depressing stuff, honestly, for someone my age. 

At first, it was just... a thing. A one-time thing. And then, well, then there was a plus sign. Which, let me tell you, throws a wrench in *any* relationship, even the ones that aren't really relationships to begin with.

He was... sweet, though. In a dorky, awkward way. He tried, you know? He really did. He wasn't running away or anything, which was more than I expected. He was just... not equipped to deal with any of it. He was still figuring out *himself*, let alone fatherhood. 

We ended up being, like, friends. Sort of. More like... mutually supportive people who had a shared, slightly terrifying experience. It wasn't romantic, not anymore. It was just... understanding. And a lot of awkward silences. Honestly, I think we both just needed someone to be weird with, and we happened to find each other. It's complicated. Everything is, right?



Ugh, family. It's...complicated. Like, seriously complicated. You think *you* have drama? Try being me for a week.

Okay, okay, deep breaths. My stepmom, Bren, she was... surprisingly cool. Like, *actually* cool. Not the kind of cool where they try too hard, you know? She was just...there. Making me grilled cheese, letting me raid the fridge at 3 AM when the nausea hit, and not lecturing me to death. She's a good egg, Bren. Really. She and Mac (my dad) were both pretty quiet at first, which, honestly, I appreciated. No big speeches about responsibility or disappointment. Just...quiet support. 

Mac, he mostly just wanted me to finish high school. Which, fair. He's a bit of a worrier, my dad. Always has been. He tried to be all stoic and "strong for me," but I could tell he was freaked out. He'd just...clean things. Like, obsessively. It was kinda funny, actually.

My mom, though... that was a whole other can of worms. She's... artistic. And dramatic. And lives in Florida. So, phone calls. Lots and lots of phone calls filled with guilt trips and vague pronouncements about "the sanctity of life." It was exhausting. She eventually came around, I guess, but it wasn't exactly a Hallmark movie moment.

Honestly, the biggest support came from Leah. My best friend. She's the one who actually *got* it. She didn't treat me like some fragile porcelain doll. She just...hung out. Watched bad movies with me, helped me pick out baby names (which was weird, let me tell you), and generally just kept me from completely losing it. 

So yeah, family. A mixed bag. But they all showed up in their own weird ways. And I guess that's what matters, right? Even the ones who make you want to roll your eyes into next Tuesday.



Ugh, okay, so like, *that* question. It's not exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't one big dramatic breakdown, though people kinda expected that, I think. It was more... a lot of little cracks appearing. Like, suddenly I wasn't just Juno, the girl who likes bad horror movies and playing guitar. I was... Juno, the *pregnant* girl. And then Juno, the girl giving a baby away. It felt like I was trying on a bunch of costumes that didn't really fit.

Honestly? A lot of it was just pretending I wasn't feeling stuff. Sarcasm became my best friend. If someone asked how I was doing, I'd be all, "Oh, peachy. Just carrying around a tiny human and contemplating the existential dread of it all." You know, deflect with humor. It's a good skill. Highly recommend.

But that only works for so long. Eventually, you gotta actually *feel* things. And that's where Bleeker came in, actually. And Paul and Vanessa. They didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. They just... *were* there. Bleeker, especially, he just... got it. He was awkward and quiet and didn't try to be all profound, which was a relief. 

I think the biggest thing was realizing that choosing to give the baby up wasn't a failure of *me*. It was a really hard, grown-up decision, and it was the best thing for everyone involved. It didn't mean I didn't care, it meant I *did* care enough to want that baby to have the best life possible. 

And figuring out who *I* was, outside of all that? That took a while. It's still taking a while, honestly. It's kinda like... peeling an onion. You get rid of one layer and there's another one underneath. But I'm learning that it's okay to not have all the answers right now. It's okay to be a work in progress.



Ugh, okay, this is a *really* important question, so you better be prepared for a detailed answer. It's The Moldy Peaches, obviously. Like, duh.

It's not just the music, okay? It's...it's *real*. Adam Green and Kimya Dawson, they don't try to be anything they're not. It's all just kinda raw and honest and weird, you know? Like, they sing about stuff that's actually happening, not just, like, manufactured pop garbage. 

"Anyone Else But You" is basically the anthem of my life right now, honestly. It's kinda sad, but also...comforting? It's like, acknowledging the messiness of things. And their lyrics are just *smart*. They make you think, but not in a pretentious, English class kinda way. 

Plus, they're just...different. And I've always been a fan of different. Being normal is overrated. Seriously. So yeah, The Moldy Peaches. They get me. They *totally* get me. Don't judge.



Ugh, challenging is... a really polite way to put it. It's like, one minute you're obsessing over whether or not you should get those Converse in red or blue, and the next minute you're staring at a positive pregnancy test and thinking, "Well, *this* throws a wrench in the whole Converse situation."

It's weird, you know? Everyone always talks about finding yourself in high school, figuring out who you are. And I was doing that! I was pretty sure I was a cynical, indie-movie-loving, slightly sarcastic person. And then *bam*. Suddenly, "who you are" feels a lot less important than "what you're gonna *do*."

It's not just the pregnancy, either. It's... everything. Like, people start looking at you differently. Suddenly you're not just Juno, the girl who likes Phantom Planet. You're "Juno, the pregnant girl." It's kinda reductive, honestly. 

And making decisions? Forget about it. Every choice feels huge, like it's gonna ripple out and affect everything forever. It's not like picking a college, where you can always transfer. This is... different. 

So yeah, challenging. That's a good word. Though I'd probably also throw in "totally bonkers" and "a little bit terrifying." But hey, at least it's interesting, right? Beats being normal.



Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *big* question. It's not exactly something you just casually unpack over a plate of tater tots, you know? But alright, I'll bite.

Before... the whole Paul situation, and, well, *everything*, I thought love was all about, like, dramatic movie moments and holding hands in the rain. Super cheesy, I know, but that's what you see, right? And responsibility? That was just what my dad nagged me about – chores, homework, not failing out of North Hennepin. Pretty basic stuff.

But getting pregnant? That throws a wrench in *everything*. Suddenly, responsibility wasn't about keeping my room clean, it was about... a whole *person*. A tiny human who needed, like, everything. And that's when it hit me, love isn't just feelings. It's *doing*. It's wanting the best for someone, even if that best doesn't include *you*. 

Choosing adoption wasn't easy, obviously. It felt…weirdly selfless, which isn't a word I usually associate with myself. But I realized loving this kid meant wanting a life for them that I just couldn't give them *right now*. Mark and Vanessa? They were amazing. They were *ready*. And seeing them, how excited they were, how much they already loved this little person... that was a different kind of love. A quiet, hopeful kind.

It made me realize love isn't always about possession. It can be about letting go. And responsibility? It's not just about doing what's *easy*, it's about doing what's *right*, even when it's the hardest thing in the world. 

It's still kinda messy, figuring it all out. But yeah, that whole experience… it definitely changed my perspective. It made me grow up, I guess. Which is, like, totally annoying, but also… kinda good?



Okay, so, um... that's a loaded question, right? Like, people expect you to be all teary-eyed and instantly connected and stuff. Hallmark movie vibes. It wasn't *that*. Don't get me wrong, it was... a lot. 

Honestly? I was mostly just surprised he was so *small*. Like, I knew babies were small, obviously, but pictures don't really do it justice. He looked like a really wrinkly, slightly confused potato. And he was making these little noises, like he was already judging my life choices. Which, fair.

There was definitely a weird mix of things going on. Relief, I guess, that it was actually *happening* and he was okay. And a whole bunch of... sadness? Not like, "Oh my god, I'll never see him again!" sadness, more like, "Wow, this is a really big deal and I'm giving up something really important." It was kinda heavy.

But mostly, I just wanted to make sure he was healthy. And that Mark and Vanessa were ready. They seemed... really ready. And that made it a little easier. It wasn't about *me* wanting a baby, you know? It was about him needing parents who were, like, actually equipped to be parents. 

It was... complicated. It still is, if I'm being honest. But mostly, it was just... a baby. A tiny, wrinkly potato of a baby. And I wanted him to be okay.



Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *loaded* question, right? It wasn't like I was trying to be cruel or anything. It just...felt like too much. Paulie and I, we were good. We were comfortable. We were, you know, *us*. And suddenly dropping a bomb like *that* on him? It felt like it would just...change everything before we even had a chance to figure anything *out*.

He's a sweet guy, Paulie. Really sweet. But he's also...not exactly the most proactive person, if you catch my drift. He'd probably just spend the whole time being really, really worried and not actually *doing* anything helpful. And honestly? I didn't want him feeling like he *had* to be a hero or something. This wasn't about him needing to save the day. 

Plus, I needed space to process it myself, you know? It was *my* body, *my* decision. I needed to figure out what *I* wanted before I dragged him into the mess. It felt...selfish, maybe, but it felt right at the time. I figured I could handle telling him *after* I'd already made some headway with the adoption stuff. Less drama that way, probably.

It wasn't easy, though. Keeping something that big a secret? It's exhausting. But sometimes, you gotta do what you gotta do, even if it's a little weird and complicated. It's just...life, I guess. And life is rarely straightforward.



Ugh, okay, so *that* was a whole thing. Honestly, it's kinda embarrassing to even *think* about, let alone *talk* about. It wasn't like I just, you know, casually dropped it into conversation over a plate of tater tots. 

See, Leah, she's... well, Leah. She means well, she really does, but she has the subtlety of a freight train. She found out from, like, *Vanessa* - who got it from, I don't even know, the ether, probably. And then Leah, bless her heart, decided Paulie *needed* to know. She figured it was, like, a human rights thing or something.

So she cornered him at the record store, while he was trying to, like, *browse*, and just... blurted it out. Apparently, he went completely pale and just stared at her for a solid five minutes before mumbling something about needing more guitar picks. 

It was mortifying. I found out *he* found out because he started acting... weird. Like, even weirder than usual. Just staring at me during Chemistry, avoiding eye contact, and generally radiating a vibe of "holy crap." I had to pry it out of him. Honestly, it was way less dramatic than I imagined it would be, which was almost worse. He didn't yell, he didn't freak out, he just... looked sad. And then he offered me a Funyun. 

It was a whole mess. People just... *know* things, you know? It's like information just floats around and attaches itself to the nearest unsuspecting person. It's the worst.



Ugh, okay, so like, it wasn't exactly a *decision* I made all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It just… *was*. Paulie Bleeker, bless his awkward heart, and I… well, we weren't exactly practicing safe sex. Shocking, I know. Teenagers. Go figure.

When I found out, my first thought wasn't, like, "Oh my gosh, a baby!" It was more, "Oh my gosh, my life is officially a really messed up indie film." And honestly? I was still figuring *me* out. I was barely past wanting to collect vintage records and avoid gym class. I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not even close.

My parents, they were… surprisingly cool about it. My dad, he just kept saying things like, "Well, this is a pickle." And my stepmom, Bren, she was just really supportive, which was weirdly comforting. They were all for me having an abortion, but… it didn't feel right. I don't know. It just didn't.

So, adoption felt like the least… awful option. Like, I could give this kid a life with people who *wanted* a baby, who were actually prepared for it. A real family. And I could still finish high school, maybe even go to college. It felt… responsible, I guess. Even though it was the hardest thing I've ever had to think about. 

It wasn't about just getting rid of it, you know? It was about wanting what was best for the baby. And what was best for the baby wasn't me, at that point. It's complicated. Everything is always complicated.



Ugh. Okay, so, Bleeker. Right. Honestly? It wasn't *surprising*, exactly. I mean, the kid was, like, a total music obsessive. All angst and guitar riffs and… well, not a whole lot of thinking ahead. He was sixteen, okay? Sixteen! He barely knew what *he* wanted for breakfast, let alone a whole human being.

But still. It stung. You know? Like, I was already doing this whole thing – the pregnancy, the adoption, the whole shebang – mostly on my own. And to have the guy who *helped* make the situation just… bail? It felt kinda cheap. Like, "Oh, I got what I wanted, see ya!" 

I tried to be cool about it. I mean, I *told* him I understood. I even said something sarcastic, probably, about how he needed to focus on his band. Gotta maintain the facade, you know? But inside? It felt like a little piece of me was just…deflated. 

It made me realize, though, that this wasn't about him. It was about the baby. And about me, figuring out what *I* wanted to do, and what was best. It wasn't about waiting for Bleeker to suddenly grow a spine and decide to be a dad. It was about finding parents who *wanted* to be parents. And that, honestly, was a relief. A weird, kinda sad relief, but relief nonetheless.



Ugh. Okay, so, seeing Vanessa with the baby... it was... a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. You spend nine months, well, mostly nine months, kinda connected to this little person, right? Even if you *know* you're giving them up, it's still... weird. 

And Vanessa? She was a mess. Seriously. Hair all over the place, wearing, like, a floral housedress that probably hadn't seen iron in its life, and just... beaming. Like she'd won the lottery and a lifetime supply of mozzarella sticks. It was kinda endearing, honestly. 

It wasn't what I expected. I figured she'd be all polished and perfect, you know? Like a Stepford wife with a baby. But she was just... real. And happy. *Really* happy. And that, I guess, was the point. 

It was a relief, actually. Seeing her like that. It meant I'd made the right decision. That the baby was going to someone who genuinely *wanted* to be a mom, even if she wasn't exactly Martha Stewart. It was... good. 

It also made me feel kinda... old. Like, I'd just finished a chapter of my life and she was starting hers. Which is dramatic, I know. But that's how it felt. And a little bit sad, obviously. But mostly good. Mostly.



Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about "Anyone Else But You"? Seriously? It's...complicated. It's not like Bleeker and I were, like, *planning* a soundtrack to our lives, you know? It just kinda...happened. 

See, Bleeker, he's a musician. A really *good* musician, actually. Super sensitive, writes all these heartfelt songs. And that song, it was *his* song. He wrote it about some girl before me, obviously. A girl he was totally hung up on. 

But then, we started hanging out, and he'd play it, and it wasn't about *her* anymore, not really. It became...about us. About how awkward and weird and kinda perfect we were *together*. Like, we were both kinda messed up, both kinda lost, and we found each other in all the mess. 

It's ironic, right? The song is about wanting *anyone* but the person you're obsessed with. And we were totally obsessed with each other, even though we were both trying to play it cool. It was like, we were admitting we were both a little bit ridiculous, a little bit desperate for connection. 

It kinda summed up the whole thing, I guess. We weren't what anyone expected. We weren't the "normal" couple. But we were...something. And that song, cheesy as it is, kinda captured that. It was our little secret, a little reminder that even when things are messy and confusing, sometimes you just find someone who makes it all okay. Or, at least, a little less terrible.



Ugh, okay, so *that*. It's...complicated. Honestly, it's not like I expected a full-blown, pink-and-blue explosion of gifts and cooing, but the hesitation is kinda obvious, right? People are weird about, like, the *circumstances*. 

See, a baby shower is usually for people who are, you know, actively planning to *keep* the baby. And I'm...not. I'm giving him – it's a boy, by the way, pretty sure – to Mark and Vanessa. They're really nice, super put-together, have a Pottery Barn catalogue memorized. Basically, the opposite of my life.

So I think people are walking on eggshells because they don't want to, like, imply I'm gonna change my mind or something. Or maybe they're worried it'll be awkward? Like, "Oh, congratulations on giving your baby away!" That's not exactly a heartwarming sentiment, is it? 

Plus, my mom, bless her heart, is trying to be supportive, but she's also kinda...overwhelmed. She's never really dealt with anything like this before. It's all a bit much. It's like, everyone's trying to be sensitive, which is nice, but it ends up just being...weirdly tiptoe-y.

Honestly? I get it. It's not a typical situation. But a little cake and some diapers wouldn't kill anyone. It's not about *me* wanting a party, it's about acknowledging the baby, you know? He deserves a little celebration, even if it's a slightly unconventional one.



Ugh, okay, so Bren. Bren's...intense. And honestly, a little bit of a control freak, even if she doesn't *think* she is. It's not like I was, like, building a fort in Mark's living room or something. It was movies and CDs! Perfectly harmless. 

But I think she got weirded out because, well, Mark is *her* husband. And even though we're all trying to be super mature about the whole adoption thing, and Mark's being all supportive and stuff, I guess she felt like me spending extra time with him, even doing something as normal as watching a movie, was...I don't know...crossing a line? Like I was trying to, I don't know, *replace* her or something? Which is ridiculous.

It's like, she wants me to be grateful for their offer, which I *am*, but she also wants to keep me at arm's length. It's a tricky balance, you know? And honestly, I think she's just scared. Scared about the baby, scared about letting go, scared about...everything. 

Plus, she's got that whole perfect-life aesthetic going on. A little bit of a messy, pregnant teenager hanging around probably doesn't fit the picture. It's just...complicated. And Bren's complicated. Don't tell her I said that.



Ugh, okay, so my mom, Bren? She's... well, she's a *piece*. Not a bad piece, necessarily, just... intensely focused on the whole domestic bliss thing. Like, she's got a whole collection of vintage kitchen stuff and thinks a perfectly coordinated throw pillow arrangement is the key to eternal happiness. 

Anyway, she thinks I don't know anything about marriage because, and I quote, "You spend all your time listening to that rock and roll and reading comic books, Juno. You haven't even *considered* the delicate art of compromise!" 

Which, okay, fair point about the rock and roll and comics. But it's not like I'm living under a rock. I *observe* people. I see how things go down. And honestly? Most of the married people I know seem... stressed. Like, constantly negotiating over who gets the remote or what color to paint the bathroom. It doesn't look particularly glamorous, you know?

She thinks it's all about finding "the one" and building a perfect life together. I think it's about figuring out how to not kill each other after, like, ten years of sharing a bathroom. So yeah, she figures I'm blissfully ignorant. She thinks I'm picturing a wedding with doves and a string quartet when I'm really just picturing a lot of passive-aggressive note-leaving.



It's kinda frustrating, though. Like, just because I don't *want* the whole white picket fence thing doesn't mean I'm clueless. It just means I have different priorities. Like, not having to iron. That's a big one.



Ugh, okay, so like, it's not exactly a *happy* inspiration, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Ooh, adoption! How *chic*!" It was more...practical. And honestly, a little bit terrifying.

See, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human. Paulie Bleeker – bless his awkward heart – he's a good guy, but he's sixteen too. We're both still learning how to do laundry without turning everything pink. 

It just...didn't feel right to bring a kid into that. Like, a kid deserves someone who's actually *ready*. Someone who has their life a little more together than a collection of vintage records and a serious allergy to gym class. 

Mark and Vanessa, they were...perfect. Seriously. They *wanted* a baby, and they had a beautiful house and a dog and, like, actual matching furniture. It felt like the best thing for the baby, you know? Not the easiest thing for *me*, obviously. But the best.

It wasn't about not loving the baby. It was about loving the baby enough to want it to have everything I couldn't give it right then. Does that make sense? It's kinda complicated. It's not a movie plot, it's...life. And life is messy.



Ugh, okay, so like, that was... a lot. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a really awkward, slightly terrifying hike up a really steep hill. And honestly? I learned I'm way more capable than I thought I was. I mean, before all this, I was mostly concerned with finding the perfect vintage record and avoiding gym class. Suddenly, I was dealing with, like, *life*. Real life.

I always thought I was pretty good at being sarcastic and keeping people at arm's length. Turns out, that's just a way of being scared. Being pregnant forced me to actually *feel* things, and not just, like, annoyance at people who chew too loudly. It made me realize I *could* be vulnerable, and that it wasn't the end of the world. Actually, sometimes it was kinda... good. 

I also learned I'm surprisingly good at making decisions, even really hard ones. Giving up the baby wasn't easy, obviously. It still isn't, sometimes. But knowing I chose the best thing for him, for *everyone* involved? That took guts. And I didn't even know I *had* guts. Figuratively speaking, of course. Though, I guess I had a pretty big belly for a while there too.

Basically, I learned I'm not just some cynical, music-obsessed kid. I'm... complicated. And that's okay. It's actually kinda cool, when you think about it. It's like discovering a hidden track on your favorite album. You didn't know it was there, but suddenly it makes the whole thing even better.



Ugh, okay, so Vanessa and Mark. Right. It's...complicated. At first, honestly, they were kinda intimidating. Like, *really* put-together people. You know? Like they had their lives all planned out with color-coded calendars and matching throw pillows. And me? I was still figuring out if I even *wanted* a color-coded calendar. 

I think I initially saw them as...well, the "adults." The people who had it all figured out and were just...taking a baby. Which, okay, they *were* taking a baby, but it felt weirdly transactional at first. Like I was selling them something. Which, I guess in a way I was, but it was a *person*. A tiny human I was growing. Heavy stuff.

But then, you start spending time with people, right? And you realize they're just...people. Vanessa, she was really good at just *listening*. Not judging, not offering advice unless I asked for it. Just...there. And Mark, he was kinda goofy, actually. He'd try to be all serious and responsible, but you could tell he was nervous too. They were both just...really wanting this. And that made it less about *taking* and more about *wanting to love*.

It changed from feeling like a business arrangement to...well, to feeling like I was letting my kid go to people who genuinely, truly wanted to be parents. And that, honestly, was the hardest part. But knowing *they* were good people, that they'd give the baby a good life...that made it a little easier. 

It wasn't a friendship, exactly. It was more like...a shared experience. A really intense, weird, life-altering shared experience. And I think we all grew up a little bit because of it. Even them. They weren't perfect, but they were *real*. And that's what mattered.



Ugh, regrets. That's a heavy word, isn't it? Like, it implies I'd do things *differently* if I could go back. And honestly? That's...complicated.

Look, the whole situation was pretty spectacularly messed up to begin with. Paulie Bleeker and I...well, let's just say we weren't exactly aiming for parenthood. It was a one-time thing, a momentary lapse in judgment fueled by cheesy pizza and a whole lot of awkwardness. 

Do I regret *getting* pregnant? No. Because then I wouldn't have met Vanessa and Mark. They were...good people. Really good. And they gave my little guy, Henry, a life I just couldn't have provided. A stable life, with a house and a yard and parents who were *actually* ready. That's not something to regret.
