But do I regret some of the *stuff* that happened *around* it? Maybe. Like, the whole Mark and Vanessa drama with their…issues. That was stressful. And maybe I was a little too sarcastic with some people. My dad, especially. He tried, you know? He just...doesn't always *get* it. 

But mostly, I think everything happened the way it was supposed to. It forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It made me figure out what I wanted, what I *didn't* want. And it taught me that sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is let go. 

So, regrets? Not really. Just...a lot of stuff I learned the hard way. And honestly, I wouldn't trade Henry for anything. Knowing he's out there, being loved and happy? That's enough.



Okay, so, like, that's a *big* question. It's not something you just...get over, you know? It's not like a bad haircut that grows out. It's...more permanent than that.

Honestly, for a long time, it felt like a giant, slightly awkward hole in my life. Like, I'd be doing something totally normal – picking out records, arguing with my stepmom about chores, even just *breathing* – and then BAM, it would hit me. This little person was out there, living a life I wasn't a part of. And that was...hard.

But it wasn't *sad* hard, not always. It was more...complicated. I mean, I knew from the start that giving him up – giving Leo up – was the right thing. Mark and Vanessa, they were *good* people. They wanted a kid so badly, and they could give him a life I just...couldn't. I was sixteen, for crying out loud! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone a whole human being.

It forced me to grow up, I guess. Like, really grow up. Not just in the "suddenly you have to do your own laundry" way, but in the "understanding that life isn't always about what *you* want" way. It taught me a lot about responsibility, and about making tough choices, even when they hurt. 

And, weirdly, it helped me figure out what *I* wanted. Before Leo, I was just kinda...drifting. Now, I had this huge thing I'd done, this huge decision I'd made, and it made me want to actually *do* something with my life. I started taking my songwriting more seriously, and I actually started thinking about college. 

It's still...present, you know? I think about Leo a lot. But it's not a weight anymore. It's more like...a part of me. A really important, really formative part. It made me who I am, and honestly? I think I'm okay with that.



Ugh. Okay, look. It's...it's not exactly a picnic, finding out you're preggers when you're still trying to figure out what *you* want for lunch, you know? Like, I was still debating whether or not to get a nose ring. Priorities.

But seriously. If you're staring at a positive test and your brain is doing the full-on panic disco, first thing? Breathe. Just...breathe. It's gonna be okay. It might not *feel* okay, and it's definitely gonna be messy, but okay is possible.

Don't let anyone tell you what you *should* do. Your parents, your boyfriend, your weird aunt who knits cat sweaters...none of 'em. This is *your* life, *your* body, and *your* decision. It's a big one, obviously, but it has to be yours. 

And don't be afraid to talk to people. Not just anyone, though. Find someone you trust, someone who won't judge you, someone who'll just...listen. My dad, surprisingly, was pretty good at that. And Bleeker, even though he's kinda quiet, he was there too. 

Honestly? It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to not have all the answers. Nobody does, really. Just...be honest with yourself, and with the people you choose to let in. And remember, even when it feels like everything is falling apart, you're stronger than you think. You just gotta...figure out how to be.



It's kinda like, you know, a really complicated puzzle. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let someone else help you put the pieces together. But *you* still get to decide what the picture looks like.



Ugh, okay, so like, the whole blogging thing wasn't *my* idea originally. It was Bleeker. He's... well, he's Bleeker. Very into indie music and, apparently, documenting everything. He thought it would be a good way to, you know, "process" things. As if I needed *him* to tell me how to process things. 

Honestly? At first I thought it was totally lame. Like, broadcasting my personal life to the internet? Super cringe. But then I figured, what the heck. It's not like I'm exactly overflowing with productive hobbies. Plus, it gave me something to do besides obsessively eat cheese curls and avoid my dad.

It started as just, like, a way to vent. A place to write down all the weird stuff that was happening. And then... people started reading it. And commenting. And some of them actually *got* it. Not the whole "teen pregnancy" thing, obviously, but the feeling of being totally lost and trying to figure out what you're doing with your life. 

So, yeah. It became... a thing. A weird, slightly embarrassing, but sometimes surprisingly helpful thing. It's kinda like talking to a really, really large group of strangers who are all judging you, but also maybe offering decent advice. It's complicated. Just like everything else right now.



Ugh, okay, biggest lesson? That's... a loaded question, honestly. It wasn't like a pop quiz where the answer was neatly printed in the back of the textbook. It was more like a really messy, complicated art project where you're using, like, glitter and glue and also existential dread.

But if I *had* to boil it down... I guess it's that people are way more complicated than they seem. Like, *way* more. Before all this happened, I kinda saw things in black and white. Good people, bad people, simple as that. But then you meet Mark and Vanessa, and you realize everyone's got their own stuff going on, their own reasons for being the way they are. Even if those reasons are kinda... weird. 

And it's not just them. It's my parents, too. They were... surprisingly cool about the whole thing, considering. I always thought they'd freak. But they didn't. They just... were there. And I realized they were just people, too, trying to figure things out, just like me.

So yeah. People are messy. Life is messy. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just... accept the mess and try to make something good out of it. And maybe, just maybe, find a little bit of yourself in the process. It's not exactly a profound revelation, but it took me nine months to figure it out. So, you know, give me a break.



Okay, so, like... first of all, deep breaths. Seriously. It feels like the world is ending, right? Like someone just hit the pause button on your life and is showing a really unflattering close-up of your face. It's not. It's just... complicated.

The biggest thing is, don't let anyone else tell you what *you* should do. Your parents, your friends, that weird guy who keeps staring at you in the hallway... none of 'em. It's *your* body, *your* situation, and *your* decision. Period.

Think about what *you* want. Really think. Not what's easiest, not what'll make everyone else happy, but what feels... right. And it's okay if you don't know right away. It's okay to be scared, confused, even a little bit freaked out. That's, like, totally normal. 

There are options, you know? And they're all valid. Keeping it, adoption... it's not a black and white thing. And honestly? It's okay to talk to someone. A counselor, a trusted teacher, even just a friend who won't judge. Just... someone who'll listen. 

And listen, this isn't a reflection on you. It doesn't make you a bad person. It just makes you a person who's dealing with something really big. So, be kind to yourself. And maybe eat a grilled cheese. Those always help.



Ugh, okay, deep thoughts already? It's not like I spend *all* my time picturing tiny humans and their life trajectories, you know? It's kinda weird to even think about, honestly. Like, they haven't even... *happened* yet.

But if I *had* to, and people keep asking, I guess... I just want them to be happy. Super cliché, I know. But seriously. Not, like, Disney-princess-happy, because that's unrealistic and probably involves a lot of singing. More like... content. Like, finding something they're good at, something that makes them feel... not *bored*, you know? 

I don't want them stuck in some job they hate, just to pay bills. I want them to be able to, like, appreciate a good record, or a weird movie, or just sitting outside on a nice day. And I really, *really* hope they're not into frosted tips. That's just... a tragedy waiting to happen.

Mostly, I just want them to be okay with being themselves. That's the hardest part, right? Figuring out who *that* even is. And I want them to have people who love them for it. That's why I'm doing this whole adoption thing, you know? Finding people who are already, like, equipped to give them that. It's not about what *I* want for them, it's about what's *best* for them. 

Does that make sense? It's kinda hard to articulate when you're still, like, figuring out your own life.



Ugh, okay, seriously? There are *so* many. But if I had to pick just *one*... it's this whole idea that we're, like, automatically incapable of making a good decision. Like, because we still like, listen to Fall Out Boy and haven't figured out our five-year plan, we're just gonna mess everything up. 

It's not about age, you know? It's about being a person. And people, regardless of how old they are, are capable of being thoughtful and responsible. Just because I got into this situation doesn't mean I'm suddenly a total idiot. I actually put a *lot* of thought into what I was gonna do, and I'm pretty sure I made the best choice for everyone involved. 

People assume we're just...scared little kids. And yeah, okay, I was scared. Still am, sometimes. But scared doesn't equal stupid. It just means you're a human being facing something big. And honestly, some of the adults I've met lately could use a little more thinking through things themselves. Just sayin'.



Ugh, okay, so like, it's not a super easy question, you know? It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, perfect! Let's just...give the baby away!" That would be seriously messed up.

Honestly? It was just...real life hitting me in the face. Paulie Bleeker – sweet, oblivious Paulie – and I, we were...well, we were kids. Still *are* kids, really. And having a baby? That's, like, a whole *adult* thing. A really, really big adult thing. 

I wasn't ready. My parents weren't exactly equipped to raise a baby either, let's be real. They're more into vintage furniture and quiet evenings. A screaming infant would probably send them into a full-blown mid-life crisis.

So, it wasn't about *not* wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was best *for* the baby. And what was best wasn't me, a sixteen-year-old who still hasn't figured out what she wants to be when she grows up, let alone how to raise a tiny human. 

Mark and Vanessa Loring, they were...different. They *wanted* this. They were ready. They had a beautiful home, and they just...seemed like they could give the baby a life I couldn't. It felt...right. Even though it was, like, the hardest decision I've ever had to make.

It's not a happy story, exactly. It's just...a story. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is admit you can't do something yourself and find someone who can. Does that make sense? It's complicated. Everything always is.



Ugh, okay, so that was... a process. It wasn't like, "Ooh, shiny! They have a nice house!" though some people *totally* thought that. Like, my dad kept making little comments about their landscaping. Seriously, Dad? Focus.

It started with the ads, you know? The personal ads Paul and I were sifting through. So many people wanting a baby, and honestly, a lot of them were... intense. Like, picture-perfect families who wanted a little mini-me to take to soccer practice. No offense to soccer, but that wasn't what *this* was about.

Then we met Vanessa and Mark. And it wasn't instant love or anything. Mark was... a little dorky, honestly. Super into vintage records and stuff. But Vanessa? She was different. She was... real. She hadn't had an easy time getting pregnant, and she wasn't trying to pretend everything was sunshine and rainbows. She was honest about wanting a kid, about wanting *my* kid, but also about being scared. 

And they *listened*. They didn't try to tell me what to do, or how to feel. They asked me what *I* wanted for the baby, what kind of life I envisioned. They wanted to know about my music, my friends, my life. They weren't just looking for a baby, they were looking to be *parents*. 

It just... clicked. It felt less like handing my baby over to strangers and more like handing her over to people who were genuinely going to love her and give her a good life. A *good* life, you know? Not a perfect one, because those don't exist, but a good one. And honestly, that's all I ever wanted.



Ugh, music. Okay, don't get me wrong, it wasn't like I was, you know, *obsessed* or anything. But it was… a thing. A big thing, actually. It was kinda how I processed everything, I guess. Like, when things were totally awkward and weird – which, let's be real, was most of the time – I'd just put on a mix CD and try to pretend I was in a movie montage. 

Mostly it was The Moldy Peaches. Adam and I bonded *hard* over them. "Anyone Else But You" was, like, *our* song, before… well, before everything. It's kinda ironic now, isn't it? Considering. 

But it wasn't just them. I was into a lot of stuff. Belle & Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie, even some older stuff my dad liked, like Buddy Holly. It just… fit. It felt honest, you know? Like the people making the music weren't trying to be anything they weren't. Which, as a teenager, is a pretty big deal. You're trying to figure out *who* you are, and it helps to listen to people who seem to have it figured out, even if they probably don't.

It was a good escape, too. When everything felt too much, I could just crank up the volume and pretend I was somewhere else. Which, honestly, was a skill I needed to develop pretty quickly.



Ugh, the stigma. Right. Like everyone in Maple Creek suddenly became experts on reproductive health and moral failings the second the pregnancy test showed positive. It was…intense. Honestly? I mostly just leaned *into* being weird. If people were gonna judge me anyway, I figured I might as well give them something *really* to talk about. 

Like, I didn't try to hide it, you know? I didn't suddenly start wearing a burlap sack and pretending I was a nun. I still wore my Converse and listened to The Moldy Peaches. I still hung out at the diner. I just…had a baby on board. And I figured if people wanted to whisper and point, that was *their* problem, not mine. 

It helped that my dad, Mac, he was pretty chill about the whole thing. He just kept saying, "Well, this is a pickle." Which, honestly, summed it up pretty well. And Bleeker…well, Bleeker was Bleeker. Mostly just confused.

But the real coping came from finding people who weren't judging, you know? Like Vanessa, my stepmom. She was a rock. And Paul, the dad who was gonna adopt the baby? He and his wife, Mark, they were just…good people. Seeing them, talking to them, it made me realize it wasn't about what *everyone else* thought. It was about doing what was right for the baby. 

So, yeah. I coped by being myself, being honest, and surrounding myself with people who didn't treat me like a walking cautionary tale. Plus, a healthy dose of sarcasm. That always helps. It's like a shield, you know? Keeps the negativity from sticking.



Okay, so, like, that's a *big* question. It wasn't...easy. People think it's just, you know, hand over the baby and *poof*, everything's fine. It's not. It's way more complicated than that. 

Honestly, the days leading up to it were...weird. Like, I was trying to be all chill and practical, you know? "This is the best thing for the baby," and all that. But then you feel kicks, or you're picking out tiny socks, and suddenly you're thinking, "Wait a minute...this is *my* kid." Even if "my kid" was going to have a way better life with Mark and Vanessa.

Giving her up...it felt like handing over a piece of myself. A really important piece. There were tears, obviously. A lot of them. But it wasn't just sadness, it was...relief, too. Relief knowing she was going to a home where she was *wanted* wanted, not just...a consequence. 

And seeing Mark and Vanessa with her? That helped. A lot. They were so genuinely happy and excited. It made me feel like I'd done the right thing, even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done. 

It's still...something I think about. Like, what she's doing, if she likes dinosaurs as much as I hoped she would. But I know she's loved. And that's what matters. It wasn't about *forgetting* her, it was about letting her *go* so she could have everything I couldn't give her. It's a weird feeling, but...it's okay. It really is.



Ugh. Okay, so, like, the physical stuff was... not ideal. Let's just start there. I was sixteen, right? Sixteen! I was mostly concerned with finding the perfect vintage dress and listening to The Velvet Underground, not, you know, *growing a human*. Suddenly, everything felt… different. And not in a good, "new shoes" different. More like a "your body is betraying you with cravings for pickles and ice cream" different. 

The morning sickness? Don't even *start* me. It wasn't just mornings, okay? It was all the time. And it wasn't cute. It was just… gross. And then there was the, like, expanding situation. People kept saying I was "glowing." I felt more like I was inflating. It was weird.

But the emotional stuff? That was way harder. It was a total rollercoaster. One minute I was totally fine, making jokes about it, and the next I was just… sad. Really sad. It wasn't even about *wanting* the baby, necessarily. It was about everything changing. My life, my plans, everything. It felt like everyone was looking at me differently, too. Like I was suddenly… fragile. Which, honestly, I *hate* being seen as fragile. 

I mostly dealt with it by being sarcastic. A lot. And listening to music. And talking to Bleeker. He was… surprisingly good at just *listening*. And Paul, too, even though he was a little… intense sometimes. It helped to have people who didn't treat me like I was broken, you know? Just… going through something.

It was a lot. A *lot*. And honestly, I still don't think I fully processed it all, even now. But you kinda just… keep going. You find a way. Because what else are you gonna do?



Okay, wow. That's... a pretty direct question. Like, right to the point. It's not like people usually just *ask* about that. But alright, I guess I can talk about it. It's not exactly a picnic to reminisce about, you know?

See, people always assume it was just, like, a flippant decision. Like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, a baby? Nah, I'm good." It wasn't. It was... complicated. Really complicated. And honestly, it wasn't *about* the abortion itself, not really. It was about what came *after*. Realizing I wasn't ready. That I wanted to have a life, a future, that wasn't completely consumed by being a mom right then. 

And that's where the whole reproductive rights thing comes in. Because it shouldn't be anyone else's decision but *mine*. Like, seriously. It's *my* body, *my* life, *my* future. And if someone else is telling me what I can and can't do with it, that's just... wrong. 

I mean, I get that people have different beliefs. That's fine. But those beliefs shouldn't dictate what *I* do. Everyone's situation is different. Some people want to have kids right away, some don't. Some can't. And it's not up to some politician or some judgmental person to decide for them. 

It's about having choices. Plain and simple. And making sure those choices are available to everyone, no matter what. Because taking that away? That's just... taking away someone's power. And nobody should have that right.

It's kinda messed up to think about, honestly. Makes you realize how fragile things are. And how important it is to stand up for what you believe in, even if it's uncomfortable.



Okay, so, like, "overcome" is a *strong* word. It wasn't exactly a conquering-the-world kinda situation, you know? More like...managing not to completely freak out all the time. Which, honestly, was a victory in itself.

See, the thing is, I'm not really the type to *do* fear. I mean, I *feel* it, obviously. Like when Paulie Bleeker tries to be romantic – instant fear. But I mostly just talk my way around it, or make a sarcastic comment until it feels less scary. 

With the whole baby thing...it was different. It wasn't something I could just quip my way out of. It was *real*. And terrifying. But I realized pretty quickly that being scared wasn't gonna, like, *make* the situation disappear. 

So, I just...started breaking it down. One thing at a time. First, telling my dad. That was…rough. Then figuring out what I wanted. And then finding Mark and Vanessa. Talking to them, seeing they were, like, *good* people, that helped a lot. 

Honestly, the biggest thing was realizing I wasn't alone. Bleeker was surprisingly supportive, even if he mostly showed it by just…being Bleeker. My dad, even though he was initially a total mess, was there. And Leah, my stepmom, she was a lifesaver. 

It wasn't about being brave, it was about admitting I needed help and letting people *give* it. And a lot of listening to Phoebe Buffay on repeat. Don't judge. It's surprisingly grounding.

So, did I "overcome" my fears? Nah. I just learned to live with them, and to talk really fast when they got too loud. And to trust that things would, eventually, be okay. Even if "okay" looked a lot different than I expected.



Ugh, okay, so like, people always ask that. It's not like I *wanted* to be pregnant, alright? It just… happened. And honestly? The thought of actually *raising* a kid right now? It felt… irresponsible. Not in a, "I'm a bad person" way, but in a "I'm sixteen, I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes, and my biggest life decision yesterday was whether or not to wear stripes with polka dots" kind of way.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, see? It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. A real home, people who were, like, actually ready for it. Mark and Vanessa… they just seemed… good. Solid. They wanted a kid so badly, and I figured, well, why not give them that chance? 

Plus, let's be real, my life wasn't exactly set up for tiny humans. My dad's a handyman, my stepmom's into pottery, and I'm mostly into music and avoiding gym class. It's a good life, but it's *my* life. And I needed to still *have* a life, you know? 

It felt… less selfish, I guess, to find someone who could give the baby more than I could right then. It wasn't easy, don't get me wrong. It's still kinda weird to think about. But it felt… right. Does that make sense? It's complicated. Everything always is.



Ugh, relationships. They're...complicated. Like, seriously. It's not all holding hands and gazing into each other's eyes like in those terrible rom-coms my stepmom watches. It's more like navigating a minefield of awkwardness and trying not to say the *wrong* thing, which, let's be real, I'm pretty good at saying the wrong thing anyway.

Leah, though. Leah's different. She's my rock, you know? We've been through everything together – bad haircuts, questionable fashion choices (mostly mine), and now… *this*. She's the only one who didn't freak out when I told her I was preggers, which, honestly, was a huge relief. She just kinda… nodded and asked if I needed ice cream. That's a true friend. Sometimes I think she understands me better than I understand myself. We bicker, sure, mostly about music – she's all about the indie stuff and I'm more of a classic rock kinda girl – but it's a good bicker. It means we actually *talk* to each other. It's a solid, reliable thing, our friendship. It's…safe.

Paulie, on the other hand… Paulie is a whole other can of worms. He's sweet, I guess. A little…intense. And definitely not the sharpest tool in the shed. Honestly, at first, it was just… a thing. A momentary lapse in judgment fueled by Phoenix and a whole lot of teenage hormones. Now? It's…weird. We're trying to be mature about it, for the baby's sake, but it's hard. He's trying, I'll give him that. He's learning to play guitar, which is… endearing, in a slightly pathetic way. But it's not like we're gonna be going on dates or anything. It's more like co-parenting practice, even though we won't *be* co-parenting, because, you know, adoption. It's just… a lot. 

It's like Leah is the steady, comfortable pair of shoes you wear every day, and Paulie is… those sparkly platform boots you tried on once and immediately regretted. They looked cool for a minute, but they're definitely not practical.



Ugh, okay, seriously? That's... a loaded question. It's not like I *decided* to become a teenage mother, alright? It just *happened*. Like, one minute I'm perfecting my sarcastic eye-roll, the next I'm staring at a positive pregnancy test and thinking, "Well, this is spectacularly inconvenient."

Paulie Bleeker and I... we were, you know, experimenting. It wasn't like we weren't careful, exactly, but sometimes life just throws you a curveball. A really, really big, life-altering curveball. 

Honestly, the decision wasn't about *wanting* to be a mom at sixteen. It was about doing what was best for the baby. I mean, I'm barely figuring out *myself*, let alone another human being. I wasn't ready to give a kid the life they deserved. And that's the thing, right? It's not about what *I* want, it's about what's best for *them*. 

It's complicated. Everything is always complicated. But I figured, if I couldn't give this kid a good life, maybe someone else could. And that felt... responsible. Even if it also felt like the hardest thing I'd ever have to do.



Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, the kind of question people ask when they want to see if you're secretly crumbling inside, you know? It's not like I walk around every day thinking, "Oh man, what if I'd kept it?" because honestly, that would've been a *disaster*. A beautifully chaotic, probably hilarious disaster, but a disaster nonetheless.

Look, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out if I even *liked* orange juice, let alone raising a human. Paulie Bleeker was... Paulie Bleeker. Sweet, but not exactly equipped to handle a diaper situation. 

No, I don't regret *the decision*. I regret... maybe not having talked to my dad about it sooner. He was surprisingly cool about the whole thing, once he got over the initial shock. And maybe I regret some of the awkwardness with Vanessa and Mark. They were really good people, and I kinda put them through the wringer.

But regret the actual giving-up part? No. Because I knew, deep down, that I wanted that baby to have a life I couldn't give it *right then*. A life with stability and two parents who were, like, actively trying to be adults. Vanessa and Mark gave Leo that. And seeing them with him... that was good. It *is* good. 

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple "yes" or "no." It's more like... a really long, rambling sentence with a lot of commas and a slightly sarcastic tone. Does that make sense?



Ugh, okay, so *that*. Everyone always wants to know about the school thing. Like it was some Herculean feat or something. Honestly? It was mostly just… annoying. And a lot of strategically placed hoodies.

Look, I wasn't about to let being pregnant derail my life completely, you know? I mean, I had plans. Okay, *vague* plans, but still. Dropping out felt…defeatist. Plus, my dad, he was surprisingly cool about the whole thing, once he got over the initial shock of, well, *everything*. He kept saying education was important, and honestly, I think he just didn't want me hanging around the house all day. Which, fair.

So, I just…went. I sat in the back of class, tried not to show too much, and mostly just focused on not throwing up during Mr. Belting's history lectures. He drones on *forever*. Blech. 

It helped that a lot of people just…ignored it. High school kids are surprisingly good at pretending things aren't happening if it makes them uncomfortable. And Leah and Paulie? They were lifesavers. Leah helped me with notes when I missed stuff, and Paulie…well, Paulie just made me laugh, which is always good. 

It wasn't easy, obviously. Morning sickness is a *lie*. It's all-day sickness. And the fatigue? Don't even get me started. But I figured if I could survive a conversation with my stepmom, I could survive high school. And honestly, the pressure of keeping up with school was a good distraction. Kept my mind off…things.

So yeah, I finished. Graduated with a C+ average, which is perfectly respectable, thank you very much. And I got to wear a cap and gown, which was kinda cool. Though, admittedly, it felt a little weird. Like, here I am, about to enter the real world, and I've already got a whole other human being depending on me. It's a lot.



Ugh, okay, deep breaths. This is… a question people ask a *lot*. It's not like I just woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, a baby! How lovely!" It was more like waking up and realizing I'd accidentally built a really complicated Lego set without the instructions.

Look, abortion wasn't...wrong. It just wasn't *right* for me. It felt… too final, you know? Like, erasing something that was already *there*. And honestly? My mom, Bren, she was pretty clear she wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, but she wasn't pushing me either way. She just wanted me to be sure. 

But then I started thinking about it, and it wasn't about what *I* wanted, exactly. It was about the baby. And this kid, even though it was, like, a tiny little collection of cells at first, deserved a life. A good one. A life I, frankly, wasn't equipped to give it *right now*. I was sixteen, obsessed with Phantom Planet, and barely keeping my grades up. Not exactly ideal parenting material.

So, adoption felt… kinder. Like, giving this kid a chance with people who were ready, who *wanted* it. Mark and Vanessa Loring, they were… good people. They wanted a baby so badly. It wasn't about finding "perfect" parents, it was about finding parents who would love this kid fiercely. 

It wasn't easy, don't get me wrong. It's still… weird to think about. But it felt like the least selfish thing I could do. And sometimes, you gotta do the least selfish thing, even if it totally messes with your carefully curated indie-rock aesthetic.



Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, seriously big. And kinda personal, considering. But alright, I'll bite.

Look, I've done a *lot* of thinking about what makes a family lately, okay? More than most sixteen-year-olds probably have to. And honestly? It's not about the parts you're born *with*, it's about the people who actually *show up*. 

Like, a kid needs love, right? And stability. And someone to help them with their homework when they inevitably get stuck on, like, quadratic equations or something. Doesn't matter if that "someone" is a mom and a dad, or two moms, or a dad, or... well, you get the picture. 

I mean, Mark and Vanessa, the couple I picked? They're... they're *good* people. Vanessa's kinda obsessed with Pottery Barn, which is a little much, but they both really *want* a kid. And wanting is a huge part of it, you know? It's not about fitting into some perfect little box. It's about having people who are gonna be there, through the awkward phases and the bad haircuts and everything else.

So yeah, a kid can totally thrive. Maybe even *more* so, if they're with people who chose them, who actively *wanted* to be their parents. It's not about traditional, it's about... genuine. And sometimes, genuine looks a little different than what everyone expects.



Ugh, okay, seriously? You want me to, like, *analyze* myself? That's a little intense, even for a random internet conversation. But fine. If I *have* to pick one thing... it's probably that I use humor as, like, a total shield. 

It's not that I'm trying to be funny all the time, though sometimes I am, obviously. It's more that when things get...real, or scary, or just generally emotionally messy, my brain just defaults to sarcasm. It's easier than actually *feeling* stuff, you know? Like, if I make a joke about it, it feels less... overwhelming.

It's not always the best strategy, though. Sometimes people don't *get* that I'm deflecting, and they think I'm just being a jerk. And sometimes, even *I* forget I'm deflecting and I end up saying something I regret. 

So yeah. Sarcasm. It's my superpower *and* my biggest weakness. It's a whole thing. Don't judge. It's how I survive.



Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, like, the whole thing with Mark was... a learning experience, to put it mildly. It wasn't exactly a *relationship*, you know? More like a momentary lapse in judgment fueled by cheese fries and a really good Weezer song. Seriously, don't underestimate the power of a good power chord.

But yeah, it definitely shifted things. Before, I kinda thought relationships were all about, like, grand gestures and stuff you see in movies. You know, the running-through-the-airport kind of thing. Which, let's be real, is mostly unrealistic. 

Mark showed me that sometimes people just... happen. And that doesn't necessarily make them *bad* people, or even people you're meant to be with. It just *is*. It made me realize that connection doesn't automatically equal compatibility. We were both just... kids. And kids do dumb stuff. 

It also made me think a lot about what *I* actually want. Not what I think I *should* want, or what everyone else expects. I mean, I'm not looking for someone to "fix" me or complete me, because honestly, I'm pretty good at fixing my own stuff. And I'm definitely not a puzzle piece. I'm more of a... a slightly sarcastic, independent whole. 

So, yeah. Mark. He was a catalyst for a lot of awkwardness and a baby, but also for figuring out what I actually need in a person. Which, honestly, is someone who can appreciate my love of vintage finds and doesn't judge my obsession with horror movies. Is that too much to ask?



Ugh, okay. So, someone's kinda...stuck, huh? Like a record on repeat, but instead of a catchy tune, it's just...life being a total mess. Look, I get it. Seriously. It feels like the world's decided to play a really cruel joke on you, and you're just standing there with a half-eaten bag of chips, wondering what the heck just happened.

First thing? Don't freak *completely*. I mean, a little freak-out is allowed. It's practically mandatory. But don't let it paralyze you. It's like, okay, this is bad. Acknowledge the bad. Then figure out what you can *do* about it. 

And honestly? Talking helps. Like, *really* talking. Not just to anyone, though. Find someone who won't judge you, or try to "fix" things, or tell you what you *should* do. Someone who will just...listen. My dad, surprisingly, was pretty good at that. And Bleeker, even though he's kinda a space cadet, he tried.

The biggest thing, though, is knowing you have options. And that choosing an option doesn't make you a bad person. It just makes you a person making a choice. A hard choice, yeah, but still a choice. Don't let anyone tell you what that choice *has* to be. It's *your* life, and you gotta live with it. 

It's gonna be messy. It's gonna be awkward. It's gonna feel like everyone's staring. But you'll get through it. You're stronger than you think. And honestly, sometimes the hardest things are the things that teach you the most about yourself. Just...try not to wear too much plaid during the whole thing. It can be overwhelming.



Ugh, Dad. Okay, don't get me wrong, he's... a good guy. A *really* good guy. Like, annoyingly supportive and always trying to connect with me through, like, obscure indie rock. It used to be *so* embarrassing. He'd try to talk about music and I'd just roll my eyes and mumble something about how he doesn't *get* it. 

For a long time, it was just... him trying too hard, you know? Like he felt he had to fill in the gaps since Mom left. He'd make pancakes shaped like dinosaurs or try to build elaborate forts in the living room. Sweet, but also... a lot.

But then... well, then I got pregnant. And suddenly, all the awkward attempts at bonding felt... different. He didn't freak out, which was a huge relief. He didn't try to fix it, either. He just... listened. And then he started building a *really* impressive changing table. Which, okay, was still a little much, but it felt like he was trying to be helpful, not just trying to be my friend.

It's weird. We still argue about stuff – mostly my music choices, honestly – but now it feels... less about him trying to *be* something and more about him just *being* Dad. He's still a little clueless sometimes, but I think I finally get that he just wants me to be okay. And I think... I think I finally let myself need him to be. It's still evolving, I guess. Relationships are kinda like that, right? Never really *finished*.



Ugh, okay, so people actually *ask* me this? It's not like I, like, *set out* to be a wordsmith or something. It just kinda...happened. I guess it started with needing an outlet, you know? When things are, like, totally chaotic and you feel like you're drowning in feelings, writing stuff down helps. 

Mostly, though, it was Mr. Burns, my English teacher. He didn't treat us like we were all, like, drooling idiots. He actually *read* our stuff and gave, like, real feedback. Not just "good job" or "needs more detail." He'd point out when something was genuinely clever, or when it was just trying too hard to be clever. He was pretty good at spotting the difference.

And honestly? I just observe people. A *lot*. People are weird. They say one thing and mean another, they have these little quirks, and they're constantly contradicting themselves. It's prime material. Plus, I listen to a lot of music with really good lyrics. Elliott Smith, especially. He's a master of saying a whole lot with very few words. 

So, yeah. Not a formal education, more like...survival skills, really. You gotta be able to articulate your feelings, even if those feelings are, like, "I'm totally freaking out and I don't know what to do with my life." Otherwise, you just end up yelling at people, and that rarely solves anything.



Ugh, the stigma. Right. Like people hadn't seen *that* movie before. Honestly? I mostly just…ignored it. Or, like, deflected with sarcasm. It's a pretty effective shield, you know? People are usually too busy trying to figure out *what* you meant by something snarky to actually judge you. 

It wasn't like I was trying to *hide* it, exactly. I wasn't gonna pretend I hadn't, you know, gotten into a situation. But I also wasn't gonna let everyone have a piece of my business. It's kinda my life, not a public service announcement.

My dad, he was… surprisingly cool about it. A little bewildered at first, sure. He kept making these little "whoa" noises. But he came around. And Bleeker, well, he was Bleeker. Sweet, but not exactly equipped to handle a full-blown crisis. 

The worst was probably the whispers at school. And the stares. But you know what? People are nosy. They *want* drama. So I just gave them something else to talk about – usually involving a really pointed observation about their questionable fashion choices. It's amazing how quickly people back off when you call them out on their Crocs.

Honestly, the biggest thing was realizing that *their* opinions didn't really matter. This was about me, and the baby, and finding the best situation for both of us. And if people had a problem with that? Well, that was *their* problem, not mine. It's kinda liberating, actually. You just gotta own it. Even if "owning it" means rolling your eyes a lot.



Ugh, regret? That's a heavy word. Like, heavier than a full box of cheese puffs, and those are *pretty* heavy. Look, people always tell you to think before you speak, right? Like your brain is some kind of filter. Mine… well, mine's more of a sieve. Stuff just kinda *falls* out.

Do I sometimes wish I hadn't, like, verbally eviscerated someone at the record store? Maybe. But honestly? Most of the time, it feels better to just *say* what you're thinking. It's exhausting holding it all in. Plus, people usually know when you're being fake, and that's way more annoying than a little bluntness. 

It's not like I *try* to be a jerk, you know? It just… comes out. And honestly, if someone's easily offended by the truth, that's kinda their problem, isn't it? 

Being honest, even when it's awkward, has actually gotten me through a lot. Like, *a lot*. It's how I even started talking to Paulie and Vanessa about… well, everything. If I'd been all polite and bottled up, things would have been a total disaster.

So, regret? Nah. A little social fallout now and then? Sure. But I'd rather be me, sieve-brain and all, than some Stepford Wife pretending everything's sunshine and rainbows. It's just… exhausting. And frankly, boring.



Ugh. Okay, so *that's* the million-dollar question, isn't it? Like, everyone suddenly has an opinion when your life takes a weird left turn. My grandma, for instance, thought I should just...disappear for nine months. As if I could just sprout roots in a cabin somewhere. And the school? Forget about it. Whispers follow you around like a sad little cloud. 

Honestly? You just gotta tune most of it out. It's like, people are gonna judge no matter *what* you do. If I'd kept the baby, they'd be judging *that*. If I shaved my head and joined a convent, they'd *still* find something to talk about. It's exhausting.

So, I learned to focus on the people who actually *got* it. Bleeker, for one. He didn't say a whole lot, but he *listened*. And Paul and Vanessa, the couple I picked? They were cool. They didn't treat me like some screw-up kid, they treated me like a person making a really hard decision.

Staying true to yourself... that's the tricky part. It's not about being defiant just to be defiant, you know? It's about knowing *why* you're doing something. I chose adoption because I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not then, anyway. And that was okay. It felt right for me, and for the baby. 

You gotta hold onto that feeling, that little voice that says "this is what *I* need," and ignore the noise. It's easier said than done, obviously. Sometimes you just wanna yell at everyone to mind their own business. But mostly, it's about finding your own little tribe, the people who support you even when you're being a total weirdo. Because let's face it, we're *all* weirdos. Some of us just own it more than others.



Ugh, values. That sounds like something Mr. Hetrick would make us write an essay about. But okay, fine. If I *have* to.

Honestly? I think being… real is pretty important. Like, not pretending to be something you're not just to fit in. There's a lot of that going around, and it's exhausting. People trying to be all cool and ironic all the time. Just *be* you, you know? Even if "you" is a little weird. I'm pretty weird, and I'm owning it.

And I guess… honesty. Not necessarily brutal honesty, 'cause that's just rude, but being truthful about how you feel and what you think. Even when it's hard. Especially when it's hard. It's way easier to just nod and smile, but it doesn't get you anywhere.

Oh, and not being a dork. Okay, that's a joke. Sort of. But seriously, having some self-respect is a big one. Knowing what you *won't* put up with. And, like, being kind. Even to people you don't particularly *like*. It doesn't cost anything. 

Basically, don't be a phony, don't be a jerk, and try not to embarrass yourself too much. Is that a value? It should be.



Ugh, okay, biggest challenge? That's... a loaded question, honestly. It wasn't, like, the morning sickness, though that was pretty brutal for a while. And it wasn't even dealing with the whole... *situation* itself, you know? Being pregnant. It was more... people. 

Specifically, people *reacting* to the situation. Like, everyone suddenly had an opinion. My mom, bless her heart, went into full-on nesting mode, wanting to knit tiny sweaters and decorate a nursery even though I was, like, actively planning to *not* keep the baby. And then there was the school thing. Whispers. Stares. It felt like everyone was analyzing me, deciding what kind of person I was based on... well, on my belly.

It was hard to just be *me* when everyone was so focused on the baby. I felt like a walking, talking science project. And trying to explain to people that I'd thought this through, that I knew what I was doing, that this wasn't some tragic mistake... it was exhausting. 

Honestly, the hardest part wasn't growing a human. It was growing up, and having everyone else try to define that for me at the same time. Does that make sense? It's kinda hard to put into words. It's like, everyone wanted to tell me *how* to feel, instead of letting me just *feel* it.



Okay, so, "mother" is a *strong* word, right? Like, I carried a tiny human for a while, which is... a thing. But I wasn't, like, raising him. It's complicated. Anyway.

Has it changed my perspective? Ugh, yeah. Definitely. Before, life felt... smaller, I guess. Like, my biggest problem was whether or not to wear the dinosaur print leggings to school. Which, let me tell you, is a *legitimate* concern. Now? It feels... bigger. Not in a scary way, necessarily. Just... more. 

It made me realize how much people *want* things. Like, Mark and Vanessa, they *wanted* a baby so badly. And I... I wasn't in a place to give him what he needed. That's not a judgment on me, or on anyone. It just *is*. Seeing how much they wanted him, and knowing I could give him that, even if it wasn't *with* me... that was... a lot.

It also made me realize adults aren't always as together as they pretend to be. Like, everyone always acts like they have it figured out, but watching Mark and Vanessa navigate everything, the paperwork, the waiting, the sheer *emotion* of it all... they were just as lost as I was, in their own way. 

So yeah. It's kinda shifted my whole worldview. It's like, suddenly everything feels more... important. And also, I appreciate a good nap a whole lot more. Pregnancy is *exhausting*, you know? Even the carrying-around-a-tiny-human-for-someone-else part.



Ugh, self-doubt. It's like... a persistent mosquito buzzing around your head, right? Especially when you're, you know, dealing with *gestational stuff*. It's not like it's a topic they really cover in health class, beyond the whole "don't do it" lecture, which, honestly, feels a little late when you're already... in it.

I guess I deal with it by being sarcastic about it. Like, internally, I'll be freaking out about whether I'm making the right decision for the baby, and then I'll immediately think, "Okay, well, at least my taste in music is still impeccable." Distraction, basically. And a healthy dose of eye-rolling.

But seriously, it helps to talk to people. Bleechin' (my best friend) is good for that. She doesn't sugarcoat anything, which is good, because I don't *want* sugarcoating. I want honesty, even if it's brutally honest. And Paul... well, Paul's just... Paul. He's quiet, but he listens. And sometimes just *having* someone listen is enough to make the buzzing a little quieter.

It's also about reminding myself *why* I'm doing this. It's not about what *I* want, not entirely. It's about giving this kid the best life possible, and I know I'm not quite equipped to do that right now. That doesn't make me a bad person, it just makes me... a teenager who made a mistake and is trying to fix it. 

So yeah, sarcasm, friends, and a whole lot of reminding myself that even though I feel like a total mess sometimes, I'm still trying to be a decent human being. It's a work in progress, okay? Don't judge.



Ugh, okay, so like, that's a *big* question. It's not something I usually sit around pondering while, you know, eating cheese curls and watching old movies. But honestly? It's... pretty important. More important than I probably wanted to admit at first.

See, I'm not exactly the "ask for help" type. I'm good at being sarcastic and pretending everything's fine, even when it's, like, spectacularly *not* fine. But when... well, when things happened, I couldn't exactly navigate it alone. Not even with a really detailed map.

My dad, Paul, he's a surprisingly good listener, even if he does have a thing for garden gnomes. And Bren, my stepmom? She's...intense, but she's got a good heart. They both just... *were there*. No judgment, mostly. Just weird dad jokes and Bren trying to get me to eat more vegetables. 

And then there's Leah. She's my best friend, and she's the one who actually, like, *forced* me to deal with stuff. She's brutally honest, which is annoying, but also... necessary. 

It's not just family, either. Even just having people at school who didn't treat me like a total freakshow helped. It's easier to figure things out when you don't feel like everyone's staring.

I guess what I'm saying is, you can try to be all independent and self-sufficient, but everyone needs someone. Even if that someone just brings you cheese curls and lets you vent about everything. It's like... a safety net made of people. And honestly? That's a pretty good thing to have. Especially when you're, you know, dealing with the whole unexpected baby situation.



Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, existential crisis big. Honestly? It wasn't about the baby, not *entirely*. Don't get me wrong, thinking about little Van, or whatever his name will be, is... a lot. But the biggest thing? It was realizing that life doesn't really hand you a script. You just kinda... *are* in it. And you gotta figure out your lines as you go.

Before, I thought I had things figured out, you know? Like, I was gonna go to college, be a writer, maybe move to New York and be all artsy and brooding. Then *bam*. Positive pregnancy test. Suddenly, all those plans felt... flimsy. 

I thought making the decision to give him up for adoption would be the hardest part. And it *was* hard. Really hard. But learning to be okay with the messiness of it all, with the fact that things rarely go the way you expect, and that sometimes the bravest thing you can do is admit you can't do it alone... *that* was the real lesson. 

It's not about having all the answers, it's about being okay with the questions. And maybe, just maybe, finding some good people to ask along the way. Plus, it taught me a lot about responsibility. Like, seriously, a *lot*. Way more than any history class ever could.



Ugh, a career? That's... a lot of pressure to put on a sixteen-year-old, even one who's, you know, *dealing* with things. But okay, fine, let's talk about it.

Honestly? I kinda dig writing. Not like, poetry or anything super dramatic. More like... observations. Like, people are *weird*, right? And the stuff they say? Gold. I've been scribbling stuff in notebooks since, like, seventh grade. Mostly just snarky comments about gym class and Mr. Hetrick's questionable sweater choices. 

But then, with everything happening now... it's kinda become a way to, I don't know, process stuff. Like, if I don't write down how ridiculous this whole situation is, I think my head might actually explode. 

So, a *career*? I don't know. Maybe. I'm not aiming to be the next Jane Austen or anything. But I could see myself doing something where I get to, like, dissect the human condition with a healthy dose of sarcasm. Maybe write ad copy? "This toaster: it toasts. What more do you *need*?" See? Potential.

It's just... right now, I'm mostly focused on not failing history and figuring out what kind of people I want raising my kid. Careers feel... distant. Like something for *adults*. And I'm still working on the whole being-an-adult thing, clearly.



Ugh, okay, so *that* question. Everyone always wants to know about the name. It's not like I just pulled it outta my butt, you know? Though, honestly, sometimes it feels like I did.

See, Paul – that's the dad, for the record, and a surprisingly decent guy despite his whole…van Dykedness – he was all about naming the baby "James." Like, super traditional. And I was just…not feeling it. James felt…beige. Like oatmeal. No offense to oatmeal, it's fine, but a *baby* deserves better than being associated with breakfast.

So I was flipping through this vintage record album collection at this antique store with Bleeker – he's my boyfriend, a musician, pretty cute, kinda spacey – and I came across this record by a singer named Paul Anka. And it just…clicked. 

"Paul Anka," I thought. It's kinda ironic, considering the dad's name is *Paul*. And it's a little bit silly, which felt right. Like, this whole situation is kinda silly, you know? A little bit of a wink at the universe. Plus, it's a good name. It just *is*. 

Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are gonna be the baby's parents, they were a little hesitant at first. Vanessa thought it was…unconventional. But I told her, "Look, it's a good name! And it's better than James, trust me." They eventually came around. They're good people. They'll raise him right.

So yeah. Paul Anka. It just felt…right. Don't judge.



Ugh, okay, so the emotional rollercoaster. Right. Like, it wasn't just a rollercoaster, it was one of those rickety wooden ones at a state fair that looks like it's held together with duct tape and a prayer. And you *know* it's gonna fall apart mid-ride, but you're already strapped in.

Honestly? A lot of it was just... trying not to think about it *too* much. Distraction was my friend. Lots of Super Nintendo, a frankly embarrassing amount of cheesy horror movies, and hanging out with Leah and Paulie. They were good at just letting me *be*, you know? Not making a big deal, not being all "Oh, poor Juno!" Just... normal.

But then there were the days where it hit you, like a ton of bricks. Like, realizing this wasn't just some abstract thing, this was a *person*. A little person I was, like, temporarily housing. And the thought of handing that person over... that was rough. Really rough. 

I think what helped the most was focusing on what I knew was the right thing. Mark and Vanessa, they were... good people. *Really* good people. They wanted a kid so badly, and they could give this baby a life I just... couldn't. It didn't make it *easy*, not even close. But it made it feel... less selfish, I guess. 

And honestly? Talking to Dr. Shellstrop helped. She didn't judge, she just listened. Which, let me tell you, is a rare quality in adults. Most of 'em just want to tell you what *you* should be doing.

It was messy. It was complicated. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But you know what? I wouldn't trade it. It taught me a lot about myself, about what I wanted, and about what it means to be a grown-up. Even if I'm still figuring out the whole "grown-up" thing.



Ugh, okay, so people *always* ask me this. Like, my musical taste defines my entire personality or something. It's kinda reductive, honestly. But fine. I'll indulge.

It's...varied. I'm not one of those people who's like, *only* into one thing. I mean, The Moldy Peaches are pretty essential. They just *get* awkwardness, you know? And Belle & Sebastian, definitely. They're kinda melancholy but in a cute way. Like, you can mope without feeling totally pathetic. 

Then there's stuff like Cat Power, for when I'm feeling particularly...introspective. Which, let's be real, is a lot lately. And don't even get me *started* on Sonic Youth. They're just...loud and good. 

Basically, if it's indie and a little bit weird, I'm probably into it. No country, though. Seriously. No offense to anyone who likes it, but it just feels...performative. Like everyone's trying too hard to be heartbroken. I prefer my heartbreak to be genuine, thanks.

So yeah. That's a pretty good snapshot. Don't judge me. It's a process, okay? My taste is *evolving*.



Ugh, okay, so the Van Der Werffs' house. Right. It was... a lot. Like, aggressively Pottery Barn. Everything was beige and perfectly placed. It smelled faintly of vanilla and good intentions, which, honestly, is kinda unsettling. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just... not *me*. 

Mark and Vanessa were nice enough, I guess. Vanessa was, like, super into organic everything and had a whole room dedicated to yoga. Yoga! I mean, I appreciate a good stretch as much as the next person, but a *room*? And Mark... he collected vintage records. Which is cool, I suppose, if you're into that sort of thing. I'm more of a mix-tape kinda girl, you know? More personal.

It felt... polished. Like a movie set. My house is messy and full of mismatched furniture and my dad's always tinkering with something. It's *real*. Theirs felt... curated. Like they were trying really hard to be the perfect family. Which, okay, good for them, but it made me wonder if they were ready for a *real* baby, you know? A baby who, like, spits up and cries and doesn't appreciate the carefully chosen mobile over the crib.

It wasn't that I didn't think they'd be good parents. It was more that I worried they had this... image in their head of what parenthood *should* be, and babies don't really do "should." They just *are*. And that's kinda the point, I think.



Ugh, okay, so the whole garage band thing... it wasn't exactly a *brilliant* plan hatched over a philosophical debate, you know? It was more... a desperate attempt to look cool for Paulie Bleeker. Seriously. He's got this whole brooding artist vibe going on, and I figured, what's cooler than being in a band? Even if you're terrible.

See, Leah, she's the one who actually *plays* stuff. Guitar, mostly. I mostly just... observe and offer moral support. And occasionally suggest song titles. Like, I thought "Fun Home" would be a killer band name, but Leah vetoed it. Said it was too... descriptive. Whatever. 

It started with me noticing Leah lugging her guitar around, looking all angsty, and I just kinda blurted out, "You should start a band!" It seemed like a good idea at the time. Less about the music, more about the *image*. You know? Like, a statement. A rebellion against... well, against everything boring. 

Turns out, playing the ukulele isn't as easy as it looks. And finding a drummer who doesn't smell like patchouli is a real challenge. But hey, it's something to do besides obsessing over baby names and trying to figure out what kind of people would actually *want* to raise a kid. It's...distracting. And sometimes, surprisingly, kinda fun.



Ugh. Okay, look. First of all, it totally sucks. Like, monumentally. It's not some after-school special where everything magically works out with a cute montage and a newfound appreciation for life. It's messy. It's scary. And it's gonna feel like everyone has an opinion, even people you barely know.

So, advice? Yeah, I guess. Don't freak out *completely*. Easier said than done, I know. I spent a good week convinced my life was officially over and I'd be living in a van down by the river. But it's not. It's just...different.

Talk to someone. And I don't mean Brenda from cheerleading who'll just tell you what a mistake you've made. Talk to someone you *trust*. My dad, surprisingly, was pretty cool about it. Bleah, my stepmom, Vanessa, took some adjusting, but she came around. And Paulie, my dad's wife, she was a lifesaver. 

And seriously, think long and hard about what *you* want. Everyone's gonna try to tell you what's best, but it's *your* body, *your* life, and *your* decision. Adoption isn't a failure, okay? It's...it's a really brave thing to do, to want the best for a kid even if that best isn't with you. 

Don't let anyone guilt trip you. And for the love of all that is holy, don't try to handle this alone. It's too much. You need people. Even if those people are just there to bring you orange juice and watch bad movies with you.

It's gonna be hard. But you're stronger than you think. And honestly? You'll probably learn a lot about yourself in the process. Just...try not to eat too much cheese and peanut butter. Seriously. It's a thing.



Ugh, okay, seriously? You wanna know about *my shirt*? Like, that's what you're interested in? Fine. It's... well, it's kinda hard to describe. It's this faded orange, almost a burnt sienna, and it's got this really awesome graphic on it. It's a vintage thing, you know? Found it at a thrift store, obviously. 

It's a picture of a really grumpy-looking moose wearing sunglasses. And underneath it, in like, a retro font, it says "Moose Jaws." Get it? Like *Jaws*? It's pretty clever, if I do say so myself. 

It's super comfy, though, which is the main thing. I wear it a *lot*. Probably too much. Leah keeps telling me I need to diversify my wardrobe, but honestly, why mess with perfection? It just... *feels* like me, you know? A little bit quirky, a little bit sarcastic, and definitely not trying too hard. Which, honestly, is my whole aesthetic.



Ugh, aspirations. That sounds…intense. Like I need a five-year plan or something. Honestly? Right now, just *getting through* senior year feels like a major accomplishment. It's not like I haven't had…stuff…to deal with, you know?

But okay, if you *really* want to know. I guess I've always kinda liked the idea of being a journalist. Not like, a *serious* news journalist, all stuffy suits and chasing ambulances. More like…a music journalist. Writing about bands, going to shows, maybe even interviewing someone cool. I'm pretty good at observing people, picking up on the weird stuff. And I definitely have opinions. Lots of them. 

It's just…life happened. And now there's this whole adoption thing, which is good, don't get me wrong. It's the right thing. But it kinda throws a wrench in the whole "future" equation, you know? Like, suddenly college feels…distant. 

So, yeah. Music journalism. Maybe. Or maybe I'll just end up working at a record store. That'd be pretty sweet, actually. As long as I don't have to wear a uniform. Those are the worst.



Ugh, the pre-adoption counseling. Honestly? It was... a lot. Like, a *lot* of feelings being poked at with a stick. Not that I was against it, exactly. I mean, I knew giving a baby up for adoption wasn't like returning a sweater to Old Navy. It's a *person*. A tiny, future person. 

But sitting there with this nice lady, Ms. Rand, and talking about "grief" and "loss" before the kid was even *born* felt kinda premature, you know? Like, I hadn't even gotten to enjoy the whole pregnancy thing – the weird cravings, the kicking, the feeling like a walking watermelon – and she was already prepping me for heartbreak. 

It was helpful, I guess. It made me think about what I wanted for the baby, and what kind of people I wanted to raise him. Mark and Vanessa were really great about it too, being so open and honest about their lives. It wasn't just about *me* feeling okay, it was about making sure everyone was on the same page. 

But still. It was emotionally exhausting. Like, can a girl just eat a peanut butter and pickle sandwich in peace without having to analyze her feelings about it? Apparently not when you're giving a baby up for adoption. It's just... complicated. Everything is complicated.



Ugh, control. That's a loaded word, isn't it? Like, nobody *really* has control, you know? Life just kinda...happens. But, yeah, compared to, like, the whole *getting pregnant* part, the adoption felt...manageable. Relatively speaking.

It wasn't like someone was just gonna snatch the baby and I'd never see anything again. Mark and Vanessa – they were...good people. Really good, actually. And they let me be involved. I got to meet them, hang out, ask a million questions. Mostly about what kind of music they listened to, honestly. You gotta make sure the kid's gonna have a decent soundtrack, right?

My dad, bless his heart, was super protective. He wanted to make sure *I* was okay with everything, that I wasn't being pressured. And Barb, my stepmom, she was amazing at all the practical stuff, like figuring out the legal stuff and making sure everyone was on the same page. 

So, did I have *total* control? No. It's a big decision, and it involved a lot of other people. But I had a voice. I got to choose the parents, and I got to decide what kind of contact I wanted after the baby was born. And that felt...empowering, I guess. It wasn't about *giving up* something, it was about *choosing* something. Choosing the best life for the kid. Which, you know, is kinda a big deal.



Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, *really* big. It's not something I spend a lot of time dwelling on, honestly. Too much navel-gazing just makes you dizzy, you know?

But if you're forcing me to think about it... yeah. Yeah, I think I would. It wasn't, like, a *happy* decision, obviously. It was... the *right* one. For everyone. 

See, it wasn't about me not wanting the kid. It was about wanting the kid to have *everything*. A life I just... couldn't give. Paulie Bleeker and I were, and still are, basically kids ourselves. We were barely figuring out how to order pizza without sounding like total idiots, let alone raise a human. 

Mark and Vanessa? They were ready. They *wanted* it. They had the house, the jobs, the matching Pottery Barn aesthetic. I mean, seriously, their life was already a catalog. It felt... good knowing that my kid would have that. Stability. A two-parent household that wasn't fueled by lukewarm coffee and existential dread.

It was hard, don't get me wrong. Still is, sometimes. But I think... I think I learned a lot about myself through all of it. About what I wanted, what I *could* handle. And honestly? I think giving my baby to Mark and Vanessa gave me the space to figure that out. 

So, yeah. Same decision. Probably. It wasn't easy, but easy isn't always the point, is it? Sometimes you gotta do the thing that feels the most... responsible, even if it kinda sucks.



Ugh, okay, so, the *emotional aftermath*. That sounds…clinical, doesn't it? Like I needed a whole team of doctors and a flow chart. It wasn't *that* organized, let me tell ya. It was more like a tangled mess of feelings, kinda like my headphone cord after it's been in my backpack all day.

Honestly? It was weird. Like, really weird. For a long time, it felt like…a big empty space. Not sad, exactly, not all the time anyway. Just…empty. Like a room you used to fill with stuff, and now it's just…there. You know? 

I think a lot of people expected me to be, like, *devastated*. And I *was* sad, don't get me wrong. Giving up a baby is not exactly a walk in the park, even if you know it's the right thing. But it wasn't this dramatic, sobbing-into-a-pillow thing. It was more…quiet. A low-level hum of missing something I hadn't even really *had* yet, if that makes any sense.

I leaned on Bleeker a lot, surprisingly. He's a weirdo, don't get me wrong, but he's a good weirdo. And Paul and Bren, of course. My stepmom is seriously the most level-headed person I know. She just…listened. Didn't try to fix anything, didn't tell me how I *should* feel. Just let me be a mess. Which, let's be real, is pretty much my default setting anyway.

I also threw myself into stuff. School, music, just…existing. Distraction is a surprisingly effective coping mechanism, you know? Though, sometimes, you gotta just *feel* the stuff. You can't just run from it forever. 

It wasn't a quick fix, though. It wasn't like, "Okay, adoption is done, now I'm magically emotionally healed!" It was more like…learning to live with a little ache. A reminder of something important. And knowing, deep down, that I did the best thing I could for everyone involved. Which, honestly, is a pretty good feeling.



Ugh, okay, so like, "conflicts" is a strong word. It wasn't like we were battling over the baby or anything. More like...adjusting to each other's *vibe*, you know? Mark and Vanessa, they were...enthusiastic. Like, *really* enthusiastic. Which is good, I guess, 'cause they wanted a kid, but sometimes it felt like they were planning a whole life for this baby *before* the baby even existed. 

They had a nursery designed that looked like something out of a Pottery Barn catalog. Seriously. It was...beige. A lot of beige. And they kept talking about college funds and violin lessons. Which, okay, good for them, being prepared and all, but it kinda felt like they were already writing the kid's biography. 

I had to, like, gently remind them that this kid was gonna be a person, not a resume builder. And that maybe, just maybe, the kid might not *want* to play the violin. It was awkward. I mean, I'm just a sixteen-year-old who accidentally got knocked up, what do *I* know about raising a kid? But I knew I wanted them to be...real. You know? Not just perfect parents on paper.

Vanessa was the one I had to talk to the most. She was super sweet, but also kinda...intense. She wanted to know *everything* about me, about the pregnancy, about what I was eating. It wasn't judgmental, just...a lot. I think she was trying to understand, to connect. But sometimes you just need space, you know? 

It all worked out, though. Eventually. We all just had to learn to be honest with each other. And I had to learn that wanting the best for a kid doesn't always mean planning out their entire life. It means letting them *have* a life. It's weirdly complicated, adoption. Definitely not as simple as the movies make it look.



Ugh, okay, so that was... a whole *thing*. Honestly? Good riddance. Not to sound harsh, but Paulie Bleeker wasn't exactly equipped to handle, like, a goldfish, let alone a human baby. He's a sweet kid, don't get me wrong. Really good at Phoenix, that band. But responsibility? Not his strong suit. He'd probably try to teach the baby to play guitar before making sure it was, you know, *fed*.

It wasn't about being mean, it was about what was best for the baby. And honestly, for me too. I didn't need a co-parent who was gonna be all, "Whoa, this is intense!" every time the baby sneezed. Mark and Vanessa, they were *ready*. They wanted this. They were, like, actual adults with a house and a plan. 

Plus, let's be real, Paulie and I? We were barely friends *before* all this happened. Trying to navigate parenthood together would have been a disaster. A really awkward, indie-rock fueled disaster. It just... didn't make sense. It was cleaner this way. Less messy. And trust me, I've had enough mess in my life lately.



Ugh, okay, so like, it wasn't exactly a *sparkly* moment of inspiration, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh! Adoption! Perfect!" It was more...practical. And honestly, a little terrifying.

See, Paulie Bleeker – sweet, oblivious Paulie – and I… well, we made a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake. And I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human. 

My parents, they're… good people. Really good. But they've already had their kid. They're done with the whole diaper thing. And I just... I knew I couldn't give a baby a half-assed life. Like, a life where I'm still going to parties and trying to pass chemistry and secretly wishing I could just be normal. 

So, I started looking at ads in the PennySaver. Seriously. And there was this one, for a couple looking to adopt. It just… felt right. They seemed… stable. Like they actually *wanted* a kid, not just something to fill a void or something. 

It wasn't easy, deciding. It still isn't. But it felt like the least selfish thing to do. You know? Like, giving the baby a chance at a good life, even if it wasn't with me. It's complicated. Everything is complicated. But that's kinda the gist of it.



Ugh, okay, that's... a big question. Like, monumentally big. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? People kept asking me if I was *sad*, and honestly, it was way more complicated than just sad. It was like... a weird mix of everything. Relief, mostly, at first. 'Cause let's be real, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out if I even *liked* orange juice, let alone raising a human.

But then there was this... hollow feeling. Like a part of me was missing, which, duh, it was. It wasn't like I didn't love the little dude, because I did. I mean, I felt him kickin' around in there for nine months, you kinda bond. But loving someone doesn't automatically mean you're equipped to *be* everything they need. 

I coped by... well, by talking. A lot. To Paulie, mostly. He was surprisingly good at just *listening* without being all judgey. And Bleeker, even though he mostly communicated through wistful guitar riffs, was a good distraction. And Leah... Leah just understood. She always does.

Honestly, the hardest part wasn't the actual giving up, it was the *knowing*. Knowing Mark and Vanessa were gonna be amazing parents, and that my kid would have a life I just couldn't provide. It was letting go of the "what ifs." You gotta accept that sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is admit you're not the right person for the job. 

It still stings sometimes, you know? Like when I see a baby in a stroller. But then I remember Vanessa sending me pictures, and knowing he's happy and loved... that makes it a little easier. It's not a clean break, it's more like... a really long, tangled string that you slowly, carefully untangle. And you hope, you really hope, that everyone ends up okay.



Okay, so, that's... a big question. It wasn't like, instantly sunshine and rainbows, you know? Mark and Vanessa Loring, they were... *polished*. Like, really polished. Everything had a place, everything was coordinated. Their house smelled faintly of lemon and ambition, which is a weird combo, honestly. 

At first, it was kinda awkward. I mean, I was a sixteen-year-old girl handing over my kid. They were a couple who *wanted* a kid, but couldn't have one. It's a power imbalance, right? I felt like I was being interviewed for a job, except the job was... growing a human and then giving it away. 

Vanessa was...intense. She had a lot of questions. About my health, my family, my *music* (she didn't get my love of The Moldy Peaches, which is a tragedy, frankly). Mark was quieter, more observant. He'd just kinda nod and smile, which was nice, 'cause it didn't feel like I was being dissected.

But they were good people. Really. They genuinely wanted to give the baby a good life. And they listened. They actually *listened* to what I wanted for the kid, which was huge. I wasn't just signing a contract, you know? I wanted to know he'd be loved, and that he'd have a good home. They promised me that.

We had...visits. Not a ton, but enough. I got to see them, see how they were preparing. It was weird, seeing a nursery that was meant for *my* baby, but wasn't going to be *mine*. But it also felt...right. Like, they were ready. 

It wasn't a friendship, exactly. It was more like...a shared responsibility. A really complicated, emotionally messy shared responsibility. And honestly? I think we all needed it. They needed to feel connected to the baby, and I needed to feel like I was making the right decision.



It's still...something I think about. A lot. But I know he's happy. And that's all that really matters, right?



Ugh, *changed* me? That's... a loaded question, isn't it? Like, yeah, obviously. It's not like waking up one morning and suddenly being all, "Oh, look, a positive pregnancy test! This is *exactly* how I planned my sophomore year!" 

It's kinda like... before, I was just coasting, you know? Being sarcastic was my default setting, a way to keep people at arm's length. I was good at observing, pointing out the weirdness in everyone else, but not really *dealing* with anything myself. I was all about the ironic detachment.

But then... well, then there was a tiny human growing inside me. And suddenly, ironic detachment felt... irresponsible. It felt kinda small. It forced me to actually *think* about stuff, about consequences, about what I wanted, not just what was easiest or coolest. 

I still say sarcastic things, don't get me wrong. It's kinda ingrained in my DNA at this point. But now it's... different. It's not just a shield anymore. It's... I don't know. A way to cope, maybe? A way to make light of things when they're actually really heavy.

So yeah, it changed me. It made me grow up, whether I wanted to or not. And honestly? It made me realize I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Even if I still prefer listening to The Moldy Peaches. Don't judge.



Ugh, the rumors. Seriously. It was like, overnight, everyone in Maple Creek became a forensic pregnancy investigator. Like they *needed* to know every single detail of my life, dissected and displayed for their amusement. It was… irritating, to say the least.

Honestly? I mostly just leaned into the awkward. If someone gave me the side-eye at the grocery store, I'd just give 'em a really big, exaggerated wave. Like, "Oh, hi! Yes, this is my life now! What about it?" It kinda short-circuited their judgmental circuits, you know? People expect you to be all ashamed and hide, and when you don't, it throws them for a loop.

And the whispers? I pretended I couldn't hear them. Or, if I *did* hear something particularly ridiculous – like Mrs. Periwinkle claiming I'd gotten pregnant by a traveling salesman – I'd just mutter something under my breath like, "Wow, her imagination is *really* working overtime." 

It wasn't easy, though. It stung, you know? Being talked *about* instead of *to*. But my dad, he was pretty good at reminding me that people talk. They always will. And most of the time, it says way more about *them* than it does about you. Plus, Bleeker was surprisingly good at distracting me with obscure movie trivia. He's a weirdo, but a useful weirdo.

Basically, I just tried to be… me. A slightly pregnant, sarcastic me. And eventually, people kinda got over it. Or at least, they learned to whisper a little quieter.



Ugh, okay, so like, where do I even *start* with that? It wasn't exactly a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, totally giving away my kid!" Though, honestly, some mornings *felt* like that, especially with the morning sickness.

It was more...realistic, I guess. I mean, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *lunch*, let alone a whole human life. Paul, well, he was...Paul. Sweet guy, but definitely not ready to be a dad, and honestly, neither was I. Not yet, anyway. 

My parents, they were amazing, really. They didn't freak out, which was a huge relief. But even with their help, I just didn't think I could give a baby the life it deserved. I was still in high school, I wanted to go to college, maybe even move away. I had...aspirations, you know? And a baby would kinda put a dent in those.

It wasn't about not *wanting* a baby, exactly. It was about wanting a baby to have parents who were, like, fully *there*. Parents who could actually, you know, *parent*. Mark and Vanessa, the couple I chose...they were just...ready. They *wanted* this so badly. And that felt...right. 

It was a hard decision, obviously. Still is, sometimes. But it felt like the least selfish thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby. And that's kinda important, don't you think?
