Ugh, okay, so like, biggest fear? That's a loaded question, right? It wasn't, like, the *giving up* part, necessarily. I mean, that was… heavy. But I knew, pretty early on, that I wasn't equipped to raise a kid. Not then, anyway. I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to eat for breakfast most days.

No, my biggest fear was probably that the people I picked – Mark and Vanessa – would, like, *change their minds*. You know? That they'd meet me, see what a total weirdo I am, and decide I was too… messy. Too much of a project. And then where would the baby go? Back into the system? That thought kept me up at night. 

It felt really selfish, even thinking it, because it wasn't about *me* wanting to keep the baby, it was about me wanting *them* to want the baby. Does that make sense? It's just… you're handing over a tiny human, and you want to be absolutely, positively sure they're going to a good place. A *really* good place. And hoping they don't decide you're a total disaster and regret everything. 

It's a lot. Honestly, it's a lot.



Ugh, okay, so *that* story. People always ask about Bleeker. It's not like I sat down and was all, "Hmm, what tragically hip, vaguely artistic name shall I bestow upon the father of my child?" It kinda...happened.

See, Paulie, that's his real name, Paulie Bleeker, he's just...Bleeker. Like, that *is* him. He's a musician, right? Plays guitar, writes songs that are mostly about feelings and stuff. And he's just...quiet. Kind of blends into the background. Like a faded wallpaper pattern. 

So when I was trying to figure out what to call him, you know, to talk about him with everyone without being *totally* obvious, "Paulie" felt...insufficient. Too normal. Too...*him*. "Bleeker" just sort of slipped out. It felt...right. It sounded like a character in a Wes Anderson movie, which, let's be real, is a compliment. 

Plus, it's kinda funny. Like, "Oh, I'm seeing Bleeker." It just sounds...less intense than "I'm seeing Paulie." Which, honestly, was a good thing at the time. It was a way to distance myself from the whole situation, I guess. A little bit of ironic detachment. You know, my coping mechanism.

Don't tell him I said all that, though. He'd probably write a really depressing song about it. And honestly, I've had enough emotional labor for one lifetime.



Ugh, okay, so like, people always ask that. It's not like I *set out* to be a punk, you know? It just...fit. Everything else felt kinda...beige. Like, all the other girls were into, I don't know, Hilary Duff or whatever, and it just felt...manufactured. 

Punk's just *real*. It's messy and loud and doesn't apologize for being itself. And the music? It's not all just screaming, okay? There's actually a lot of really smart stuff in there, about, like, questioning everything and not just blindly following what everyone else is doing. Which, honestly, felt pretty relevant even *before* the whole...situation. 

Plus, the clothes are comfy. Seriously. Skinny jeans and band tees? Way better than trying to squeeze into something sparkly. It's a whole vibe, you know? A "don't mess with me, I'm thinking" vibe. And after a while, it just becomes *you*. It's a way to say, "This is who I am, deal with it." Which, let me tell you, is a skill you pick up pretty quick when you're... navigating life.



Ugh, the D-word. Divorce. It's... a thing, right? Like, a really *big* thing that happens when people decide they can't stand to look at each other anymore without wanting to, I don't know, re-arrange the furniture with their faces. 

It definitely messed with my head, growing up with it. My dad, he just... left. Poof. Went to find himself and his inner pottery artist or whatever. Mom, she was just...tired. And honestly, I get it. They weren't *horrible* people, just... not good *together*.

I think it made me kinda wary of, like, the whole "forever" thing. Like, what if "forever" is just five years and a really awkward conversation about who gets the good spatula? It made me not want to rely on anyone *too* much, you know? Like, if they leave, you're just back to square one, only with more emotional baggage.

So, with Paulie Bleeker... well, he's Paulie. He's solid. He's *there*. And he doesn't talk about his feelings a lot, which, honestly, is a plus. But I think I kept things pretty casual for a long time because of it. Didn't want to get all invested and then have someone pull the rug out from under me. 

It's weird, though. Having a baby kinda forces you to deal with that stuff. You can't just be all detached and ironic when there's a tiny human depending on you. You gotta, like, actually *commit* to something. And that's... scary. But also, maybe, kinda good.



Ugh, okay, so people keep *asking* me this. Like, it's not exactly a topic I volunteer for dinner conversation, you know? But alright, I'll bite.

I guess what makes my story... not *normal*, because let's be real, it's pretty far from normal... is that it's not some super dramatic, tear-jerking after-school special. It's messy. It's awkward. It's got a lot of really weird people involved. And it's about making a choice, a *big* choice, and actually sticking to it, even when it's hard and everyone's got an opinion.

Most stories I see, they're all about keeping the baby, or, like, giving it up because something *terrible* happened. Mine was... different. It was about wanting to do what was best for everyone, even if "everyone" included a little person I hadn't even met yet. 

And honestly? It's about realizing that being a grown-up isn't about knowing all the answers. It's about figuring out what you *want* and then being brave enough to go for it, even if it's not what anyone expects. Plus, Paulie Ruffner is involved, and that alone makes it pretty special, in a spectacularly weird way. Don't tell him I said that.



Ugh, okay, good friends. That's... a surprisingly deep question, considering I just spent the last hour trying to decide if orange juice counts as a vegetable. But alright, I'll bite.

Honestly? I don't need a friend who's gonna, like, *agree* with everything I say. That's just...boring. I value someone who'll call me on my crap, you know? Like, if I'm being a total sarcastic mess, they'll be like, "Juno, seriously?" and not just laugh along. 

But it's gotta be done *right*. It can't be all judgy and preachy. It has to be...gentle ribbing, maybe? And a healthy dose of understanding that I'm probably just deflecting 'cause I'm actually feeling stuff.

Mostly, though, I need someone who can just *be*. Someone I can sit with in silence and not feel awkward, someone who won't freak out if I start rambling about obscure indie bands or the existential dread of suburban life. And, like, someone who won't judge me for...well, you know. *Everything*. 

Leah's pretty good at that. She doesn't always *get* me, but she tries. And she brings snacks. That's a big plus. Basically, a good friend is someone who doesn't make me feel like I have to be anyone other than a slightly cynical, perpetually awkward teenager. Is that too much to ask?



Ugh, okay, so like, *everyone* had an opinion all of a sudden. It's not like I was invisible before, but suddenly I was this…project. Like a science fair experiment gone slightly awry. 

My relationship with my dad, Paul? That got…weirdly good, actually. He was surprisingly chill, you know? Like, he didn't *get* it, not at all, but he tried. He made me pancakes a lot. Comfort pancakes, I think he called them. It was kinda sweet, even if he did keep asking if I was sure about, you know, *everything*.

My stepmom, Bren? She was a lifesaver. Seriously. She was the one who actually went with me to all the appointments and didn't treat me like I'd grown a second head. She's just…practical. And she makes a mean casserole. 

But Leah…Leah was…difficult. She was mad. Like, *really* mad. Said I was ruining everything. Our band, our future, everything. It sucked. We didn't talk for a while. It felt like she just didn't understand that this wasn't some grand plan, you know? It just *happened*. Eventually, she came around, but it took a while. It made me realize some friendships are…fragile, I guess.

And then there was Bleeker. Oh, Bleeker. That was a whole other level of awkward. He tried to be supportive, which was nice, but he mostly just looked terrified. Like I was going to explode or something. 

Basically, it sorted out who was actually *in* my corner and who was just along for the ride. And honestly? I think I needed that. It's a good way to figure out who you can really count on, even when things are totally messed up. It's not always pretty, but it's…real.



Ugh, okay, deep thoughts already? Seriously? Fine. But don't expect, like, a super polished, inspirational speech. I'm not exactly Oprah, you know?

Okay, so... I guess the biggest thing is just... being real. Like, people try so hard to *be* something, to fit in, to be cool. And it's just... exhausting. And usually kinda pathetic. I'd rather just be me, even if "me" is a little awkward and says things other people are thinking but wouldn't *dare* say out loud. 

I also think it's important to be honest, even when it sucks. Like, lying just makes things messier in the long run. And yeah, sometimes the truth hurts, but it's better than building everything on a foundation of, like, total BS.

And... this is gonna sound weird coming from someone who, you know, *is* dealing with a pretty big thing... but I think people should be allowed to make their own choices. As long as they're not hurting anyone, obviously. It's their life, their mess. They gotta own it. 

I guess that's it. I'm not trying to save the world or anything. Just trying to navigate this whole thing without turning into a total sell-out. Does that make sense? It's kinda hard to articulate when you're, like, constantly being bombarded with teen movie tropes.



Ugh, okay, so the whole naming thing was... a process. Not like, a *fun* process, you know? It wasn't like I was flipping through baby name books dreaming of "Penelope" or whatever. It had to be something... good. Something the people who were gonna *actually* raise him deserved. 

See, Mark and Vanessa, they were kinda stuck. They had a whole list of super preppy, kinda boring names. Like, "William" and "Henry." Seriously? It felt weird picking a name for someone I wasn't gonna be, like, *raising*. It felt... presumptuous.

Then, one day, I was flipping through this old National Geographic – don't judge, it was at my dad's – and there was this article about the constellation Leo. And it just... clicked. It felt strong, but not *too* strong, you know? Like, not "Thor" or something. And Vanessa, she was really into astrology, so it kinda fit with their vibe. 

Plus, it just sounded good. Leo. It's a solid name. Not overly fussy. And honestly? It felt like a little piece of me, choosing something good for him, even if I wasn't gonna be there to see him grow up with it. It was... a responsible thing to do, I guess. Which, for me, is saying something.



Ugh, okay, deep thoughts time. Don't get me wrong, I was *totally* capable of handling a baby. Like, I could've figured out the whole diaper situation, probably. But that's not the point, is it? The whole thing... it was like a really intense crash course in, well, *everything*.

I learned I'm way more resilient than I thought. Seriously. Before Paulie Bleeker and the whole... situation... I was just kinda drifting, you know? Existing. But having to actually *think* about the future, not just for me, but for this little person... it forced me to grow up, like, immediately. It wasn't graceful, let me tell you. Lots of awkwardness and sarcastic comments to mask the panic.

And the world? The world is full of people who are... complicated. Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted Baby MacGuff, they weren't what I expected. They were... perfect, almost. And it made me realize that "perfect" doesn't mean boring. It just means they were ready. And *I* wasn't. Not yet. 

I also learned that wanting something for someone else doesn't make you selfish. It took me a while to wrap my head around that. I wanted this baby to have a life I couldn't give it, and that wasn't a failure on my part. It was... a really brave thing, actually. Even if it felt totally terrifying at the time.

Honestly, the biggest lesson? People are messy. Life is messy. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just admit that, and try to make the best of it. And maybe eat a really good peanut butter sandwich while you're at it. That always helps.



Ugh, okay, that's a *big* question. Like, existential crisis big. Honestly? Probably not a whole lot. It was... messy. A total, beautiful, awkward mess. People always wanna know if I regret it, if I wish I'd kept the baby. And it's not about regret, you know? It was about doing what was *right*. For everyone. Especially the kid.

But if I *had* to pick something... maybe I would've been a little less sarcastic with Mark and Vanessa at first. I mean, they were genuinely good people, trying to figure things out, and I was just... shielding myself with snark. It's kinda my default setting, you know? Like a protective layer of irony. 

I think I was scared of letting them *see* me, the real me, the one who was freaking out about growing a human and then giving it away. It felt safer to be witty and detached. But they were so patient, and eventually, I let my guard down. And that's when things actually started to feel... okay.

So yeah, maybe a little less sass upfront. But honestly, even the sass was part of the process. It was *me* figuring things out. And if I changed that, I might've changed everything. And honestly? I'm pretty happy with how things turned out. Even if it was, like, the most intense experience of my life.



Ugh, disappointment. It's, like, a constant companion, isn't it? Especially when you're a teenager and everything feels *super* important. Honestly? I mostly just...acknowledge it. Like, yeah, that sucked. That really, really sucked. Then I try to figure out if dwelling on it is actually *productive* or if I'm just being melodramatic. Which, let's be real, is a valid option sometimes. 

See, I've learned that plans are mostly just suggestions the universe makes, and then laughs at when you try to stick to them. Like, I thought I had this whole thing figured out with the adoption, right? Pick the perfect parents, everything's gonna be smooth sailing. And it *was* mostly good, but there were bumps. And moments where I was like, "Seriously? *This* is happening?" 

You just gotta...roll with it, I guess. And eat a lot of cheese and peanut butter. That helps. A lot. It doesn't *fix* things, but it makes them slightly less awful. And sometimes, the disappointment leads you to something better than you originally planned. It's weird, but true. It's like, sometimes you gotta lose something to realize what you really want. Or, you know, just to realize you can survive without it.



Ugh, Leah. Okay, don't get me wrong, she's...intense. Like, permanently dialed up to eleven. But she was *essential*, you know? Before all this...situation...happened, we were just kinda orbiting each other at school. She was the super-stylish, super-into-everything girl, and I was...well, me. I mostly just observed. And made sarcastic comments. It's a talent.

But then, when I found out I was pregnant, everything shifted. Suddenly, I needed someone who wasn't gonna freak out and judge me, and who also wouldn't treat me like I was made of glass. She *did* freak out a little, initially. A lot, actually. But then she got over it, and she was just...there. 

It wasn't always easy. She had her own stuff going on, you know? Trying to be a perfect student, dealing with her mom...and then she got all into the whole adoption thing *way* more than I did for a while. Like, she was planning the nursery before I'd even decided what kind of music the baby would like. It was a little much.

But she was genuinely trying to help. And she listened. Even when I was being a total mess and just rambling about how weird everything was. She didn't try to fix things, she just...let me *be* with it. And that's what I needed. 

So, yeah, it went from kinda casual acquaintance to...I don't know, a real friendship. A messy, complicated, sometimes-annoying-but-ultimately-supportive friendship. It's good to have someone who can call you on your BS, you know? And Leah is *really* good at that.



Okay, wow. That's... a loaded question, honestly. Like, "favorite part" implies there was a *lot* to choose from, and while it wasn't all bad, let's not pretend it was a walk in the park, okay? I mean, morning sickness is a misnomer. It should be "all-day-and-sometimes-night sickness." Not glamorous.

But, if I *had* to pick something... I think it was the feeling of, like, having this little secret. Not a *bad* secret, you know? Just... something completely mine. Before that, I was just Juno, the girl who liked records and avoided gym class. Suddenly, I was carrying a whole person. It was kinda... empowering, in a weird way. 

And the kicks. Those were pretty cool. Felt like a tiny little alien doing karate inside me. Though, sometimes it was right when I was trying to eat a peanut butter sandwich, which was less cool. 

But mostly? It was realizing I wasn't as totally clueless as I thought I was. I mean, I was still pretty clueless, don't get me wrong. But I could handle things. Big things. Even if "handling things" meant deciding to find the *perfect* parents for a kid I knew I couldn't raise myself. It was... complicated. But yeah, the secret, and the kicks. Those were alright.
